It was a wonderful selection of South American art with a look at the progressive and reflective views of the socioeconomic/sociopolitical views in a modern and beautiful display....just great Art! The most important museum in Buenos Aires. What a collection! from Frida Kahlo to Berni, all the most important artista from latin america are held in this impressive and modern building. the place lives art in a way that you feel embrace by it by the momento you set foot inside.We had tea at Marcelo's next door, great cakes and tea! lovely waiter and staff, a little pricy, but worth it

A great permanent collection, rich events and one of the best landscapes of Buenos Aires. The building offers a great scenery for every art exhibition, and a permanent collection which make it a must see in Buenos Aires.As every museum around the world, photo and recording are restricted but not prohibited.Depending of programmation you can expend a whole day here, resting in the nice cafe and even buying some souvenirs at the gift shop.
Wonderful . Not huge. But definite quality gallery. It was a wonderful peaceful and educational gallery. The Yoko Ono exhibition was on when I went. The Latin American exhibition was excellent.

MALBA all times!. This is one of thr best museum you might have the opportunity to visit and enjoy in Latin America! Definitely a must-visit attraction in Buenos Aires. Temporary installations are unique! Enjoy!

A great visit. I am not normally a museum goer, but with time to spare, MALBA was recommended.
They were showing the Yoko Ono exhibit.... really interesting and very interactive. A good place to spend a couple of hours, and good value

Small but very interesting museum. Very nice!. Small and nice. Gives a great sense of the tensions and problems of Latin America expressed thru art. For me, a must see especially if not from Latin America
Nice!!!!!. Beautiful! Similar to MASP, MALBA is a must-see. Great curators put on a great show every time. Saw Yoko Ono's dream come true and loved it!

Mediocre. A lot of the main exhibition was closed when we visited which was a little disappointing, pales in comparison to many other world museums but conversely has a number of interactive exhibitions which was pretty cool!
Enjoyed the Yoko Ono exhibit

Some really nice pieces in here - worth the visit. Nice building, and the latin american art on the first floor is exceptional - some amazing works here. The Yoko Ono exhibition on at the time was a waste of space, but would recommend a visit.

Cultural center. the MALBA is more than a museum, it is more like a cultural center with lots of interesting activities happening, from movies to special exhibitions to classes and guided tours. The permanent exhibition that is well worth a visit in this beautiful museum.

Enjoyable few hrs. Visited Yoko Ono exhibition here a whilst on a few day city visit. Easy to get around if you have a couple of free hrs. Also on hop on hop off bus route so worth the stop. Wednesday's seems to be reduced prices also.

Delightfully Diverse. We liked what we saw in this museum. We enjoyed seeing Diego Rivera and Frieda Kahlo...but only one piece each. Several other Latin American artists had works on display as well. Yoko Ono's exhibition was on display. It was both interesting and bizarre.
Great place. Loved this gallery. They currently have Yoko Ono's exhibition going on too which was super interesting. And there's a wiahing tree outside - be sure to stop over!

Museum of Latin American Art Buenos Aires. Great building. Must see the Yoko Ono temporary exhibit. The permanent exhibit is bit boring, mostly Brazilian and Argentian artists from 20th century.
The shop does not offer very creative items except for Perfectos Dragones jewelry.

interesting and informative- a good way to spend an afternoon. I had the pleasure of seeing the latest Yoko Ono exhibit but wish more of the text was in english as well but fair play, as it is in Argentina and Spanish is expected....my phrase book and google translate did help in deciphering most of it!Another interesting exhibit was by an artist called Voluspa Jarpa who used the concept of classified U.S. government documents to highlight some of the biggest political movements in South America....I really enjoyed this one!
Loved it. Yoko Ono retrospective when I went, just a pity they didn't use her original English text so had to translate back from Spanish!
need to visit. spent 2 hours inside , spledid art works and you do not need t pay for a tour , juts go and buy a cheap ticket

an interesting place. Even if Buenos Aires is a city that has a lot of other attractions to offer, a longer stay can successfully include MALBA. The building is a nice example of modern architecture, placed in the nice Palermo district, at a walking distance from the very pleasant Japanese garden. When we visited MALBA the main collection was actually closed to the public but we visited a very exciting Yoko Ono exhibition. A lot of young people were visiting it, making a vibrant atmosphere.

You must be a big fan of Modern Art. This attraction was written up by many of being really good. We found this museum somewhat disappointing. It might be the art contained within the museum was not what I like. There are many other places that you can see in Buenos Aires that are better.
Me gusta. It would be nice to have more guided visits and tours but overall a great experience. It is always good to know more about Latin American Art
love love love. Absolutely stunning array of beautiful, insightful and unique art. Shows the vibrancy of Latin American Art. I am sure there is something for everyone to like.

Disappointed - most of it closed. We trekked all the way there by crowded subway and a 2 km walk only to find that most of the museum was closed for refurbishment. So we could only see one small exhibition (free) and the Yoko Ono exhibition which costs 100 pesos. I am not a fan of her work and that sure hasn't changed after seeing this. So just make sure that you check before you go there that it has reopened .

Excited to see Yoko Ono. This was one of the highlights of my trip. The museum is beautiful and the exhibit very well curated and hanged. Unfortunately, the day I went the permanent collection area was closed. Great visit for those who love art.

Thought provoking displays of modern art. The Museo de Arte Latinoamericano, or MALBA, is the brainchild of Eduardo F. Constantini. Unfortunately, at the time I visited, its standing exhibit of Latin American Art was closed for updating. However, there are two other exhibits that are well worth seeing.One is a retrospective of Yoko Ono's work.I have to make a confession here--can I make a confession here?--Yoko Ono kind of makes my head hurt. Her form of interactive, creative art in the past has struck me as just too avant-garde, maybe too precious and self-congratulatory. But then again, Dar Williams in one of her shows talked about how, from her perspective, John Lennon was most famous as Yoko Ono's spouse, and not the other way around, so I decided to give Yoko another try.Much of the art was as I recall it. There are instructions for things one can do--an example is, to climb a ladder and at the top, take the magnifying glass and look at the painting hanging from the ceiling to find the word "Si." Which I do. As I wandered around following (or not) the instructions, watching others do the same, and also taking in some of her other kinds of pieces such as videos, a room with broken pieces of pottery that everyone is supposed to piece together however they wish using masking tape and string, and broad maps upon which anyone can stamp the words "peace" wherever they wish, I found myself having a more charitable interpretation than before. Maybe it's the fact that everything is in Spanish, which adds a layer of remove (although there are also English translations in small font underneath). I've said before in other places that the question of art, especially modern art, is one I struggle with, although deferring to those whose job it is to curate exhibits seems like a reasonable approach, if an abdication of the responsibility which I suspect many modern artists would prefer remain with the viewer. An exhibit like this is a good example. People taking in these exhibits are meant to participate, and others to watch the people participating, until the boundaries between the artist, the art, and the pubic dissolves. The second exhibition is a show by Voluspa Jarpa that takes many of the declassified papers from the years of the Cold War and through a variety of media uses them and images and constructions to ask pointed questions about the role of the US in fomenting specific policies and players in the region's politics. It's a jarring, creepy picture; leafing through documents detailing how the US government had clear preferences and policies concerning different groups in these independent countries is disturbing if not surprising. Some of the exhibits that employed laser-cut plastic to copy pages, symbols and fonts are particularly striking. I regret that the permanent exhibit is temporarily closed, but it's still a beautiful space and well worth visiting.

Fun!. We went in late Aug (late winter/early spring) and the main museum was temporarily closed until Sept. However, the price of admission was very cheap so went to the special exhibits of Yoko Ono and visual artist Veluspa Jarpa. Both were so good and worth the trip. The Yoko Ono retrospective had many interactive exhibits that were thought provoking and fun. The Jarpa exhibit was a fascinating exploration of political documents such as declassified reports about kidnappings, murders, assassinations etc in South America.

A must-see experience for Latin American art, culture, and history. A visit to the MALBA should be high on anyone's list in Buenos Aires. The permanent exhibits are well curated, thought-provoking, and each one, truly an attraction. Even for individuals who are not traditionally art lovers, the collections have something for everyone- from modern art to ancient Latin American works to conversation pieces and exhibits that challenge the way we view ourselves and the world around us. The MALBA is reasonably priced and located in the beautiful Palermo district of the city. It took us about two hours at a relaxed pace to tour the entire museum and we felt like we had the full experience. A fantastic attraction!

Questionable.. At the time I visited there was no permanent exhibition. Downstairs there is an accessible installation. Political and leaning to the left. It would be nice to vist the full building to gain a good understanding.

Unexpectedly wonderful & witty. It was absolutely ...have no words for it. I went there expecting nothing, I admit it and I just fell for the beauty, humour and witty or intelligence of the exposees!! Congrats to the curators! And to the artists, in the end. I like to consider the Argentinians modern artists are so full of this qualities. Cause this is what the visit let me think of. I strongly recommend it to every intelligent person!

Museum shut down due to construction . Stay away till 15th Sep. Most of the museum closed due to reconstruction. The part of the museum that is open is yoko yono exhibits. There are no notices for these shutdowns outside. We were in the line waiting for the museum to open and were excited to see the exhibits. They should put up a proper notice that most of the exhibits are closed so that travelers can plan better.

Modern museum. Visited on a Monday morning (not as busy) during the Yoko Ono "Dream come true" exhibit, which was a nice surprise and also went through the permanent contemporary collection, which is comprised of Alejandro Xul Solar, Frida Kahlo, Antonio Berni, etc. Great place to visit in Buenos Aires...

Great space, top exhibitions. Museums are great to let you feel like you're getting a little bit of culture, but often the visiting exhibitions are the better offerings. And while Yoko Ono's show was very interesting, the Latin American Art was the highlight.

Nice little spot. Buenos Aires has a vibrant gallery scene but surprisingly few fine arts museums for a city of its size. MALBA is an interesting and well curated - albeit small - collection [mostly modern] art from all over Latin America. You can cover the whole collection in 1-2 hours at a leisurely pace.

Well Worth Visiting. The Yoko Ono peace exhibit is currently being featured. While not Latin American art, the show adds value to spending a few hours in the galleries where important work of the region is displayed. The museum is just the right size for families with children or for adults.

Viva MALBA!. Great works of art mixed with life exhibits. We enjoyed the visit far more that we could have anticipate. Our little one enjoyed the modern exhibits in which she got to participate and be a part of the exhibition. It's truly a gem. The young flock to this museum and with good reason; it's provocative and inspiring.
Don't miss that place. MALBA is an excellent chosie, especially during the rainy day. At the moment they host an extraordinary exhibition of Yoko Ono, so harry up!

Interesting and not too big sample of Latinamerican art. This museum has a reasonable size that will allow the visitor to spend some time enjoying its very varied display of the most important Latinamerican modern artists. Being the result of the personal collection efforts of an Argentinian business man it does not necessarily follow a structured or preset catalogue of artistic periods but it includes most of the biggest names of Latinamerican painting from Diego Rivera and Antonio Berni to the most recent developments in Pop art or Minimalism. It is also home to an excellent cinema that shows independent films and it offers interesting temporary exhibitions.
Amazing place to visit. I completely loved it! Went there yesterday and it looks like they have put a lot of effort on it. Place very clean and much variety on the art, highly recommended !
Fantastic museum. If you are in Buenos Aires you MUST go here! Even if this museum is not very big it's so cool! You can admire masterpieces by Frida Kahlo, Botero and other famous latin artists!
Fabulous . Wonderful collection on modern Latin American art and a lovely building. Learned a lot about artists I did not know. Lovely museum.

Simple and beautiful. This museum is found in the neighborhood of Palermo, which is easily reached by the bus system, or colectivo. As a student, I was able to get in free with my student ID on Wednesdays, but in order to avoid the long lines, I recommend that you "buy" your tickets on line (there is no charge for student Wednesday, but you need the reservation to get in) your online ticket comes to you in the form of a QR code you can show on your phone. While there, Yoko Ono had a featured exhibit, which was terrific if you enjoy conceptual art. There are great representative pieces from great Latin American artists: Frida Khalo, Diego Rivera, Xul Solar, Botero, and much more. The space is ample and the bookstore and gift shop are reasonably priced as far as museums go. A very pleasant experience overall.

Best in the City. I have been to the MALBA twice on different occasions, and its AMAZING, must visit if you are in the city.He visitado el MALBA en dos ocasiones y siempre es una experiencia increible. Visita obligada si estas en Buenos Aires. MUY Recomendado.

Latin American Art. Went to the Museum of Latin American Art of Buenos Aires expecting the best and I was not disappointed. It is a must see museum. Lovely architecture, excellent presentations, good service and a wonderful restaurant to boot. I enjoyed visiting the different rooms full of excellent representations of Latin American Art. The store has a lot of the typical museum findings. The books for sale are a pleasure.
Amazing Art!. If you enjoy art, this is a must. I was able to go without my 5 year old and very thankful. He would not have enjoyed this at all. But I did! There is something for everyone.
excellent introduction to LA artists. an excellent introduction to latin american artists, this museum shows several works of major importance to our history back home.
One of the main museum in Buenos Aires. Latinamerican art for everyone in a beautiful and modern museum. Do not forget to go to the shop: is has a lot of creative things to take back home.

All Kinds of Interesting. Though a little overpriced, MALBA is a must-see for any modern Latin American art aficionado. I moved here not long ago, and found it a bit smaller and less-filled than I had envisioned. It's 3rd floor is in construction, but the Rivera and Botero pieces are incredible to see up close. There are sculptures and 3D pieces that offer a more interactive experience, but my personal favorite exhibit was the traveling exhibit of Claudia Andujar Marcados. Definitely worth the minor frustrations.
Great museum! . This place is fantastic. This is all art we don't see much of in North America. Really fantastic way to access the visual culture of Latin America. Fabulous.

Beautiful building, not particularly big enough.. We went here on a rainy day in BA and while the building was beautiful the temporary exhibit (on Yoko Ono) was just not that great. Since it is a small place this was half the experience. Be sure to check out the new exhibits before you go as it is one of the more expensive visits in the city.

Nice gallery to spend an hour. . The museum shows local artists as well as changing expositions. It's relatively small and undergoes renovations. Interesting to spend a quick hour but not more than that as there are not so many rooms of exhibition. They have a nice museum store.

Not my taste but worth the visit. Very disappointed in Yoko Ono exhibition. Personally, I cannot connect. Feeling that the Michael is being taken out of me. However, other exhibits were of interest which did make the visit worthwhile. By far, I preferred Museo Nacional De Bellas Artes.

WOW - Amazing art and architecture. I visited the MALBA last week in Buenos Aires. I am a volunteer at the Getty Center and the MALBA is similar in the awe-inspiring feeling of space and light while viewing world class art. The curators exhibited the art in the most profound way. This visit is a memory for a lifetime. Not to be missed while in Buenos Aires..

Great collection. MALBA has a great collection of different Latin American (and international) artists. There is a variety of different pieces - paintings, interactive pieces, sculptures, pottery, etc. It takes about an 70 minutes to walk around the entire museum. When I visited, the top floor was being prepped for the Yoko Ono exhibit, so I unfortunately did not get to see it. However, everything else is excellent. Also, on wednesdays, admission is free for students + half-price for others.

Nice museum poor exposition. I went to the museum with a great expectation to see Yoko Ono exposition and it was a great disapointment. It's interactive, we can say modern but in my opinion nothing to do with art.The permanent part it worth much more.
Nice S-american art, but overrated. MALBA has some imortant and beautiful pieces of south-american art. But we found it to be overrated: the exhibitions were rather small and the staff were rude.
Modern. A museum with amazing showrooms. Among the available art, there is a section with abstract and kinetic work, which should be very pleasing to fans of geometric shapes.

Museum unmissible visit. The most important when you visit a city is knowing of tourist place and the museums are in the list for checking. Nice place for understanding the past and look forward the future.

One of the best in America. This is an amazing museum. The permanent collection is impressive and there are always great surprises.Is a must see in this beautiful city. Plan to spend at least 3 hours to visit. The cafe in the basement is nice and the food is ok.

What a nice surprise, one of our best visits in Buenos Aires!. Whole family together, a long weekend in Buenos Aires and few hours inside MALBA, just felt like first world class museum, wonderful to see some of our local latin american art work, as well as contemporary video art. Spend at least 2 hours and there, and walk to Japanese garden later to finish your day
AMAZING!!!!!!!!!. Beautiful art work! Literally perfect. Also, it is free for students every Wednesday (bring your student ID)!!!!!!!!!!!
wonderful. a place of modern and powerful art ,a lovely building,and a chance to discover some unusual work from latin america young artist

Interesting but not mind blowing. Was definitely interesting and entertaining to see the art, but I didn't feel fully engaged while walking through the museum. Also something that can be a pretty quick stop because it's not too big.

This was the first time I visited this museum, and it was worth it.. Finding a Tarsila, a Portinari, and master pieces from many Latin American painters made the visit very pleasant. The museum is very well located in Palermo Viejo, and can be easlily reached by subway. I enjoyed walking from downtown, having lunch at Recoleta, watching the metal flower at the United Nations Plaza, and coming back from the museum to the hotel by subway. I regret the repair job being undertaking in the upper floor (May, 2016). I should have inquired before coming over.
Modernist . My wife and I went to Malba expecting to see an amazing museum. It was nice but not terrific.If you do not have much time in Buenos Aires, you can without feeling guilty skip this Museum.

Great exhibition on perspective in May 2016 and Jeff Koons sculpture. The MALBA itself is a lovely building with a great collection of Latin American art including works by Botero, Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera among lots of other greats. We saw the exhibition of perspective which was excellent, as was the Jeff Koons Ballerina which is actually outside the museum so can be visited for free. Museum entrance is half price on a Wednesday. There is also a cinema and a nice café.

Easy to Do in a Few Hours. I liked the MALBA, and recommend it if you like modern art. It's a fairly quick museum, though to be fair the third level was closed while they set up for a Yoko Ono exhibit (and closing part or all of a museum when threatened by Yoko Ono's art always seems wise! /s).The permanent collection has some nice pieces, and all signage is in both Spanish and English. There is no audio guide (in any language), which is disappointing. I enjoy hearing some of the background and interpretation of the pieces.There was a temporary exhibit on the basement level, centered around planning to place art interpretations of biology/body parts. The planning was filmed, examined, and now the pieces themselves are displayed after the films were examined (and in one case, shown as part of the exhibit). This sounded really cool, but ended up being a bit of a yawn. The positive parts outweighed anything I didn't enjoy. Given the modest size of the collection, this means I was able to zip through and focus on what I liked. This created a great morning and left time for other activities. On a side note, the store is pretty cool and had a better selection of things outside the typical bag/tote/coaster/poster/keyring/mug selection.

Suprisingly Really Enjoyed. Really enjoyed MALBA with it's ecletic mix of art and sculpture. The permanent exhibition has some great pieces in it and the exhibition that we saw on the third floor was a fun play by the artist with maps. Cute little gift shop with some nice pieces in also.Would recommend for any art lover, modern or not.

5 minutes wasted.. I came to this museum with high expectations, however these were severely let down. First off the 2nd floor is closed till the end of June so you are left with 2 floors of 'art'. The ground floor consisted of that sort of art where a 5 yr old could stick twigs on a page. It was the most boring and ridiculous exhibition and a huge visual let down. We also saw black and white photos of people, just photos. There is the main exhibit with the weird white thing you see in the photos and a few oil paintings and then you're done. I think me and my partner were in there for a total of 10 minutes and we left hilarious at how crap it was. Just a heads up.
Waste of time in June 2016. Half the museum is closed while they set up for a new exhibition so it's a total waste of time at the moment, there's just nothing to see!
Better than Museo de Bellas Artes. I read it was in the top 25 in the world. Enjoyed it. Pity the second floor was closed. Not everyone gets a discount on the entry fee on Wednesdays.
Great musuem. Different type of art than we get in the United States. All from Latin America, modern and well selected. The current exhibit was intersesting and from a local artist.

Amazing Art Muesum. The location is in one of the nicest area of the city, nice modern building, well kept and wonderful modern latin american art exhibition. The permanent collection is great and it has very good exhibitions. Strongly recomended

Amazing artworks!. Went to Malba primarily to look at Tarsila do Amaral's most famous work - Abapurã. The museum is located in a beautiful building at a fancy neighborhood in Buenos Aires.
The works located within were amazing - expect to see Bottero, Friday Khalo, Di Cavalcanti, Tarsila and much much more!

Great expositions. I went with 2 friends and we were all very pleased and surprised by the art works and exhibitions . The permanent collection is rather classic but still nicely assorted and structured. The other exhibition by another artist was really a discovery. Also the book and museum shop offer nice things

MALBA is worth a visit.. This isn't my favorite museum in the city, but it is worth a visit, as it is said to have one of the best representations of Latin American art in the world, and it seems every year they pick up a few new pieces from the local ArteBA fair, which means their collection keeps growing with some of the newest work on the market. The building itself is beautiful as well. One day of the week, admission is half price.

Great visit to modern art . Wow I was so happy that this was the first of many museums I visited. It is not free but about $3 usd. Excellent modern art. Beautiful building and lovely cafe and restaurant to enjoy some food after inducing in all that art. I must admit. Some I just couldn't understand. Lol

Gorgeous modern building with first rate Argentinian artists represented.. Impressive collection of local art housed in a contemporary building. There was a nice gift shop and we had a great simple lunch in the cafe. We arrived early and walked the small contiguous neighborhood.

great museum. Loved this art museum. It was not huge, but a nice collection of modern art from the Latin American region. We stopped and got a coffee at their restaurant afterwards and enjoyed the ambiance.

Excellent . First floor is on fire, I been there with my mom and she loved it, she even cried ahahaha there are works of Renoir, Monet, Tolousse, Cezanne, Goya, Rembrant , Rubens it's gorgeous and at the second floor you will find works of Argentinian and Mexican artist from 19th century. Entrance is free!!

A place to discover first class, renowned artists .... I was charmed by this new Museum in town.
The number of paintings and other art pieces is limited but of high quality. You will discover pieces from well-known artists.
New building with a great design at still a very reasonable price compare to European standards.

Excellent small museum. The collection is manageable and quite well represents Latin American art --at least for non-specialists. The bookstore in the basement had a variety of art books and magazines.

Interesting but Not Outstanding. A nicely done modern art museum, but it doesn't stand out from other modern art museums. There are a few exceptional examples of Latin American modern art, but most of it is like North American, European and other regions' modern art.
The museum architecture is clean a contemporary and the museum restaurant/cafe is nice.

Interesting and different exhibits. The museum is well layed out and easily accessible. Many of our large group viewed the exhibits and all of us enjoyed them. I loved the different types of mediums from the big white room full of black holes, the intricate work of cut out maps, the headset music that went with some pieces, and so much more. We even had lunch in the outdoor café. Like all Buenos Aires restaurants the portions are huge.

Closed on 2 days, back to back. Disappointed. . We went here on 2 days. Sunday and Monday. Closed on both days. No place is the work say and closed day mentioned. Very disappointed. Not professional at all.. Must be a great place, but we left Buenos Aires without seeing it. Sad. Bhagwan.
Great museum. This cosy museum houses an impressive collection of artworks from the region. Strong curation. Service is great - had an enjoyable time!

The best of its kind in the world. There is no better exhibit of Latin American art than MALBA. The galleries are large and well-lit, with plenty of space to get perspective on the fabulous array of sculptures, paintings, and mixed media.

Fabulous Museum!. My mind was blown so much amazing art!!! A must see in BA! Out all the countless museums in Buenos Aires this one was my favorite! Great collection, not too big and overwhelming, this place is great on a rainy day!

Closed on Tuesdays. Amazing Museum!. What I love most about this museum: it's not too big and there is always a changing exhibition on the top floor. The museum itself is interesting and it offers an artistic insight into Latin America's culture. Take your time to look close to see the details! My advice: don't go to the Museum café afterwards, try Casa Cavia or Pain Quotidien instead.

Good modern art. I am not a fan of modern art but my partner is. The building is interesting and not too overwhelming. There are various artists on display from very good to bad from almost traditional to kooky.
Fantastic museum!!. I loved this museum.The building itself is worth a visit. It is not very big but it is perfect for a fantastic overview of Latin American artist.

Modern museum. It was a nice overview over Latin American paintings. It is located in Palermo near Evita museum and some nice gardens like the botanical garden and the zoo so that could be made in one day. The museum shop was closed due to renovation.

Definite must see for the museum seeker at heart.. Make sure you allocate time in your trip to visit MALBA. I was able to see so many paintings that I've only read about in books. There are permanent expositions, temporary exhibitions, and installations. I would not consider my husband a person who enjoys art but he liked the "The violent tapes of 1975". Art moves you, it strikes a cord in you and this is a world-class museum. The fee to enter was not much compared to what you get to see and experience on the inside.

WONDERFUL permanent collection and very good cafe. My eyes were opened to many new Argentinian and other Latin American artists. Temporary exhibit was okay, but we spent several hours with the permanent collection. Stays open till 8 pm.
Great gallery . Great Collection of contemporary Latin American art. There was a large range of art though most was Argentinian. Loved the Koons sculpture outside .
Top class museum. Great museum. Top class artwork. This is a must see. It is,at the level of the Best museums in new york, París or london.Great artworks. Price is ok
You don't have to miss it!. Beautiful permanent exposition, but also very interestin temporary exhibiting artists. Nice spot and easily to be reach from the center of the city

A "Must See" in Buenos Aires. Contemporary, classic, political, quirky, historic - MALBA has it all. It's not huge and can be covered in a couple of hours but the reflections will last much longer! I went on a rainy day and couldn't think of a better way to spend the afternoon. Thoroughly enjoyed it. Discounts for students and for teachers, if you have appropriate ID, and those with a disability are free. Highly recommended

Great small museum!. Set amongst some of BA's beautiful parks - this museum is a must see for art lovers. It is also such a manageable size that it can be visited quite quickly. Highlights were a great Jorge Macchi exhibit and in the permanent collection - the self portrait of Frida Kahlo and works by Diego Rivera and Botero. Nice cafe downstairs to stop for a quick refreshment after your visit as well.

Nice building, small collection. I'm not sure if it was when we went, but there was a disappointing small number of works on show. There is the famous self portrait of the lady artist with the monobrow, but not much else to enthuse about. Except it is a wonderful building with excellent air conditioning that we appreciated and a nice restaurant and bar.

Interesting museum!. This museum is so interesting.I went there with my mom in 2013.We really appreciate to see the art and the pictures there,especially Abapuru of Tarsila do Amaral,a Brazilian artist.
Great art and outside seating. Wonderful art in a small setting. Gift shop worth a view as they have unique items. Having an adult beverage outside on their patio is extra-special.
Great museum to visit. Although there are no tour guides or pamphlets is in English, the art spoke volumes! Easy to get to and worth the visist

Excellent Latinamerican art museum. One of the best art museums in Latin America.
Sea Berni and other important artists in the permanent collection.
Too modern for me. Very modern. Not my type of art, but appreciated it. Lunch at the cafe was delicious. Building was beautiful. Near a nice mall.

Nice small museum of art. This is a very nice museum of Latin American art. Its permanent collection offers examples from any countries, although I did find the exhibited collection some what small. I can be seen in less than an hour.

interesting, but not really the best museum in Buenos aires. The tourist guides we read said 'if you have to see only one museum in Buenos Aires, see MALBA". I do not really agree. The Museo of Belle Artes is better. MALBA has a nice permanent collection of Argentinian and South American painters, with representative works, but does not have too much space, so no need to plan for more than one-one and a half hour. Explanations in Spanish and English, and temporary exhibitions that add to the experience.

Imaginative art, creative setting. The museum displayed trends in modern art using Latin American artists represented in their collection. This colonial history display was imaginative and the entire facility was impressive.

Great, every time. I have been here twice now and it always surprised and pleased. The size is just right and the exhibitions really well curated. On this occasion is was Jorge Macchi, who was a great discovery. Loved it. The permanent collection is also excellent. The entry ticket is very affordable for what it delivers. The museum restaurant is also excellent, as is the shop and book shop. There are few better museums of this kind in the world, and I have seen many.

Fantastic art, definitely worth a visit. Cannot recommend this enough! For only 45 pesos you'll be able to see fantastic works of Latin American art (including paintings by Diego Rivera and Frida Kahlo). Unexpectedly wonderful exhibits in a very modern building. I spent just over an hour there but will no doubt be back!

MALBA is amazing. Our visit to this unique museum included one of the most interesting video presentations we have ever seen: the removal and restoration of an Antonio Berni mural from a quinta in the country to its location in the MALBA. A fascinating and difficult endeavor with a breathtaking result.

Fab modern art from the region . Great to see a space to showcase Latin American art, there's a good mix of styles to suit all tastes between the permanent & temporary exhibitions. There's a good gift shop, the café is OK. The only drawback is location - it's not particularly close to the metro or train so you need to walk or take a bus (or hop in a taxi).

Wow.. Art is of course subjective but in our view this was a waste of time and money.Not an awful lot (quantity wise) on display here so you'll be ready to leave before you know it but for us the art on display was borderline ridiculous. Pictures of crinkled pieces of paper and cut up bits of newspaper was not what I expected after reading such good things about this place. We definitely wasted time and money and wished we'd have spent the extra time just strolling around Palermo instead. Avoid, unless you like very random "art".

A private collection with surprise . There are some paintings that are really important in the Latin America history. Also the selection of autors and the mix of past and present is brilliant. Sculptures and special projects are interesting, always. The building is world class, not that big but modern, clean and full of technology. Checking on internet before going is a good idea, sometimes they open only one floor and it's a little bitshort as a program.

Beautiful museum and not too time-consuming- go on Wednesday!. Great museum to get some Latin American culture while in BA. It took 1.5ish hours to get through and is half priced on Wednesdays (and free for students!)
Quick & Priceless Treat!. It's worth visiting, small exhibit with mixed exhibit. Here is a Frida and a Diego...worth it. But other exhibits, it's just a gem, this place.

Beautiful setting to see such fine art. This is a fantastic gallery - full of light and space showing of Latin American artists with a special flare. They have a number of non-Ar gentian works by Diego Rivera and Frida Kahlo de Rivera from Mexico and Botero from Colombia. A photo exhibition from Brazil was incredible. Must see.

Excellent museum. We were on the fence about visiting MALBA but I am so glad we went. The exhibitions were thoughtfully curated - the Jorge Macchi show was excellent. Despite what some people said about the collection being limited - I think the quality of the permanent collection far outweighs this. I learned a lot and would go back in a heartbeat.

Well worth a visit . We spent a couple of hours looking at the fabulous artworks displayed here. Really interesting Latin American paintings and sculptures. The building itself is fabulous - very light and airy. Nice cafe outside on the ground floor. Would definitely recommend a visit.

Incredible museum with awesome art. MALBA is a must if you want to know about latinamerican artist, great sort of artist and shows al along the year will introduce you into a really well curated museum. Take your time is easy to arrive and placed in a beautiful area of Palermo.

Beautiful building and garden but the collection is limited. Perhaps I am spoiled because I live in a major city but the collection here is very limited. It is worth seeing, as is the building and the garden cafe. The gift shop is excellent and has unique and interesting items.

Great Collection of Latin Art in a Beautiful Museum. Wonderful, exciting and extensive museum of contemporary Latin American art.
Attractive and sleek restaurant with excellent choices.

Great introduction to Latin American art. Well worth a visit if you're interested in 20th and 21st C art. We were unfamiliar with most of the artists on display here but found it really interesting and well laid out. The modern building itself is worth a look.

Excellent shows and a good, but not deep representation of Latin American Art in a beautiful building.. MALBA as it is called is by far the best museum in Buenos aires. It's exhibits can be seen in a day, its shows are extremely well curated and presented and it has a select representation of famous Latin American painters best art.It's located in the posh Recoleta district, where many foreign embassies and high end residences are located. The district itself is also worth a walking tour.Finally, there is and excellent restaurant located in the museum.
Superb. Wonderful, stunning, fabulous. The work of Jorge Macchi is fantastic - rich in symbolism..wonderful permanent collection.Museum is stunning, number 6 bus outside takes you back to Santa Fe.
Great museum. Great museum with works by Kandinsky, Jackson Pollock, Frida Kahlo, Diego Rivera and lots of Argentine artists. Worth a visit.

Perfect!. A trip to MALBA should be on your list of things to do in Buenos Aires. The architecture is interesting (I understand why some people don't like it) and the collection is terrific. The museum is not large (unfortunately the top floor was closed the day we were there) and easily done in an hour or two. The collection is fantastic - a wide range of art and media. And you can take photos (no flash)! The only slight disappointment is that the gift shop does not have a book of the art in the museum. I don't often buy them but wanted one from this museum. The restaurant at the museum is lovely - good food, reasonably priced, and has a pretty outdoor space. Highly recommended!

a first class museum a bit out of the very center. i think it is not very useful to rate things on everybody's tourist list, but i feel this museum is not taken care of as it deserves. perhaps because of its name? well, it is true that its permanent collection and many exhibitions are about latinamerican art but it is not exclusively so, and many exciting exhibitions are of very particular international kind. further to that the building is architectonally very attractiv and it has a very nice indoor and outdoor restaurant and coffe shop, further to an important shop of art books and rare souvenir items

Lovely gallery/museum - and manageable!. this is a beautifully designed museum of great architectural merit, and of manageable size, with a delightful collection of paintings, sculpture and other artefacts.
Definitely worth a visit! . It is a small museum with a very small collection , one original Frida Kahlo, one Botero, one Diego Rivera, one Tarsila Do Amaral ,pictures and sculptures.

An extraordinary collection!. I'd first visited MALBA in 2007, and swore the. I'd return if ever the opportunity presents itself. Thankfully it did! The collection is exceptionally rich, and from Tarsila's "Abaporu" that greets you as you enter the main gallery through the Bernis and Calvacantis and Potinaris to the sole Botero you'll not be disappointed. The top floor gallery is home to rotating exhibits--when we visited it housed Jorge Macchi's "Perspectives" series. Nicely done all around, and in an inceedibly beautiful building. A must-see if you're in Buenos Aires!

Excellent introduction and exciting new work. A contemporary bldg with lots of light, the Museum (true to its name) has a wide ranging permanent collection of Latin American artists, eg, representative works by Kahlo, Botero,Guttero. At the time of our visit, the temporary exhibit by Belgian artist Francis Alys was thought-provoking and impressive. Using a variety of different media,ie, sculpture, video, painting, animation, he explored the theme of culture and immigration. Recommend.

Small but interesting. Worth the price of admission. $6. There's a Diego Rivera and Frieda Kalo's self-portrait. No English speaking guide but English translations on some of the pieces. Open Mondays.

Disappointment!. The building and its setting are lovely. There is a permanent collection of some fine works, but the entire third floor was closed for an installation which should have been hung by the time we were there according to the dates of the exhibition. We walked down to the Museo de Bellas Artes which had a larger than anticipated collection of twentieth century Latin American Art along with a strong holding of European art.Malba's restaurant was definitely overpriced with the highest service or cover charge we encountered on our trip.Definitely worth a trip but not the "do not miss" experience I was hoping for.

Pretentious but Great. Why do art galleries have to take themselves so seriously? Some of the intro paragraphs to different collections were hilarious in their pomposity! But some intriguing exhibits which will leave you asking 'is this art?' And others which are stunning. Well worth a visit.

Great museum, definitely worth a visit!. The museum ia bot large, but has an inpressive permanent collection with clear explanations of the art development of the last century. Also the temporary exhibitions were very interesting and inpressive. Definitely worth a visit, especially for design lovers!
Modern Art Museum. Nice building if you are in to arquitecture, art worth looking at, modern and lots of lights. Great café, perfect for a rainy afternoon.
Make sure you go to Malba. Beautiful building with a very interesting collection. The gift shop has some quirky and great stuff. And the cafe is great. Make sure you have lunch there.
Best Modenr Art Museum in Argentina. Modern and Global Museum in Buenos Aires. Great collection although canonical.If you need a panorama of Modern Latin American Art, go to Malba.

Great collection. MALBA has an amazing collection, latin american art, like Frida Kahlo or Botero, and is a great opportunity to know better argentinian artists. The building is also amazing. Is a good chance to visit the neighborhood
Great Architecture!. Interesting building but there is limited art since one whole floor was closed. The art that was there was interesting but am not sure if it is representative.
Great glimpse of Latin American Art. Being from Europe, we were all not familiar with Latin American art. The MALBA cured some of this ignorance. We really liked the temporary exhibition.

Awesome museum and great art. From the street the museum has an important architecture and evidences it's modern design. As you enter the building and move forward through the art collection and the expositions displayed, you find yourself immersed in the most magnificent works of art by the most prominent latin american artists. Definitely a must for a visit to Buenos Aires. Wednesdays entrance is 50% off.

Skip it if you are short in time and money. Unless you are a Frida Kahlo fan.. We are from London, maybe we have being spoiled. They have ONE exhibition room, that's it. If you are short in time and money skip it, if you have a bit more time give it a go, or if you are desperate to see a Frida Kahlo. It is a very small collection, one original Frida Kahlo, one Botero, and sculptures. If you are from a big city with big museums I think you might be disappointed. The Museum is not free and it is not cheap, also NOT CHILD FRIENDLY. Never we had being asked silly requests, they want your child to be holding your hand at all times, even outside the one exhibition room in the stairs and sitting area, that was stressful.

Great museum, quick visit. As someone who doesn't love going to museums, I found this perfect. It's small and you only need 45 minutes (or so) to get through it. I found all the pieces interesting and thought provoking, but it wasn't such a large museum that I had to spend the whole day there. The building itself was also beautiful. We'll worth the trip.

Impressive collection. I did not expect to see such a fine collection here. Very good presentation of art movements and artists . My favourites included great artists like Manet, Monet, Degas and Rodin's sculptures.

Believe the great reviews!. If you arrive before noon on Sunday, have a coffee or meal at the charming restaurant connected to the museum. Indoors, enjoy the breadth of painting and sculpture displays and beautiful architecture of this modern and comfortable museum. The hop-on bus stops there too. There's a nice shop at the end.

Small collection. I enjoyed what we saw but was surprised by the small size of the collection. The building has three floors but only the 1st floor is open to the public (at least when we visited). If it hadn't been for two pieces I really wanted to see (a Frieda Kahlo and a Diego Rivera), I would have been very disappointed.

Only got to see the permanent exhibit.... Spent a little time here on a rainy day and unfortunately we only got to see the permanent exhibit which had some cool stuff in it but was also fairly small. We may have had a better experience if we had been able to see more. I think total time in the hall was an hour...

big disappointment. After reading the good reviews and having studied a fair amount of history of art I decided to make my all the way out to the MALBA! Only one level was open, despite being advised that everything would be open on the website

Great atmosphere! Loved It!. The MALBA is an awesome museum were you can find lots of history, great exhibitions and have a blast. I specifically went when the Antonio Berni exhibition was available and found it superb!

Interesting building, but unexciting exhibits. MAMBA is an architecturally interesting building. However, the exhibits were (to me) rather unexciting. The permanent collection, located on part of the first floor, were all that could be seen. And it cost 75 pesos - not the best deal in town. But at least MAMBA is open on a Monday when most other places (and even gardens) are closed

20th Century Art --- Good and Bad. Today I visited MALBA at the end of a hectic tour of Beunos Aires. The museum building is new and attractive. The contents was a mixed bag. There was a goodly selection of works by early 20th Century Artists -- some like Frieda Kahlo and Diego Rivera -- were well know while others of whom I had little or no knowledge. The highlight of the museum to me was a recently recovered and restored fresco mural by by Antonio Berni. Of course, like and museum dealing with "modern art" there was the standard collection of solid-color canvass or ones with a half dozen diagonal lines. These definitely remind me of the emperor's new clothes. Overall, it's a small collection but definitely worth a visit.
Fab museum. Modern Latin American art. The Tarsila do Amaral and Frieda Kahlo self portrait are both wonderful. I also loved the sculptures. Go there.

One of my new favorite museums!. The MALBA is the perfect museum — even for those who don't really love museums. Its permanent collection is stunning and gives a great overview of Latin American art. Its special exhibiotion space had a great Francis Alys show when I was there. Galleries are just right size-wise and are not overwhelming. Cafe / restaurant is lovely and has a nice menu. Gift shop is wonderful. I go to and have been to art museums all over the world, and this one was really memorable.

A tiny bit of art in a new great building - very dissapointing. All local tourist adds mention this musem, and having in our home country a beautiful sample of Latin American art in the Recanati Museum in Cesarea (Israel) we jumped at the opportunity to see more. They have one (rather small) Diego Rivera painting, one Frida Kahlo painting and one Botero painting and some eclectic collection of lesser avangarde creators in ONE museum room. A small additional room contains some precolumbian art of secondary importance too. We left dissapointed. I gave them 2 points instead of their earned 1 in the hope that they will spend more time in building a good collection of art and less on advertising and politics.

Disappointing. Great art but only one small floor of exhibits. We walked around thinking there must be another area we were missing. It is too bad because the art that is there is interesting but just too little of it to make a trip worth while unless you are in the area or staying close by.
A little empty. Only the permanent collection was open for viewing. So only the upper floor the gift book shop ,and the restaurant were open. A lot of plastic over doorways .

Great but...... Firstly you have to visit malba...no question about that..When we were visiting buenos aires ,we were very impressed by the rich street sold art and designs (even the grafittis you see at all corners of the city)At Malba I was expecting more wow works because of the city s great potential Looks like the museum is more dependent on existing collection rather then exhibitions.Museum store was also poor, even compared to Istanbul Modern I could not spend money because nothing was much available and all written stuff in general was in spanish.Still it is a must visit point however with a better management the experience can be triple enrichened.
Lovely diversion.. This is a great building/venue and a very manageabley sized collection that gives a good overview of modern art from a BA perspective. Reasonable price and well laid out.
Modern museum. The Malba is a small, modern museum. There's one gallery with there own collection. Exhibitions by artists take up the whole upper floor.

Awesome Malba. One of the coolest museums I've even been - the best in South America.
It is possible to compare it to MoMA - with a modern decor and displays a mix of works by notorious and upcoming artists. Also a must go.

Quick museum visit. Only one floor was open in MALBA
Pieces displayed were interesting and reflective of Latin America. They architecture is very pleasing.

Must visit. I am not that much into modern art, but I really liked it. Unfortunatelly, only the first floor was open, but as I am student and we went there wednesday, I had it for free. So go there wednesday and you pay less ;)

Interesting museum, but limited.. The museum has one Botero, and one Kahlo painting as part of its permanent collection, and, at present, has no temporary collections. Despite its limitations, it is well worth a visit, and can be combined with lunch in its pleasant restaurant.

Good Museum for those who like smaller museums. I'm not really a museum person, but I enjoyed this small museum. The artwork was interesting and it could all be seen in an hour, which is perfect for someone like me.
We kinda expected more. The museum was generally OK, but the exhibits were not particularly stand-out. As a result, we did not spend long at the museum -- 2 hours tops.

Don't miss this museum. We visited during 2015 with our kids. I recommend this museum to all travellers interested in Latin American art. Although relatively small, the building is very interesting and well designed so all exhibitions can be nicely "travelled".

Dissapointed. We have been to malba several time. I think is a nice museum but it's not extraordinaire. This February there is no seperat exhibition, but the still charge you the full entrance (I find a discount would be nice). Lovely little shop and great architecture

Not to be missed.. How can you not visit MALBA when in Buenos Aires? Not only are all of the important artists represented here, but the museum is designed on each floor in a figure eight which makes it so much easier to ensure that you see everything and not walk miles to do so.

Beautiful gallery. Not a huge collection but very interesting and well curated. Loved the Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera pieces as well as fellow artists of the period. Lots of political art. Also enjoyed the fantasy art by video of the artist who tried to build a bridge from Cuba to Key West and from Morocco to Spain

Small but excellently curated collection. We very much enjoyed our visit here. The permanent collection is small but of the highest quality and well organized. We were fortunate to catch an exhibition of Francis Alys which was thought provoking , highly original and very relevant to current events regarding the worldwide migration crises.

Nice collection of works by Latin American artists. Malba focuses on modern Latin American Artists. The collection is good though not extensive. The building is beautiful and the collection is well laid out. A nice bookstore and gift shop to boot.

The MALBA is Delightful. The Malba was just a short walk from our home so we were there almost once a week. Everything about it is excellent, the building itself and the art and exhibitions. I Highly recommend it .
Excellent collection. MALBA has a wonderful collection of Latin American art - mainly 20th century. It's in a nice neighborhood, too.

Beautiful Art. I visited this museum every time I go to Buenos Aires
It's always nice
I found really great artists all times

Compelling Contemporary Art. Enjoyed seeing and learning more about Latin American artists. Museum's architecture is itself a piece of art - soaring windows and attractive gallery space. The gift shop offers an array of unique items.

Liked but didn't love it. Some interesting pieces and some fine paintings. Some exhibits weren't for us but it was worth the visit. Definitely for contemporary art lovers. Cheaper on a Wednesday A$36 and free to pensioners.
First rate. . Best museum we visited. Beautiful building with some English descriptions. Don't miss the restaurant. Good food and delightful service.
If you have to visit only one museum make it this one. This museum has a wonderful collection and attracts lots of art lovers. It was a perfect break during the hot summer days in Buenos Aires!
Private museum. a very modern private building with a good collection of contemporary artists that belong to the owner of the museum

Some strange art here. This is a beautiful museum with very modern art and some works by Latin American artists from other countries. A lot of what is being exhibited now is rather weird. There is a Freda kahlo self portrait and something by Diego Rivera. I walked a long way to get to the MALBA but am not sure I loved it.

Also has Best Restaurant in Buenos Aires. We came to see Solar as one wonderful Argentinian artist (also Berni and a few others) and discovered the museum cafe and had the best food of our week in Buenos Aires! We had marinated salmon and a minestrone type soup ( but only better). This was also our most expensive meal in Buenos Aires but best ($usd 60). Expansive varied and full of excellent choices.
Museum. We hired tour guide for the day to take us to different art galleries and museums. We had a terrific time at thus museum a bit small but very interesting and informative with a fun vibe.

Modern Art Museum, Nice but small collection of art. This museum is worth a visit. It is very modern and appears larger than the galleries permit. But, it has a very nice, yet small, collection of modern art from cubism, to kinetic, to concrete. Well worth a couple hours to appreciate contemporary Latin American artists
Weak collection. The museum's building i fancy and modern but his collection is thin and poor. I consider it disapointting for and expensive price (in argentinean currency).
Art lovers should not miss this museum. A great museum building which is home to a great collection of all great Latin American artists. Art lovers, do not miss!

If you like contemporary art go and visit it. I was a bit skeptic at the beginning prior to visiting the museum as I always do not know what to expect from a contemporary art museum. Nevertheless I found very interesting works. Price is 75AR$.

Just enough and not too much. Sometimes going to an art gallery can be a bit of a chore - you feel overwhelmed by the number of exhibits or the amount of information. Not so with MALBA - a beautiful light space with the terrifically interesting art works nicely spaced out so that it's enough but not too much. Lots of variety too, ranging from more classic works to very avant-garde. Well curated and really enjoyable.

Modern Art Museum . Well , I was a little disappointed with this exhibit. This was not my cup of tea. It is closed on Tuesday. Wednesday 12-9pm. Thursday -Monday and holidays 12-8pm. Cost was $15.00/ 2. The building was spacious , there was a cafe if you would like something and a little gallery store. This is a personal review , I did not enjoy it.
A nice museum. We have seen a good exhibition of Francis Alys and the MALBA permanent collection. It is a relatively small museum, very well kept and professional.

Small and focused Contemporary South American Art Museum. This is a very attractive modern facility which presents a modest sized collection representative of its subject of contemporary South American Art. Building achieves its purposes and is recommended for brief visit. Respectfully, we have little appreciation for modern/contemporary art so the three star rating is reflective of our lack of appreciation for most of the contents.

Worth Seeing. This museum is relatively small but did have some quite interesting works of art. Depending on your schedule, you could walk through it in 1-3 hours and see everything. There's a small gift shop and cafe within. The architecture of the building is interesting as well.

Interesting & Adventurous. New modern museum, where they are showing their permanent collection to its best advantage and to a professional level. Although we found the special exhibition disappointing, this was our personal opinion and no reflection on the standard of curatorship, which was very high. Well worth a visit.

Interesting Modern Art. We spent about 3 hours here and were able to see the full museum. Interesting collection of Modern Art as well as some works by Diego Rivera and Frida Kahlo. We also sat outside at the cafe and had expresso which was nice.

Expensive and a bit obscure in parts but well presented. MALBA is located in Palmero and I would recommend a visit as part of a walking day in the Recoleta/Palmero area incorporating the Recoleta cementery > MALBA or museo nacional de bellas artes > Floralis generalis. The cost was 100AR per person although a discount is offered to seniors (>65 years) and students with presentation of appropriate ID. There is a cafe on site but it is very expensive.Like many art museums focusing on modern art (20th century to present) this one can be a bit hit and miss in parts. On the pros I did enjoy the cinematic displays and numerous pieces on the second floor. There was a good variety within the displays but the number remained limited which was positive as it meant you didn't end up having to spend an entire day in here to cover all the exhibits due to FOMO. The museums architecture was impressive - in particular, the incorporation of natural light. In terms of cons some pieces were definitely a miss - such as the carton show fused with soft pornography on the bottom floor. In addition the piece entitled 'Mobile phone, rubber band and blackberry' appeared to be just that to me. I also must state that I didn't appreciate the inappropriate use of complicated and out of context language in the information displays. This was probably in order to try to create a perceived complexity to the work that really just wasn't there - or maybe I just 'didn't get it'.Overall one of the better modern art museum's I have been to and may be worth a visit if that's your thing. Make sure you don't miss the Floralis generalis which is located across the road.

Better than expected. It was great to see in person some of the famous paintings I grew up learning about in school. There were also many paintings I had never heard of that I enjoyed seeing for the first time. The museum staff was great: from the lady whom sold me my ticket, to the extremely knowledgeable guides for both English and Spanish. The museum is located in a beautiful modern building with nice white walls and plenty of natural light.

Modern Latin American Art. A good example of modern art from several countries in Latin American. The museum building is a very nice structure. Obviously one needs to be interested in modern art to find the collect interesting. If you are interested it is a convenient way to get a quick review

Geat museum!. I really like to visit this museum of art. There I could have a glimpse of the most valuable painting done by a Brazilian, Tarcila do Amaral. Yes, I am Brazilian. But there are many other relevant pieces of art, too. It's a must-see place when in Buenos Aires. Check it out, there is one day of the week that admission is free for students and retired people. Even international student cards are accepted!

Enjoyable and approachable. MALBA's art collection is large enough that you get a great historical, regional and political variety and perspective, yet small enough that you can take in the whole thing in one visit. There are plenty of explanations in English. What was really spectacular were the installations (and especially the films) by Francis Alys. Arresting, absorbing, challenging. Don't miss this wonderful exhibit (through February 15) and this exceptional museum!

Fantastic museum. It was exciting to see the superb permanent collection, which includes many artists not often seen in the US. The collection is beautifully displayed in the museum's attractive building. Be sure to have lunch, a bit pricey but more than worth it.

Eclectic Collection in a Striking Environment. We were fortunate to get free admission as senior citizens (over65). There a a variety of exhibits often augmented by video presentations. The Francis Aylis exhibit was striking and ranged from distressing to enlightening. Well worth the trip.
Small enough to cover in one afternoon. There were three exhibits and we were able to visit them all in one afternoon without getting exhausted. The place is light and airy and the art is vibrant.

Nice collection in a specialy design settings. Collection of Argentinean and other Latin American artists representing different periods from Modernism to conceptualism and current modern art. Includes a beautiful self portrait of Frida Kahlo. Good explanation of the movements in English and Spanish. Definitely worth visiting

Surprisingly good museum. Reviewing museums and granting them stars is a challenge. How are you going to compare L'Hermitage, Louvre and MoMa with the lesser beings in the art world? This museum in Buenos Aires is not par to those; however, it does show a great expo of Latin American Art, including some classic paintings by Anita Mafalti and Salvador Dali. The bookstore is excellent and I decided to borrow the stair concept, a piece of art in and by itself.
Nice collection. A variety of collections. One of the modern day museums in BsAs. The collection built out of scraps on the ground floor is a must watch

The art of a country shows its soul.. I just made that quote up. This was a great art museum. It's small, the people who work there including the guards were low key, and the placement and curation very good. One piece was Amante (Lover) - like a tail of a cat shaking in anticipation. The drawings were pretty dark- Argentina has seen some hard times.

Very open, and excellent works to view.. The modern airy, museum has three floors with the core on the second level. Artists reknown in all art forms are beautifully presented including Diego Riviera's, and wife, Frida Kahlo's works.PS. The Italian cafe next door to the museum has excellent food, served pronto!

Gorgeous museum, but a little overpriced. It's a gorgeous museum, but the collection is quite small. Tarsila's Abaporu and Maria Martins' Impossible are fascinating, but the rest of the collections are a little bland. Admission AR$ 75 was a little overpriced when I visited in early December, but it's more reasonable now with the official devaluation of the AR$ relative to the US$ just before Christmas.

Stunning museum. The best museums are always the one's that are specifically built to house the artwork on show.
We found this place delightful. It is certainly worth an hour or two of your time. Enjoy!

Nice building, limited contents. The first impression is charming: the modern building is full of light and very practical for an art exhibition. Temporary shows are hosted at the upper level, in wide rooms that allow you to enjoy the individual artworks exposed. The permanent collection of modern art at the first floor is, on the contrary, quite deceiving. Only one Botero, one self-portrait of Frieda Kahlo, one painting of Diego Rivera. Some operas of Pettoruti, Xul Solar and Antonio Berni are blended with other minor latino-american artists of the XX century. Not really much to see and not of the highest level, in my opinion. One good point: the free entrance for the over-65 applies also to foreign tourists.
Wonderful place. Spent several hours in the museum. And I would spent more if I have time. I am under impression of pictures and specially of the movie made in Kabul.
A great surprise!. Amazing museum with profissional workers, large rooms with expressive artistic works and good manners to expose them! Do not go to the restaurant is a stupid mistake ! Enjoy!
Excelent museum. If you are planning to walk around Recoleta and Palermo, Malba should be your destiny, even for a short stop. The museum has some of the best artists from LATAM.
Rosie Millar. I'm a little embarrassed to say we didnt love it as much as expected. Must be too old for mosern art! But we did love some pieces including one of the wonderful Frida pieces.
Nice little museum. Worth a visit if you're interested in art and have a free evening. There's some great paintings and exhibitions.

The best Latinamerican art museum. Before entering this museum it is worthwhile to look at the very original building with a beautiful architecture. Entrance fee is only about 3 USD, for students and pensioners half price. Besides its excellent and varied collection of Latinamerican art it has also a cinema where classic films are usually projected or often the vanguard films of recent poductions, difficult to see elsewhere. The art collection includes fantastic pictures of such artists as Tirso do Amaral (Brazil), Antonio Berni (Argentina), Wilfredo Lam (Cuba), Roberto Matta (Chile), Pedro Figari (Uruguay), Fernando Botero (Colombia), Frida Kahlo (Mexico), besides many other excellent painters, like José Gurvich and Joaquín Torres García of Uruguay, Emilio Pettoruti, Xul Solar and Jorge de la Vega of Argentina, just to mention a few. Once your visit is finished it is very recommendable to go to the museum restaurant, just to have a coffee, a small repast or a full lunch or dinner, youwill not be disappointed.

MALBA.......amazing building!!!!!. Our taxi driver didn't know where the museum was but luckily we persisted and got there! A magnificent building architecturally. Modern art.....some of it not to our taste but well worth going for the building!!!!!
Excellent museum.. Small and well organized with a clear theme - takes no more than 2.5 hours to thoroughly visit the exhibits. Very beautiful.

Great museum. This is a great museum. Lovely building. excellent featured artists. We had a delicious lunch in the restaurant. It was very busy and the service was excellent and attentive. Popular with the locals. Outside seating available.
Spend the afternoon here for sure. Small museum but totally worth spending a lot of time here. The layout is great and incorporates many mediums. Don't miss it!

MALBA-excellent integration of building with modern art. MALBA is housed in an impressive structure that is an artwork in itself. On the first floor is an excellent restaurant. The museum deals with space artistically as the empty areas and the exhibition areas flow together and enhance each other. There is an impressive select collection of modern art. One is not overwhelmed with massive quantities just overwhelmed with massive quality. The MALBA has several iconic pictures (such as the Che Guevara piece that spawned a million {posters and tee shirts} and a Frida Kahlo self portrait). An excellent collection of modern art encompassing different media and creative presentations.
Ok-ish museum. It is ok, but far from great, does not have very much actual art. If your are interested in Argentinia 20th century art than to the fine arts museum.

Great little museum. While the museums are not as grand as they are in Europe they do have a warm feel to them. We enjoyed this museum, like many in SA, it is small and compact with every changing exhibits. Worth a look for sure.

In & Out in 30 mins. Large impressive building containing, however, only a handful of rooms displaying a disappointingly small number of pieces. We browsed slowly and appreciatively, even doubling back on ourselves at times and still covered everything in less than 30 mins!Malta states it has more than 560 pieces but most aren't on display. I wouldn't waste your time here until they actually try to display more of their collection.

Seriously?. Buenos Aires version of Sydney's MCA?If so the MCA is better, Sooo much better shoukd not rven compare.75 Peso entry is cheap but this is still a waste of money in my opinion.2nd floor Francis Alýs is a total waste of time in my opinion 0/5The permanent collection on the second floor is better 3/5.Ground floor 1/5 including the Egg.The recent glowing reviews puzzle me, they really do.

Never disappointing!. The Museum itself is very nice, and although the collection is small, the building itself is great. I have visited a couple of times and have been positively surprised every time with the temporary exhibits, 2016 wasn't the exception!

Small museum, but nice. The building is beautiful, but the museum is quite small. The museum was setting up a new temporary exhibit when we were there, so one floor of the museum wasn't open. As a result, it took only about 75 minutes to see everything (including playing with the interactive exhibits in the modern art area. The museum is worth a visit to see some Latin American art, and the modern art area was fun.

A Few Interesting Works. Visited the MALBA during a multi-day stop in Bs As. There is a mix of modern (late 19th century, early 20th century) and contemporary (today) art. Unless you are a lover of all types of art, this museum´s collection will probably leave you half satified. The space and architecture is well done. There are one or two representative works by bigger names such as Diego Rivera and Frida Kahlo. If you enjoy modern art, this collection won´t come anywhere close to the Reina Sofia in Madrid or the MOMA in New York. Moderate your expectations accordingly and it will be an enjoyable visit.Side note - I´ve seen some questionable contemporary art, but the blackberry strapped to a mango with a rubberband drew quite the eye roll.

Modern and lots of space. Must visit.. Build in 2001 by a rich local business man in order to house his impressive private collection with 2 more floors for expositions. The museum is very roomy and with lots of light and space for the collections. Definitely worth while a visit while in Buenos Aires.
Very cool art pieces- most fun museum we visited. Overall this was my favorite museum while visiting BsAs. The pieces are really fun and you can get a good feel of all the work in under 2 hours.

Must see the Egg. MALBA, the abbreviation for Museum of Latin American Art of Buenos Aires, located in beautiful area of Palermo. Admission 60 pesos, with lower senior rate. Beautiful modern building with impressive permanent collection. Some of the temporary exhibits were unusual but give insight to different views of art. Cafe on site. Check schedule as some museums closed on Monday.

Very nice. What can be said about the MALBA? A great museum for the Latin American Art, which includes many fantastic artists.
The restaurant outside the museum is also very good! Go for the niçoise salad!

Just right!. Great escape from the summer heat in Baires. The collection is just right not too big and not too small and many good pieces from Latam artists. Enjoyed our visit and there is a good museum shop with a nice assortment so fun to walk around in. Will come again when in Baires... Ps they offer discount for ppl with a Samsung smartphone I thought this was awesome eventhough I dont have one ;)

Worth a visit. Even if you are not that interested in art this is worth a visit and doesn't need a lot of time ... After hearing and reading so much about Diego Rivera and Frida Kahlo it was a high light for me to see their work.
Excellent exhibition. Very nice museum of modern Latin art. Well displayed and informative. Accessible by all transportation. Excellent restaurant.
Must visit!. We saw a traveling show that will be at the LA Museum of Art (LACMA) soon, so this gives you an idea of the quality of the museum. Go!

Very nice museum. We loved the space and the small permanent exhibit. The only reason that I didn't give this 5 stars is that we didn't necessarily love the temporary exhibits, and that takes up most of the space. But a good experience all in all and I would recommend.
Great museum! . I highly recommend spending a few hours at the MALBA. The Museum is beautifully designed and the collection of contemporary art worthy. Do not miss Frida Kahlo's self-portrait!
Excellent for Argentinian Art. Wonderful way to get a flavour of the Argentine Art and the history. Entrance is reasonably prized. If you appreciate art then this would be a great place to visit.
A usual stop for me and my family. I can't leave Buenos Aires without visiting the museum. I suggest stopping at the bar/resto for a nice lunch or a tea with a slice of their amazing cakes.

Worth a visit to any fan of Art. This place was a great small museum that is doable in an hour or two and has some amazing pieces by very well known Central and South American artists that range from Colombian to Post Modern. The have an original Frida Khalo and several other pieces that were amazing to see in person, particularly their modern kinetic sculptures and new media room. It's close to the park with Botanical and Japanese Gardens so it's a great daytime date spot if you combine the two and plenty of restaurants are nearby.
Things to do in Buenos Aires. I didn't want to miss MALBA given its reputation. The displays were interesting and the building itself had nice architecture.

Beautiful building, small exhibit. There is so much interesting Latin American art to exhibit and I was hoping to see more. The permanent collection is great but I was expecting more art in this very spacious museum.

How I Found Myself There. It's a fairly small space for an art gallery. There aren't many rooms in it. In hindsight, though, that was for me a good thing as I was exhausted after walking for miles when I found myself outside this strikingly attractive building and summoned up the last of my energy reserves and went in. The admission fee is modest. I was glad I did go in as there is a superb Frida Kahlo painting (self portrait with monkey and parrot); it is protected by glass like the Louvre's protection of the Mona Lisa. This seems excessive. There is a lot of cubist and surrealism work by various Latin American artists (most of whom, I admit I'd never heard of) in the permanent collection. On the second floor was an art installation which was moderately diverting. All in all, not bad.

Good, but doesn't live up to the hype. After reading so many shining review on tripadvisor, I was expecting big things. And yes, the building itself is beautiful, with some great South American artwork. And yes, it's worth a visit. But what surprised me is that it's pretty small. Although it's over three levels, each floor is pretty much one medium-sized sala. Worth an hour to an hour and a half, not much more.

Interesting Art Display. Tumbled upon this museum when randomly walking in the city and decided to stop by for the ac (I was melting at this point having walked for 2 hours in the sun) and wifi but got so much more!
