Enjoyed viewing Alys pieces on immigration and the various forms of contemporary art. Very meaningful work. It isn't a very large museum so a good 2 hours should get one through the displays. I left satisfied.

Don't Miss MALBA. MALBA is a great short instruction in Latin American art. The exhibits do not focus on only Argentinian artists but survey all of South and Central America. So the Venezuelans are represented, as well as Mexican muralists. Pride of place goes to Antonio Garni (the frescoes at the Galleria Pacifica are his).
Favorite museum . This is my favorite museum in Buenos Aires. Great exhibitions, beautiful building, great restaurant inside to have lunch al fresco.
Bizarre. This was a little bizarre..but then again I'm not the best at "modern art". It was quite entertaining with the exhibits though. DEFINITELY worth a visit!

Fabulous insights into central and south American art. An hour or so in the MALBA is an hour or so well spent. As well as key Argentinian artists, there are key works from, e.g. Frieda Kahlo.
Not to be missed!

Art Museum Visit. We visited th MALBA on a hot and humid mid morning. We started at the restaurant but just for coffee. The coffe was quite good and the price very reasonable. The museum is not huge but was just what we were after. The MALBA contains a variety of interesting paintings by Latin American artists including Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera, The museum also contains special exhibits that change periodically. During our visit one exhibit centered around an attempt to build a bridge of boats between Cuba and Central America and another centered on a British units experiences in Afghanistan. Overall this was a great visit. It s perfect if you enjoy art and what to see an entire museum in 1-2 hours.

May disappoint if you're expecting bright bold colors. As a layperson, with no training or expertise, my image of Latin American art consists largely of bright, bold colors and flat perspectives, often with a folk art quality and/or encompassing political commentary. Google "latin american art images" for an idea of the sort of art I have in mind. Should you be hoping to find such works at MALBA, you may be very disappointed. There are certainly some examples of this type but they were few and far between on our visit--possibly due to a large temporary exhibit by a Mexican-based artist, Francis Alÿs, that was far removed from this genre and that no one in our party could appreciate at all.

The temporary exhibit would be the determinant factor on an excellent rating.. The museum has a small collection of local artists, there are several pieces that are worth visiting the museum. However we believe that the temporary exhibits could make this museum even more worthy to visit. There are several special offers for the entry, so I would recommend to check them, for example we got a 2 for 1 entry to the museum because of the Samsung phone.

If you are European, this is the place to go. This museum only shows Latin American art - which you will hardly know from Europe - and which is therefore really worth a visit. If you have a Samsung mobile or tablet show it to the cashier and you will get a substantial discount.

Small but beautiful – Worth the time. This museum was recommended to us by a number of people equally charmed by the small, well curated collection here. You can probably complete your visit to this clean, bright, airy museum in about an hour but you might find yourself wanting to linger.

Great place. Loved this gallery. If you are into Modern Art you will enjoy this museo. Lovely building, great collection, and the temporary exhibitions also were well worth the visit --Francis Alys when I was there
Fair art. Limited area with only fewer art work. Can spend 1 hr. Slightly dissappointing. Some rooms and for closed for coming new opening soon.
Even if you don't like museuns,. do like me , one day for museuns then a great dinner...it's worth while no need to spend lots of time in front of a painting, be nice, please the wife

It's interesting South American art . Hi all
The place is decided into 3 floors , first floor is the best one which really present the Latin American art and history , second floor is more about immigration and it's very tiny
It costs 75 pesos and can take 2 hours to finish the museum
Cheers!
T

Such a good exhibits! Open Mondays when many other museums aren't. Nice collection. Saw a great exhibit on Francis Alÿs while I was here Nov 2015. Really made me think! Also, at the lower level is an egg that is equal to one in the city that will tell you something very profound related to the Internet and social interaction/contact. This museum is referred to as the MALBA and a lot of museums use acronyms here (easier when you are talking to taxi drivers).

A great opportunity to see contemporary art not easily found elsewhere. I didn't make seeing art in Buenos Aires a priority. I went here on a rainy day and am very happy that I did. I saw a special exhibit that included work from Carlos Cruz-Díaz. It was wonderfully curated and the pieces were fantastic. What I truly appreciated about this museum is that much of what I saw it did not feel as though I could easily see elsewhere. The building itself is also very well designed as an exhibition space.

Interesting museum. Visited MALBA today. The building is easy to navigate and the collection is varied. There are some works from many European well known artists plus on the upper floor, local Argentina artists of which we knew nothing until today. The Musem was free on Wednesday. Well worth a visit and also to explore the parks and surrounding district.

Great fun, interesting collection of modern and contemporary painting, sculpture and installations.. An excellent museum, very well designed building with a great collection of Latin American art. Had two shows on when we visited. Very well done. Well worth a visit.

Lovely museum, very interesting art. Ignore that negative review, if you love art you will love MALBA. The museum focuses on modern and contemporary Latin American art, covering painting, sculpture, digital art and everything in between. The permanent collection is not huge but very well curated and gives you a great glimpse into the lives and art practice of Latin American artists, from the 19th century to the present day. There is a very clever temporary exhibition on at the moment on the issue of migration, but if you miss it, I am sure there will be a good temporary exhibition to replace it. Highly recommended.
Great artwork from native artists. Great visit to view modern art from Argentina. It was a rainy day so this was a perfect thing to do and spend some time indoors admiring local artwork.

Some interesting piace of art. They definitely have some nice pieces of art and it's not a too big place, so doesn't need to spend hours there. If you have a Samsung smartphone, you can get 2 tickets for the price of one. Good deal.

Interesting Space with some interesting exhibits. This is a beautifully designed space, but somehow seemed smaller than i expected. I did visit 24hrs after a long flight so may have been disorientated. There is a lot of good stuff here - there is also a some that's rather so-so. But then that's the thing with art my good stuff may be your so-so.

Beautiful building with good exhibits. I've been to MALBA on a few different trips and each time the temporary exhibit was interesting, extensive and very well presented. I wish the permanent collection was larger so that I felt that I discovering new things on each visit. It's definitely worth checking out if you are interested in contemporary art.

Perfect for a rainy day. It rained our last day in Buenos Aires, so the hotel concierge recommended we visit MALBA. The museum is housed in a beautiful contemporary building in a scenic area of the city. We arrived just as the museum opened, which was great because the line grew rather long shortly after. The number of exhibits is low compared to museums in other major cities, so it only doesn't take long to see everything. The restaurant is very good.

Superb building but content odd and mediocre...too modern, not art. Loved the building but content is contemporary art which in my opinion is art for those who cannot paint of sculpt but want to be artists. I did enjoy seeing the building, building gets 5; art does not.

Nice, but small museum. Good overview of Latin American art, however the permanent exhibition is rather small. The temporary exhibition took considerable space and was at the time done by European guy on Afganistan war and inequality between Europe and Africa. So, topics that are already widely covered for Europeans and did not perhaps give a better insight to Latin America.The ticket was not expensive, but don´t plan more then 1,5-2 hours for it.
Not worth it at all!!!. The only museum in BA what you have to pay for it, 75$ (arg. pesos). The building is nice but the art inside is highly questionable....Huge deception!

Don't miss this art museum in Buenos Aires. This is a nice museum located in a very scenic part of the City. Several floors with a changing special exhibit on the upper and lower floors.Admission is 35-40 pesos, you can check your packsack, and they have a nice café (which is usually busy) and a gift shop.Most of the displays include signage in English and Spanish including background information on the artists.It is a bit off the main streets so write down directions if you are walking there. It is also close to a number of other attractions (Japanese Gardens, Zoo, Botanical Gardens) if you want to combine more than one stop in a day.Definitely recommended.There is a restaurant.
One of the best museums in south america . Houses some of the most important modern artworks of Latin America, as well as prestigious exhibitions.
Fascinating arena. Well worth a visit of you are in Recoleta. Some good art and some other "interesting " material . Wednesdays for Samsung owners was cheap .26 pesos for 2 .

Great rainy day diversion. This museum is a beautiful space, reminds me of many other contemporary art museums with wide open areas, walls for a modest diversion and to create some more hanging space, and bright focused lighting. It was fairly inexpensive, well tended, and had a very diverse collection on exhibit. They seem to have a pretty deep permanent collection. The pieces are presented beautifully and there is more than enough English translation of the accompanying text on the walls by each display. The range was incredible. It might not be as well organized as MOMA, for example, but it makes sense, and leads you through a progression of periods and styles in a nice fashion. There is an adjoining cafe that is pretty good, as well. Go and take it in.
The one museum you must not miss. A great introduction to Latin American and specifically Argentine artists. The building is also exquisite.

Beautiful building moderate collection. The architecture of the building outshines the collection within. We've had the opportunity to visit the finest art museums of the world, and have a good appreciation of Latin American artists, but this lovely museum has a modest collection of the truly great artists available. Having said that, however, there is enough to expose students to a variety of historically evolving techniques. It's a nice museum for the city. I was quite,entertained by the written discriptive dialogue on the walls throughout the museum, a lot of time went in to that assignment.

Don't leave Buenos Aires without visiting it !. Great collection of art from throughout Latin America. interesting diversity and good example of the best artist of the region. Fabulous setting, The building is enjoyable by itself.

Impressive. I really enjoyed roaming this museum. I am still trying to wrap my mind around "modern art," but I liked this museum's attempts at introducing visitors to the different phases of modern art particularly in Latin America. I learned a lot, and it is beautiful inside. It did not mind paying what amounted to $7 to see the upstairs exhibits.

Cheap and chic!. Great little museum. The ticket prices are very reasonable (about 5USD). It's a small museum so you can see the whole thing in less than 2 hours. Items to see? Some great Botero's and the Infamous Frida Kahlo self- portrait.
The museum store was awesome- you can get some great little gifts.

All Depends If You Like Modern Art at a fee!. My wife is into modern art, so she would rate it a 5. But, for me, if my old old antenna fell off the roof, I could display it here!!! I paid 75 pesos for this!! We both greatly enjoyed Museo National de Bella's Artes a few blocks away & it was free. Go figure!!

Lovely building, decent art collection. Eduardo Costantini has had a beautiful modern gallery built to share his (mainly modern) Latin art collection with the city. The building is lovely, reminscent of the Modern Art Museum in Barcelona. But the collection of are is more "decent" than outstanding. For me the highlight was the temporary exhibition by Francis Alÿs with engaging work about being embedded with British forces in Afghanistan and a fascinating film of the artist chasing small tornadoes in fields so he could film them passing over him!
Different. Ultra modern location, combined with radical latinoamerican art. Great location, nearby, there is a fantastic restaurant named Dashi. To make a complete visit

Stimulating art, easy to enjoy. I enjoyed this museum. It is a modest size, nicely displayed, and felt like a nice "bite size" that leaves the visitor intrigued by the experience. If you don't like the performance art displays, or the modern art concepts such as the cell phone rubber banded to the mango, or the complete working hydroponic "biosphere", there is also a more conventional sampling of early earthenware art, a Frida Kahlo, or a Diego Rivera to spend time with. Something for everyone to leave with something new to think about. Finish with a tasty croissant and an espresso on the outside patio.

Fun, complete and easy to visit in an afternoon. The MALBA itself isn't massive, and can be seen in a few hours or less if you're interested in visiting a specific show that's being put on. The cafe there is a nice spot to grab an espresso while exploring the area, which is accessible by bus but isn't the most pedestrian friendly area of the city.
A jewel; must see. this is a collection of Latin American art that is as good as any you can see anywhere. Must see this museum

One of the best spaces to see Modern and Contemporary Art in Buenos Aires. At MALBA, the do a great job of presenting both legendary local artists and international artists. The current exhibition, Francis Alÿs A Story of Negotiation, curated by Cuauhtémoc Medina, is certainly worth a visit
Don't miss it!. Small museum with the best contemporary art in Buenos Aires. Xul Solar watercolors not to be missed! Avoid the coffee shop: expensive and bad.
lovely collection. one of only a few museums opened on Mondays. Spent about 1 1/2 hours looking at a stellar private collection of South American artists.. very nice Cafe in museum .

Great for art lovers. The MALBA has a great collection of LATAM Art. Both the permanent and itinerant collections, are well curated. Developer by Argentinean Mogul Eduardo Costantini, the building is modern and elegant. It houses a nice library and cool gift shop.

Style without substance...... Was really disappointed with Malba. Despite the external appearance, it's pretty much one big room with a handful of interesting pieces, and a lot of filler. Perhaps I was expecting too much, and in fairness, the upper floor was closed while a new exhibition was installed but I was really disappointed with it. I was there when it opened at 12 midday, and was walking down the street by 12.45. It certainly looks the part. But there just isn't a lot there. By all means go if there is a specific piece you want to see. Otherwise, stick to the Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes (Museum of Fine Arts). Pay a visit if there is a specific piece you want to see, otherwise, I'd head to
Great collection not too big. Beautiful building and a great collection that is not too big to get overwhelmed, only need a couple of hours to visit. On peak hours there might be a line.
Small but varied collection. As in any museum, the art is a personal preference ... The collection is varied but small. I would recommend a visit of an hour.
a must see. A wonderful museum of art, always with new exhibitions and cinema offer! Loved the frida khalo drawing! For students a lower price on mednesdays.

It was alright. I was expecting much more in terms of exhibits and space but was disappointed. I would rate Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes much higher not only because entrance fee was free but the number of exhibits on display. In the website it was showing $45 pesos/adult but at the counter, we were charged $75 pesos/adult.

No shivers down my spine. We visited the MALBA after our Argentinian tourguide praised it. Actually we found it OK but bot great. The collection was actually very small. We expected more.. The building is great though!
Great MA museum. Really enjoyed visiting MALBA. A lot of new objects and performances that I didnt expect to see. Amazing place - really worth a shot!

Really great to see South American art - fantastic gallery. We really enjoyed this gallery - they have some classic works of art by South American artists such as Torres Garcia (my favourite) and Frida Kahlo, and some very interesting works by new younger artists. It is big enough to be interesting, but not so big that you get overwhelmed. If you only want to see one art museum in BA make it this one. Very refreshing. And you can take photos!

A pride of our city. The collections are exposed with great care. They also broadcast independent films, which is nice for a change from the commercial movies. They recently exposed outside a replica of the top of the obelisk - it was a wink for locals, pretending they had removed the top of this monument.

Refreshingly different to European museums. We visited MALBA on a recent visit to Buenos Aires and were very impressed with the quality of exhibits that reflected great artistic talent in Latin America. The architectural design of the museum was also very impressive allowing for lots of natural light and an easy flow of visitors. MALBA should definitely be on a Top Ten 'Must Visit' list of attractions in Buenos Aires.
good collection of modern art. pretty good as art museums go. I liked the experience. i did not like the price of entry which was expensive and the queue to pay for the ticket.

Lovely museum in great neighborhood. Although kind of small, the exhibits were very interesting. The cafe is lovely with outdoor seating and fantastic food. I noticed that local people came for the cafe only. (ie they were not visiting the museum). If you go,leave some time to go down the street to visit the mall and also walk the 5 blocks to the Eva Peron Museum which is also worth the visit.

long line on Saturday afternoon, interesting art, see the pyramid outside. Probably best to come here earlier. By 3pm on a Saturday the line got pretty long. The main collection is up the escalator and is pretty fun. I especially liked the pyramid outside, free entrance there.
Good stop at Palermo. I had higher expectations after reading everyone's admirable reviews, but overall it was a good visit and we liked their current exposition.

Interesting!. Well, most of the amazement in this visit was seeing the Abaporu right in front of my eyes without having a clue that it was in there. Nice surprise! Now, you wont have that sensation, but the visit is worth anyway.A nice feature was that gauge installed in front of MALBA, you shout at it and it scores your yelling power!

Half a day to get inspired by art. MALBA. If you like art, this is a must. The permanent collection is brilliant with Argentinian painter Berni's work all over. Everything is so big and wide handbag open spaces in this museum. One of my favorite pieces?? The bench!!! You just have to go and see for yourself. It's in the Palermo side if the city.
Average museum. Nothing much to shout about if you have been to museums in NY, London or Paris. This is just a normal museum. Only visit if you really have time to spare, if not can give a miss.

Half priced Wednesdays are the way to go. A great museum if a little smaller than expected. Half price Wednesdays made it good value for money. Interesting living art exhibition which was interactive at times.
One of the best Museum at BA. At Malba Museum you can enjoy an excellent collection of Latinamerican art. Also the have really good temporary exhibitions from international artists

Nice visit. Although we both aren't modern art enthusiasts we had a pretty good time visiting this Museum. The permanent exhibition is varied and mostly interesting and we enjoyed a lot the temporary one on Polesello. With 2 or 3 temporary events anyone should be able to find one to his taste. The building is very nice and the overall feeling inside is relaxed and pleasant (nobody comes to prevent ou to walk with you bag/camera/coat... as it becomes too often the case in other places). There is a beautiful bookstore inside. Didn't try the restaurant but it looked pleasant as well.

The MALBA is excellent. Always amazing artwork on display. Always an interesting exhibit put up. The collection on hand in regards to Latin American arts will appease all lovers of art as much as a classical European collection would.

Worth a Visit - lots of interactive exhibits. This was a great way to spend a day. Not only was the journey to the gallery fun but so is the quirky and varied art. Whilst there the top of the Obelisko was on display outside which you could go into. We enjoupyed the art on display and you are allowed to take photos of it all. The art is housed in a large open arena and has toilets and lifts on all floors. Definitely worth a visit. Take your id as you are likely to get a discount if you are over 60 or a student or an educator.

Wonderful collection. MALBA has some of the best Latin American art in the world. It was wonderful to see Tarsila do Amaral, Maria Martins, Frida Kahlo, Helio Oiticica, and more. During my visit they also had a contemporary exhibit that was curated very well and had a lot of fascinating, interactive pieces. I'd love to go back.
excellent museum. We really liked this museum- lots of really interesting art by artists you may not know if you are not from Latin America. Well worth visiting.

Abaporu!. Tarsila do Amaral is in the House, Abaporu! Very nice collection, with Botero and very important Latin artists. Beautiful and modern construction. Opens by 12! don't go early in the morning! Accept credit cards and cash!
Must go if you are in Buenos Aires. A must for locals and visitors. The distribution of the museum is great, always with something new, attractive... Even kid friendly.

Not bad. I gave this museum a low rating, but it's mainly because I was expecting to see more Diego Rivera / Oswaldo Guayasamin type of art. It's mainly modern art in the most modern sense of the word, which I don't care for.However, the museum is very nice, top of the line, clean, and relatively cheap. I hit the whole thing in less than an hour. It would be nice if the gift shop had a larger selection, but other than that it was a perfectly adequate visit.

Fabulous art museum.. Permanent exhibition is excellent taste of Latin American artists. Restaurant excellent but potions are huge,very good value.Bread basket amazing. Friendly and efficient waiters. Museum in a really interesting part of city. Taxis very cheap and 1000's of them.

Interesting museum but not for young visitors..!!. Good and well presented museum on contemporary art of LATAM. Anyhow, some exhibition is not appropriated for children or any young visitors. Certainly, it is not a family-friendly museum if you have young children.
Must See!!!!!. Great museum with titles from great Latin American artists. Very beautiful building, a must see for all travelers in Buenos Aires.

YAWN. I went with a Spanish class field trip. I am not a fan of modern art so take that into consideration. The best part of the museum is outside the front door- there is a façade of the Obelisk tower and you step inside and there are four live video feeds from the actual cameras in the obelisk- free and fun! The museum has the usual bizarre and ridiculous "art" presentations (I know, in the eye of the beholder)- one was rather disturbing; it was a video montage and one of the scenes appeared to be a woman being raped, or at least engaging in rough sex (looked like a rape scene). I would not take my child to see this. The highlight of the museum is upstairs; there is a display of glass windows and walls, objects that distort your image when looking through.
Do not miss. This is a great place to understand some of the history and range of Latin American Art. Seemed very accessible and lots of explanations in English, not to mention some great art!
A must see. This museum is one of my all time favorites. The art is curated beautifully and the museum picks cutting edge, interesting pieces to show.

One of a kind Museum. The Malba is definitely a must see if you are in Buenos Aires. The art is creative and is unlike anything I've ever seen. They have everything from Frida Kahlo to many more modern artists. My family found the pieces that had mirrors and illusions to be amazing and so fun to look at. Make sure to leave yourself a couple hours to explore! The cafe was very pricey and had average sized portions (but delicious food) I would revisit the museum but not the cafe.

Small but Worthwhile Museum. We truly enjoyed the jewel box of a museum but were disappointed not to see more of the classic Latin American Art. For example there was just one Frieda Kahlo on exhibit. It looks like they were under construction and might be adding more gallery space. The restaurant is awesome!

Well worth a visit and spending time enjoying the collection. Great collection that is well presented, the gallery is well organised on a number of levels and is highly recommended. Can get very crowded at times but just take your time as it is well worth it.

Very good collection of modern art. MALBA is definitely worth a visit! The building is stunning and there is a very good, albeit small, collection. I learned a lot about Latin American art! Depending on the special exhibits, you can tour it in about an hour or so. There is a small gift shop with some nice items for sale. The restaurant - Marcello - is excellent and shouldn't be missed. Also don't forget to walk around the neighbourhood where there are some nice villas.
Great names. Has some very relevant pieces by the most famous Latin artists. I recommend planning a couple of hours in this museum fly anyone travelling to Buenos Aires.
Loved MALBA!. Thoroughly enjoyed this museum! In comparison to the Modern and Contemporary Art museums, this was by far my favorite! I also recommend purchasing the book of the collection!

Belissimo!. Exelent museum. Small but their collection is absolutly stunning. THose one from south america please do not lose this museum in ordem to understand a bit more of our history - not sure why ABAPURU is there....

Interesting... Worth a trip! . I learnt so much about art in the rooms that did have some English explanations, it's interesting to see how things over the years have impacted how people see and do create art around it. You can breeze round all of the rooms in just under and hour. For more of an art lover who may take it in better it could be a longer trip. Remember it's not far from Recoleta cemetery either, two top tips if there's a line on the floor don't cross it! And also no flash photography! They both got me into a little trouble... Beautiful modern building whilst there the Paraguay exhibit is also worth seeing.

Love it. Its has three floors full of every kind of art. It includes a movie theatre, a library, and rooms made specially for one piece. You can find Frida Kahlo and botero art, besides a lots of other artists. I paid really low as a student, defenitly a place you have to go in Buenos aires.

Small but precious collection. The Malba is a must for those looking for the essential of latin american modern painting. Well worth the visit. On Wednesdays students, teachers and retirees do not pay admission but must show document. Free wifi once inside.

MALBA is a small but excellent place to see great artists from the region. Beautiful architecture, nice location, excellent stable collections and incredible temporary exhibitions from other Latin-American countries.
Outstanding collection of Latin American Arte Moderno. See outstanding art and special exhibitions in a modern setting. Worth periodic visits to see new works of art.

Wonderful Museum with Highly Diverse Galleries. I loved this museum. It is very entertaining. They has wonderful art and photographs. The galleries are highly diverse and each will take you to a different place. I particularly loved the modern "participation" pieces.

Must-see in Buenos Aires. What a fabulous museum. This is the largest collection of Latin American art I've seen, and it's amazing and well-curated. The museum itself is also a beauty. The restaurant inside is very good too.

Innovative art exhibits. Fun to visit. Very worthwhile visiting while in Buenos Aires. The building is beautiful. We explored the top floor where there was a special exhibit of Prosello Joven--the younger years of a principal Argentine artist. It was great and varied. Not very formal. The dark room to experience total darkness was great although a bit scary. I have gone to this Art museum before. But found it even better this time around. Great focus on latin American artist frequently not known or recognized in other countries.

If you like modern art ..... MALBA has an excellent collection of modern art - a really diverse selection and representation of styles, mediums, artists and regions. You're allowed to take photos, too.

Don't miss the MALBA. There are a number of large corporate sponsors to the museum, like Samsung. So if you show your Samsung phone you get a 2 for one entrance. If you're a teacher, likewise entrance discounts. So the MALBA has a cool interior, open air and the rooms flow nicely from one to the next. There are display cards in Spanish and in English. Permanent collection of Latin American artists is pretty good...Rivera, Berni, Kahlo and more. Nice indoor / outdoor café.
Nice stop. Smaller than expected, but quality. Many museums close by as well, so it was easy to walk between them and make a day of it.
Don't miss it. A beautiful building that holds impressive works of art from Latin America. Get in touch with our roots and experience the evolution of art in our continent.

not thrilling but nice. Interesting but if you are from New York or another big city don't expect the same range and variety.offerings are very limited.one Frida kahlo one Diego Rivera. A pleasant experience.
Must see. Wonderful museum. A must go see. You'll spend about 2-3 hours there. I loved seeing things we wouldn't normally see in the US.
Refreshing. Interesting permanent collection, with Refreshing expositions of varied artists. Building itself is also worth a visit.

Botero, Diego Rivera and many others. Interesting summary of modern Latin American Art that you can enjoy in 2 hours. Note Citi discount 25% is only for local account.To me, exhibition on Rogelio Polesello was interesting reminding me of Yayoi Kusama.

one of the nicest museums. Very interesting exhibits. IN one, as you walk through the room, it captures the dialogues and transcribes it. IN another one a man was holding a zillion things that were connected to him.All in all had a nice experience.

Wonderful building and even better collection of modern Latin American Art. NO great surprise that MALBA is one of the top attractions for visitors to Buenos Aires as well as for BA residents. This is a great collection of art from all over Latin America with exhibits of not just paintings but also photography, sculptures and other art forms. MALBA also has film screenings. The museum is easy to get to (its in the swish district of Palermo). You'll recognise some of the painters (Diego Rivera, Frida Kahlo, Botero etc, but Roberto Matta, Lygia Clark and Antonio Berni may not be as familiar. The entrance fee is very moderate.My only criticism would be that the MALBA is often very crowded. Still, this is one of the gems of Buenos Aires 'Mile of Museums' and shouldn't be missed. Oh, there's also a plea ant bar and restaurant attached.
Excellent collection in an excellent environment. The best Latin American art collection, in an excellent building.The gift shop is a place to look into..

MALBA museum, unexpected pleasure. We liked the variety in the types of artistic media in this museum. There were paintings, lithographs, photos,, sculptures. A few of the artists were people we had already heard of, but really enjoyed the most the artists we had not heard of.

Leading modern art items from Latin America. Interesting museum with exceptional Latin American artists. The one exhibit with plastic hanging bubbles and other structures is so fun and exciting for guests.
Best exhibition ever seen. I love this museum. Antonio Berni's great collection, love every piece of them. Been to many museums, the collections in this just opened my eyes.

Quick Visit Beautiful Works. I visited Malba and the cost was 36 Arg. pesos. I was pleased by the cleanliness, the staff and of course all the artwork from artists I did not know. This is a good take and worth it. There is also a dining area and museum store with fairly priced items. Some of the more extensive works were by Polesello Joven. I am not an artist but there are five different categories of art to be seen here up to contemporary. Even the non artist will walk away with a lesson in art history! There are many statues along the way from Recoleta Cemetery, about 1 mile and a half walk. It is recommended not to walk at night in this area but very normal and safe in daytime.

Thought we missed something. I was pumped to go here, and I went with a local, but we were both shocked that we got through it so quickly. We thought we were missing something... There was some cool stuff, and it's worth going to if you have time, but nothing memorable and small exhibits. There was this one light exhibit... oh, man... I can't do it justice in words, but I started laughing hysterically (because it was so bad)

Excellent and well curated modern art museum. See a little bit of every kind of modern art here in one quick stop. From ancient artifacts and Diego Rivera pieces to fun pop art and video art you will get a great taste of Latin American art here. Highly recommend.
Not overwelming. Great Museum.. This museum provides a great over view of Latiin American artists. Always great exhibits. My favortie in BA. Around the corner is Paseo Alcorta. great shopping.

Learned a lot about Latin American Art!. Just amazing. It´s a must do in Buenos Aires, you will learn more than you expected about Latin American art. It´s located close to the garden of roses a really nice area to relax during the afternoon.
Good visit. Worth a visit. Interesting building, some good art.On main thoroughfare, easy to find. Restaurant looks good too.
My favorite. One of my favorite museums in Buenos Aires. Fun and interesting. They had the Polesello Joven exposition when I visited.
Only if you have time to kill. A four-star museum by South American standard, otherwise three-stars compared with its peers in other major international cities. Small collections of work.

Great -- Wish for More. Fascinating museum. My only complaint is that it wasn't large enough. There is one Frida Kahlo work, but don't go just for that. I discovered some names and works I didn't know before.

A must visit in modern Buenos Aires!. Inaugurated in 2001, the MALBA Museum is already a landmark and a must visit in Buenos Aires. It houses one of the largest and most valuable collections of Latin American modern and contemporary art in the whole world: the Eduardo Costantini's Collection. This businessman and philantropist, while establishing the MALBA Museum, shares his fantastic collection with us! Outstanding paintings from Tarsila do Amaral, Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera, among many others. Take the opportunity, check MALBA opening hours, temporary exhibitions and organize your visit. No visiting fees for teachers and senior citizens! One last remark: the "Museo Nacional de Arte Decorativo (MNAD)" is at a walking distance from MALBA, allowing you to easily combine both visits. Enjoy!

Best collection of Latin American Art. The collection was really amazing, and as teachers we got in free. I've never seen so much quality Latin American art in one place, and it has a wide range. We had fun taking pictures with the pop art.
Good place on a rainy day. Very nice Gallery, popped past to see the Frida Kahlo art and found lots more interesting things to see.

New Perspective on Modern Art. MALBA is a fantastic museum of modern art. What make MALBA stand out - besides the great space and fine collection of Latin American work -- is the signage (most in Spanish). I learned a great deal about different Modern Art styles and the artists, in a concise way. This museum made me want to learn more, something that the USA's great museums hadn't accomplished.
Fantastic museum for adults and migs. Great collection of contemporary LA art, some interactive switches for children, and beautiful building. Highly recommend！

modern museum worth seeing. 3 levels of art. Found more european art here than in all of the art museums in this city which is funny since it has 'latin american art' in it's name! Degas, Monet, Van Gogh, etc.
A great place for a few hours of intellect. Excellent place to see some incredible modern work, two great paintings by two great Mexican artists: Diego River and Frida Kahlo.

You must go!. It's a singular place with beautiful pieces of art!
You can take pictures (without flash) and the museum is very technologic (they encourage to share on social medias!!!).

Excellent collection for LATAM! Fun & easy to go-by. This museum is nice! I went because it said it had work from Diego Rivera, Frida Kahlo and Botero, but though they are there and are stunning, there are much other modern and contemporary works by other Latin-American artists which are great.I personally enjoy the modern art and I thought the permanent collection was good. It is not too big but it allows you about 30 minutes of slowly enjoying it. The salon is big and well organized.The exposition at the moment was Polesello joven (young Polesello, an argentinian artist) and it was great! I didn't expect it but his works with acrylic are fantastic, fun and interactive. I went alone but I think is a great opportunity to visit with friends or family.
Nice art work. Some important painting from Latin American artists. However, I was expecting the art collection to be much bigger, as well as the building.

Can't miss. Great latin american collection, i had the oportunity to get to know very talented argentinian designer Polesello's work. Really cool thing to do, either with a partner, friend or family/kids

Exceptional place. MALBA is just incredible, eclectic, and very intriguing. There are usually several live exhibits that leave visitors in total awe. It´s an exceptional way to spend an afternoon in BA.

Great musuem Current Polesello exhibit is great. beautiful museum that highlights latin American artists throughout history and the different movements. There was a Polesello exhibit that was fantastic to view. Top notch museum in BA that must be seen.
the best modern art museum in BA, Latin American Art. This is the best modern art museum in BA, Latin American Art, a must if you visit Buenos Aires. not far from centre of town

Expensive, Especially Without Special Exhibit. MALBA is a good museum in a beautiful building. However, the entrance fee is rather high, especially since the rotating exhibit at the time was not open when we went. The girls at the ticket office did inform us when we purchased the tickets, but we were only going to be in Buenos Aires a few days, and wanted to see some nice art work. Overall, I would check it out, but I was slightly disappointed.

Great films sessions, clean and well maintained building. This place is in perfect conditions, worth to visit. The building is always clean and tidy, despite the crowded visits for popular exhibitions.The permanent collection, besides Berni's, is not of my favorite art schools, but it depends on your preferences. What I truly recommend is to attend to their film festivals. It has a great organization and original projections.

Amazing exhibition. Was really surprising the quality of the exhibition', the Berni's, Rivera, and the early Rogelio Polesello.
Besides the quality, the museum stand itself, this is something Argentineans can feel proud.Not only soccer.
Really superb, also the tickets prices are completely affordable.

Terrific art museum, definitely worthwhile. MALBA is a good place to visit because it is inexpensive and interesting. It contains a wide variety of art and should appeal to both avid and casual museum-goers. The museum isn't enormous, so don't plan to spend hours on end, but it's got a sizable collection of interesting art.It's closed on Tuesdays but opens at noon on all other days. Wednesdays are the cheapest, with an entry fee about $36 pesos. Students get in free as well.
Small But Mighty. This art museum had a great representation of South American art which was very well displayed. Easy to see it all in a couple of hours.

Affordable and doable in half a day. Has a nice selection of Latin American art, comprising both permanent and rotating exhibitions. What some may see as a limited number of exhibits is a bonus, making the experience not too overwhelming. Entrance fee is reasonable, but a frightfully expensive cafe brings the score down

Great art and great food - what more does a human being need?. World class modern art gallery both in the architecture and design. It also has a superb, stand-alone restaurant which is both stylish but unstuffy - a destination in its own right with top notch food at decent prices. A don't miss in BA.

Wonderful museum!. This was an intriguing place. The permanent collection is smallish but excellent, and there were some fabulous installations on the top floor. I am usually not a fan of the latter but these were clever and funny and extremely well executed. In addition, there were two wonderful photographic exhibitions. Plus, it's a great building.

Surprised how good the collection was. The permanent is large and impressive. Lots of local artists are represented. Argentina has a rich history of art that is unknown to many north americans and this is a great place to get a crash source. It is not unlike MOMA in New York and has a great gift shop to boot. I am still carrying the bag I bought there. I think it has close to 400 thousand flown miles on it.
Very interesting museum. Great museum with some very interesting pieces. The cafe is a great place for a pre-museum meal or drink as well.
A great day out.. You can easily spend a good afternoon at the MALBA! An interesting collection of Argentinian and Latin American artists well worth a visit.

Students get in free on Wednesday!. This museum is stunning, with several floors containing different exhibits. Some of the exhibits include people, which was fascinating to see. The exhibits are thought-provoking and leave you pondering each piece. General entrance is 60 pesos, but students who come on Wednesdays (with a valid student ID) can enter for free.
Wow! Porteños and Argentinians love color and art.. The Malba was a great way to spend an hour or two enjoying contemporary Argentine art. Well worth a visit.
Art in the City. Art Deco taken to a new means, How enligtning to see art from Latin artist on display very authentic and true to their roots

A museum worthwhile visiting. I was particularly interested in seeing a Brazilian outstanding painting the " Ibapuru". I was quite surprised to run Into a very interesting presentation of art with light. Although an admirer of paintings no canvas, I was quite impressed with the exhibit. Of you like to step out beyond your boundaries in art Thais museum is a great option.

Fine Museum. The permanent collection is impressive--a 'Who's Who' of LA art. I also saw an exhibit of work by a 20th C photographer that was excellent. It's not a huge museum, so you can easily see it all in an afternoon.

Fine art in a nice place!. This museum is one of the latest been inaugurated in Buenos Aires. Belongs to a very important business man, lover of fine art. you can find permanent gallery and depending of the season there are special galleries dedicated to particular artists. Plus theater to go to movies and a nice coffee shop towards the garden. Excellent place to visit!
Don´t expect to see too many paintings.. A museum that is located in Buenos Aires fanciest neighborhood. The regular collection is OK, not too many paintings, though.

A Delightful Experience. Well done experience for both the art enthusiast and those with less exposure to modern art. It was more of an art experience than merely looking at paintings on walls. The building design added to the pleasure.

An Art Lover's Must!. Gorgeous collection. Very interesting special exhibits...I can only imagine that is always the case. Small compared to many other art museums so it is very doable in part of an afternoon. Don't miss out.

Small collection, but interesting. This was nice but I thought they'd have more. Of course I missed tomorrow's opening of another artist. They advertised khalo & rivera & botero but only had 1 of each. Also they said they had movies about artists &/or time periods but you had to stand to watch the whole piece. They need more of this with places to sit.  Also, this was my first time, ever, not buying anything in the gift store. They could add items!

A delight. Well curated modern Latin American art. Yes, there is a Frida Kahlo and a Diego Rivera but the permanent collection contains works by other outstanding in a variety of media from across Latin America. We also had a delicious meal in the the Museum restaurant.

Permanent exhibit is fantastic. Only a few USD for entrance, and they accept US student IDs to get in cheaper. The permanent exhibit is a wonderful display of talented Latin artists from Rivera to Botero. The top floor is a rotating exhibit. It was an experimental performance art section when I went. It was all very weird to an untrained eye, but I actually enjoyed it and felt like I gained a decent bit from it

Nice pieces, but limited material. When I went, one of the floors was closed so that this review may not be reflective of the complete collection. There are some nice pieces including a good Frida Kahlo and a good Botero. I liked it though.

I'm not sure it's worth it..maybe just because it was only half open... There was only the first floor open when I went today, and there was no more than 50 painting I guess in total. It is nice though, but I'm wondering if it really is representative of latin american art. It seemed a little more modern than latin. a nice, if not sad, work from botero was my favourite.

Modern way to see Latin artists . The upstairs portion of the museum was closed when we were there but the second floor exhibited unique Latin America artists that you are not necessarily exposed to in the United States. It's not as large as MOMA in NYC but it was definitely a good place to visit and quick reference point for art lovers.
Good architecture. Interesting modern architecture but the collection is small. Its main attraction is Do Amaral's "Abaporu".
Amazing Museum -. This is an amazing museum and a must visit when in BA. It showcases the best that Latin American Art has to offer and is elegantly done.

Famous paintings and challenging installations. We loved see famous works by Latin American greats, but the highlight was the special exhibition of live installation pieces. The live installations were challenging and odd, but are the kind of experiences that we will be telling stories about for ages.

A unique, modern museum. We were lucky to see a spectacular show of Berni while there, but all of the exhibits look amazing and beautifully curated. Large, modern, well maintained, great gift shop, lots of light, excellent but small permanent art collection. 2-3 hours depending on how long you like to linger. Reasonably priced entrance fee.
Not one of the best museums in BA. There are many more interesting museums in BA to visit if time is short.Do not bother with lunch as it is overpriced and the service is slow and haughty.

Awesome Museum. Small, so won't take up a lot of your time and won't give you chronic museum legs. Permanent exhibition isn't big in size but packed full of great pieces from Antonio Berni to Frida Kahlo. The quirky environment of the museum is doubled by the experience upstairs in the temporary exhibition. Really weird, performance-art stuff but it really sticks in the mind. Have recommended and will continue to reccomend this gallery.

Combining this Museo with Arte Decorativo then lunch, a great day!. This isn't a large museum but it's an interesting one - we enjoyed both the permanent and temporary exhibitions. There is a seniors' rate if you're over 60. We were hoping for an overview of Latin American Art but that's not really what this Museo presents. However, being keen amateur photographers now that we have retired, we really enjoyed the exhibition on the works of Annemarie Heinrich - see our pic of her photo from 1940. We were disappointed that there wasn't much information provided about the lives of the artists but we were inspired to do more reading after our visit. Another highlight was a short dance/drama piece (approx 20 min?) representing time & at the end they formed "a revolving door" that you could walk through. It took us a while to work out what this piece was about (we might be a bit slow with our understandings of this art form!) but we ended up enjoying it, especially the looks on the children's faces who were also trying to work it all out!...(see 2nd photo). We combined our visit to this Museo with the Museo National de Arte Decorativo - a very reasonable entrance fee so worth the 15 min walk (across the main road) between the two museums (check opening times as Arte Decorativo opened later). Walking through this very affluent area is interesting in itself eg. lots of dog walkers exercising a range of very pampered pooches! We had planned on having a light lunch at one of the museums but both looked very expensive for what we felt like - a simple sandwich. We walked along the main street and found a pleasant/sunny outdoor cafe. If you're looking for a very pleasant day out, we suggest combining the 2 museums and staying in the area for lunch. After that we walked back to the main road where it was easy to get a taxi back to our hotel. The hotel suggested the "safer" taxis to look out for...not sure of name now as that was a couple of weeks ago.

Innovative building--quality of regional art depends on current exhibitions. Worth spending an hour or so if the current exhibition is interesting. If the weather is good, you can have a pleasant 1.5km walk to/from the Museo de Bellas Artes--ok visit, mostly somewhat mediocre European art.
Must see!. It's not a big museum so you won't spend that much time there. we stayed there for less than an hour and checked the whole place!

Experience depends on the current exhibition, permanent collection is limited. I visited MALBA on a recent trip to Buenos Aires as it was one of the few museums in the city open on a Monday. I had previously visited the museum on a trip to Buenos Aires several years ago. The first floor of the museum houses its permanent collection and the second floor is dedicated to temporary exhibitions. The permanent collection is a bit limited and although several of the individual pieces are great, they do not necessarily tell a cohesive story about Latin American art when taken together. The success of a visit to MALBA really depends on what the current exhibition is. On my prior visit, the show was dedicated to the work of Felix Gonzales-Torres and provided a comprehensive overview of the artist’s work. On my visit earlier this week, the exhibit focused on recreating live performance pieces by international artists. This made for a unique and at times uncomfortable visit as there was little explanation of the works, perhaps on purpose.

Perfect intro to Latin American Artists. This was a really interesting museum. Exhibits were from a few well known names for me but it also introduced me to other artists I had never heard of. A terrific collection that is not too huge. The restaurant was really expensive, but food ok. There was one exhibit of some ecological thing that was not well maintained, but in general this gallery was very good and well worth a visit.

Very cool museum. This is one of the nicest museums in latin america. It has one of the most impressive latin american artist collections and has great temporary expos. When I was there they had Mario Testino.
Fun. We enjoyed the new and permanent exhibits. Well worth the visit. There was performance art on the top floor and a great collection of Latin American art on the second.
a respite from the rain. interesting permanent collection of art and the temporary installations were unique and very accessible.
Very interesting!. Had no expectations and was delightfully surprised.very human art in motion. Not your usual art museum.

The Marcelo restaurant is a treat.... I didn't visit the museum, but the Marcelo cocina is a real treat. Good coffee and lovely cakes. They do an incredible passion fruit marmalade with their bread. I still need to find it in Buenos Aires. Nice and quaint cafe. We only went for afternoon tea, but the lunch also looked amazing, as the waiters brought it to other customers. Service was ok. The waiter we had was quite grumpy and unfortunately added 125ARS to the bill by mistake, which left a bit of a sour taste in my mouth because of the way he dealt with it. It was taken off in the end.

MALBA - Buenos Aires, Argentina: MUST VISIT. MALBA was incredible. It was the most interactive museum that I have ever been to. It was interesting, eclectic, and very intriguing. There were several live exhibits that left us in total awe. It was an exceptional way to spend an afternoon.

Beautiful museum!. There You will see some boarding modern art, but also some unexpected exhibitions! Unusuall!
In the corner there is a great bistro.

Quality not quantity. I was not really sure what to expect with this museum, but I left extremely impressed by the originality of the exhibits. The paintings were beautiful, but I left more impressed by the exhibits that had to do with perception. One of the exhibits in particular was worth the entrance fee. It was a large screen with a story being written as you walk in. After a few moments pass by I realized the woman in the corner was writing her perception of what was happening in the room (which included what me and my family were doing). If my only critique is that it wasn't bigger than I assume it is worth the visit.
Great Museum!. I enjoyed this museum, it doesn't have an extensive collection but very nice and cheap admission. The restaurant on the side is outstanding!

Just the right length of time. MALBA is the perfect modern museum. I walked around with a friend for about an hour and a half and was fascinated by the interactive exhibits. You won't leave feeling like you missed entire exhibits because the museum isn't huge– you leave feeling like you saw it all. You'll love it.

Visit if you have time.. MALBA is a nice space, the exhibitions are well organized. The art is not plentiful, though. A few interesting pieces but the name of the museum invokes expectations that, unfortunately, are not met.

Unique place, even for non-art fans. My wife and I are not art fans, full stop. But we went to MALBA and definitely had some new content to talk about afterwards! The first couple floors were pretty standard – works from artists across Latin America covered the walls. The top floor, however, is what stuck with us – a series of “active” art installations (their current exhibition). One room had men simply painting the white walls more white. Another had us write our name and the time we entered the room on a wall. A third had a man in a corner wearing a face-covering mask that emitted light on 3 sides. The most bizarre had a man connected by wires to multiple objects floating in the room – not just controlled by his hands, but mouth, nose, ears, legs, and even some more, well, private parts. Every calculated motion of his adjusted the objects in the room. Odd, yes, but pretty unique and accessible for non-art fans such as ourselves.

Definitely worth it. This is a great museum with a permanent exhibit including several famous artworks such as Frida Kahlo, as well as a changing exhibit that we most enjoyed. It was interactive and a lot of fun. Just be sure to plan properly, as they don´t open until noon.

MALBA MUSEUM. I have been 3 times at the Malba, since 2003. It has a beautiful arquitecture and nice restaurant and gift shop. You should see it at least once, for its architecture, even if you are not interested in modern art.

Excellent if pricey lunch. Sophisticated selection of salads, fusion cuisine, etc. with decent wines in a nice setting. Wasn't the cheapest place in this burg but the art makes a visit to this museum a must.
Great art experience. My favourite art gallery in BsAs - beautiful modern building with a varied and representative permanent collection.

Fun museum- nice 'extra' on your trip to B.A.. Malba is a really nice museum- one of the best in Latin America, but I wouldn't say it should land on your 'must see' list, especially if you are on a short trip to B.A. If you have more time, or are particularly interested then it is certainly worth a visit. One of the best parts is that you can take pictures of the pieces- certainly something I've never experienced at another museum.The modern museum collects only contemporary works. You will see a lesser known Diego Rivera in a break from his more traditional style, and a great Frida Kahlo self portrait among other things. There is some very modern, Avant Garde art on the second floor. You probably want 1- 2 hours to get through the museum.

Really interesting art musuem. I grew up near Washington, DC, so I am pretty spoiled in having visited a lot of great museums. MALBA did not disappoint! The permanent collection provided a good introduction to Latin American artists that I was not too familiar with. It was especially impressed with the kinetic art section. On the top floor where they have temporary exhibits, the "Infinite Experience" was unlike nothing I had ever seen before and I really enjoyed it. On the mail level, they had a great exhibit of Annemarie Heinrich photography. That was my favorite part of the museum.This museum is mostly contemporary art, so if you're looking for something else, you won't like it. If you like contemporary art though, definitely go. I enjoyed it!

Good overview of Latin American Art. The museum is very modern, and really light and airy inside. There's a great permanent collection, that gives you a nice overview of some of Latin America's best artists. Loved the Frieda Kahlo original. The top floor is the exhibition space, which changes. Don't go on the weekend - it is super popular with locals and tourists and the lines are long. Go on a Wednesday when its cheaper.

A treat for your eyes. Portinari, Tarsila do Amaral, Xu Solar, Diego Rivera, Antonio Berni, Frida Kahlo and many others. You won't regret the visit. Keep in mind the opening time of the museum, we had to wait outside for some minutes.

Go for the Restaurant, Not the Art!. Outstanding, but expensive, food at the restaurant. The first floor (per enact exhibit) art is average. They do have a Frieda Kahlo original. The second floor, "Experience Infinity"Is a 60s type "be-in" kind of experiential art. If you were born after 1970 it might be interesting.

If you like contemporary art this museum is not to be missed.. Easy access in wheelchair. Beautiful building. Lovely restaurant good food. Eat inside or outside with the stupid smokers. Buenos Aires hasn't learned that the best seats should go to non smokers. we ate inside. Elegant. The museum itself has the best Argentinian contemporary collection. It is truly world class. Best part of our visit. spend two hours.

Nice permanent collection + fun experimental art. A nice modern building (for the lovers of modern architecture) - a nice welcome and a very nice permanent collection. On the second floor there was an experimental exposition ongoing with some young artists which was fun - really out of the box. Loved it.

Latin American Taste. MALBA has a unique taste that will turn you into a Latin lover. It is warm and delicious to the senses, allowing you to enter new realms as you dive deeper into the feeling behind the art. The dimensions discovered here are very cool.

Strange. Sorry, but not to my tastes. There were some unusual human performances that left us wondering what it was supposed to be, but that also fit in with much of the "art" that is on display. We left after 45 minutes. Nearby Belles Artes and also Evita museum were much preferred.
amazing. great museum. If you want to go to a museum in bsas this is the one. exhibition was beautiful and interesting.

Latin American Art at Buenos Aires. Fundación Constantini is the private owner of this stupendous Art Collection, where some of the most representative Art from Latin American painters and sculptors may be found along this modern and well lightened building .
Diego Rivera, Emilio Pettoruti, Frida Kahlo, Antonio Berni and Fernando Botero are a must, in this Monument to Culture and Art !

Beautiful museum with interesting exhibits. This museum has a variety of art that is nicely displayed. I appreciated the accessibility and being able to borrow a wheelchair.
It also has an excellent restaurant.

Something different. I liked MALBA. Especially if you are an art lover I would recommend this museum. They have some great and original pieces. I liked the third floor the most; where you are a part of art; it was very unexpected. I did think it was rather small.

Great contemporary Latin American art. This was my 5th visit to this amazing art gallery in Recoleta. The art collections are so diverse and never fail to impress you with their quality. They have famous artists from all over Latin America such as Botero from Colombia or Frida Kahlo from Mexico and naturally lots of Argentine artists like Carlos Alonso. There are 3 main floors with a permanent rotating collection on one floor and multiple modern sculptures scattered throughout. There is the standard bookshop in the basement for great books and souvenirs of your visit. When I was visiting this time they had actors performing living sculptures which they called Experienca infinite. Downstairs they had an ultra modern dance performance choreographed by Osias Yanov. It was exhausting and exhilarating just watching it.
Must see. This is a perfect size museum with a diverse selection of offerings by South American artists. Great way to spend half a day.

Interesting art collection in a beautiful modern building. Had great fun in this modern/contemporary collection. The building is spacious and light-filled with presentation on par with any international exhibition. A diverse collection of 20th-21st century art from the region. One piece involved a museum 'guard' who would suddenly burst into song. We usual have moaning children when we visit art galleries, but this was more successful. Had a very expensive lunch at the adjacent restaurant.

Well organized collection and interesting live art. It is a small collection but very well curated. Special exhibitions were very well done. There was also live artists throughout which was a little surprising for me, but my wife and kids loved it

Beautiful building and interesting collection. The permanent collection of Latin American Artists is small but good. The modern art is interesting, to say the least. While we found it very "out there" it certainly gave us much to talk about! It's definitely worth a visit.

Worth checking out!. This is a small museum with interesting (and sometimes provocative) exhibits. It is well worth seeing and a great value; you can see all the exhibits within 60-90 minutes and then walk to a great cafe. We saw two performance art exhibits, that we are still talking about!

Fantastico!!. a really wonderful collection-- Berni really spoke to me. 5 star!! I'm not a huge art museum fan, but this one was so uncrowded and offered such a wonderful collection that I was really captivated,

Waste of your time. One more museum, in the row of other it have very buitiful building and very nice trimmed trees and bushes surranded. But inside nothing impresing colledction, mabe besause a time of our visit or some issue with money colleted from gouverment. It not worst your time to visiting.

My mind has been blown!. My daughter took us to the MALBA because it has a half price entrance fee on Wednesdays. So we paid about $3 each to see the special exhibit entitled Experience Infinity that is on display until June 15, 2015. This is a performance art exhibit that had us talking for the rest of the day. I have a feeling that we will be talking about Experience Infinity for a long time to come. To go to a museum and end up thinking about the very nature of our existence is not a bad deal for 30 pesos.The museum is small. You can easily see all the exhibits in under two hours. My wife says that the purpose of art is to raise questions and not to find answers. You will leave this unique museum with lots of questions that go well with Argentine wine after your visit.
Worth a visit. Very interesting and imaginative Latin American artists! Had some performance artists. I've never experienced a museum quite like it.
Extraordinary. A different museum!beautiful bilding and decoration.nice pieces .the living art on the second floor create a vivid atmosphere.nice work, i could easily visit it once again
Worthy of a visit. We enjoyed our visit to the museum and our rest from the heat in the cafe alfresco. Unfortunately the staff in the Gift store where incredible rude and good to avoid.
Definitely worth a visit. If you are a fan of contemporary and modern art, you will be definitely be pleased with this museum.

Wonderful Art in Buenos Aires. This collection of Latin American art is very diverse. During my visit, I found the permanent collection intriguing, cut two actual human forms of art were a little complex.
Great Art in beautiful, manageable space. The art was more impressive than we expected even with all the hype, the space was fantastic, and the outdoor café very good.
Good interesting museum. Value for money and a lot of variety in the exhibits, a good place to while away an hour or two. The building is pretty cool in itself.

Great Modern Art museum at Recoleta. Excellent temporary exhibits and installations. Their permanent exhibit features the Costantini Collection including works by Frida Kahlo, Diego Rivera, Fernando Botero and Tarsila do Amaral.
Admission price on Wednesdays it's only $5. The museum is closed on Tuesdays.
By bus: 0, 37, 38, 41, 59, 60, 67, 92, 93, 95, 102, 108, 110, 118, 124, 128, 130.

Impressive Permanent Collection and Contemporary multimedia art performances. Great modern Latin American artists in their permanent collection with the added bonus of great contemporary multimedia performance art on third floor. Excellent photo exhibit of the works of Annemarie Heinrich. Building itself is an architectural marvel. Would not recommend their restaurant with high prices, small portions, and poor food.
Cool Modern Art Museum. This museum had a lot of neat and interactive exhibits. It was a nice complement to Bellas Artes on a rainy day of museum-hopping in Buenos Aires.

They wrote my name on the wall. This was a fun visit. They had an exhibit where there was a man stopping role and writing the time and their name on the wall. Some other interesting stuff to check out.

Loved it. I was very happy with the second floor exhibit and got to discover 3 new artists who I never heard of before: Alejandro Jul Solar, Miguel Covarrubias and Antonio Berni. Wonderful works by these artists and the historical video on the recovery of the Berni mural was quite educational.. The temporary exhibit on the third floor, called Infinite Experience was "modern", very quirky and, after a brief period of puzzlement, very enjoyable.

A posh museum of modern art. MALBA is the most popular museum of modern art, probably of South America. The reason: a bit of TATE Modern, a bit of MoMA, a bit of pretentious. If you are into that kind of art, is a must when you visit Argentina's capital.
Enlighting place. It is a very well organized and modern museum. you can see the best samples from Latin American contemporary art. Must see.

must see/hear experience. Has about 550 holdings but displays about 25%. Three floors with the third floor devoted to performance art that channeled one's involvement into the art. Works from Latin American only, but have been lent to North American Museums. On second floor a typical museum guard broke into an inspiring solo in the room. Entrance fee is about $5 USD and the restaurant is worth the stop for good food and wines.

Terrific Collection. Wonderful collection of Latin American Art and also we were fortunate to see a number of performance artists on the second floor during our visit, a temporary exhibit. Go here. You will be very glad that you did.

Not what I had hoped for. Only one floor was open for viewing since the museum was getting ready to open another exhibit on the 3rd floor. Viewing that would have made all the difference. The second floor was open, and we enjoyed viewing the permanent collection. Plenty of security staff around but only one rest room for the museum and the cafe and the women's was in serious need of some attention. See my review for the cafe in a separate review.
Art. Art was different and museum was lovely. The works were extensive and presented well. Location of museum was lovely

Fun and Unexpected. We spent several hours at MALBA. First floor was conventional art from 20th century Argentine artists. Some of it quite good, some unusual. We had not seen the objects that moved when switched on. Video of obtaining a fresco from an estancia was enlightening and gave more meaning to looking at the fresco on a nearby wall. Top floor was unexpected. Performance art at its finest. One room was a guy attached by wires and pulleys to various objects in the room. His movements made them go up and down and sideways. Surprise was that one of them was attached to a prosthetic penis protruding from his pants. Next room was a troupe of marchers in an open space. Eventually we realized that they were a revolving door and the only means of exit was through them. They marched around and provided an opening for egress. Thoughtprovoking and original.

Beautiful gem of a museum. Beautiful museum with a great collection on modern art. It also houses a wonderful gift shop with affordable gifts to take back home. It's a great stop on the museum tour of Buenos Aires.

Good painting selection and a fabulous restaurant. My wife and I, both artists, enjoyed this museum the most of any we saw in Argentina. When we were there in March 2015, there was a very worthwhile painting exhibit. But the star of the visit may have been lunch at the white tablecloth restaurant. High quality Italian food. My wife swooned over the gnocchi she ordered and I had the best Caesar's Salad that I have ever had anywhere. Classic but with an injection of appropriate proprietary refinements.
Highly Recommended. Sleek design. Entering the permanent collection was breathtaking because the space was so pleasurable; an interesting and eclectic collection. Highly recommended.
Very interesting museum. If you enjoy art and have a couple of hours free then I can recommend visiting the MALBA. I have been there several times over the last six years and it is fascinating.
A must when in Buenos Aires. Like many modern museums in big cites architecturally beautifully designed and with an impressive collection of Latin-American modern art. Also beautiful surrounding

Good sample of Latin American Art. It is a place to see modern and contemporary art. Many different expressions of art while walking through different rooms: paintings, live figures, some music, etc. We were chased by a guy with a light panel in his face...!Interesting and worth the experience. Entrance fee: 100 Argentinian pesos.

First Rate Museum of Modern Art with Latin Perpective. This is not a huge collection. It is a wonderful collection. Looking at most of the schools of modern art, you see the "Latin American" version or translation. So, you can see the Argentinian artists version of Cubism, or Impressionism or Abstract Expressionism. What is so fascinating is the schools are clearly recognizable but the artists but have a consistent and different sensibility. Just looking at the Abstract Expressionism, the colors are more vibrant and freer. It's a wonderful collection that let's you rethink art and its expression through the Latin culture.

Doesn't Click with Us Either. While we always pop in when we are here in BA.....and always n a Wednesday for jubilados, when it is free.....we don't know what all the fuss is about.We were here this past Wednesday and the only exhibit was the permanent collection. We have our favorites: Frieda Kahlo, Diego Rivera,Xul Solar, and Berni.In fact, all 6-7 times we have been here......there was NEVER anything on the lower level.MALBA certainly has it's fans.......we are not two of them. There are MANY small museos in BA that truly bring us joy. The reason we continue to go back to the MALBA is always this thought: This time will be different. We'll become passionate.Different strokes for different folks!

Wonderful Museum. Although under renovation during our visit, the MALBA was still quite impressive. Their permanent collection is a wonderful collection of Late 19th- 21st century art featuring Frida Kahlo and Botero among many others. We also ate at the museum for lunch, which was delicious. Wonderful place for art enthusiasts!
Modern space worth a visit. Great museum with works of art by Frida Khalo. Modern space and inexpensive to get in. Definitely worth a visit.

I suppose its only for art lovers. After hearing so many good things about this place, I was excited to go. Firstly, I had heard numerous times that Wednesday was free days. Well it wasn't, at least not in March 2015. Anyways. I can usually get behind just about anything and enjoy it. But I felt like this place just wasn't clicking with me. I haven't been to many modern art museums (as in the time frame, not the style), and I just couldn't really get a lot of it. There was one piece that was two black squares on the wall. Anddd... that was the piece. If you enjoy art, I'm sure you'll love it. If you're a casual kinda person looking to spend a good afternoon... this might not be the place for you, as it wasn't for me.

Berni exhibit. We loved the exhibit of local artist Berni. Very complete collection as a whole and well curated. As an added plus the cafe is a nice place for a coffee before or after looking at the art.
Small but interesting. This small museum has mostly modern art by latino artists. It is fun and doesn't take too long to visit.
Take the opportunity and.... Great collection and after a relaxing visit if you go during the morning, try the restaurant. I found it very good.

Berní Prints And Paintings. The February 2015 exhibit I saw was mostly work by Berní, an Argentine who spent some time in Paris and gathered his thoughts about the exploitation of women and child poverty.Though his use of extremely detailed impressions of stamps on paper, including physical embossing of the canvas, he carries a strong message about the life of a woman dreaming to break the bonds of exploration. He names her Ramona. She is a prostitute who does menial jobs and prostitution to break out of her lowly status.He does something similar with the story of a child called Juanito who lives in a slum. He uses paintings and collection of refuse materials like oil cans and metal debris to speak of his poverty and dreams.Both his subjects are well developed, imaginative, carefully depicted with emotions and dreams.Be sure to start at the top floor of the exhibit to catch the proper sequence in his subject development.You will marvel at the detail of his embossed prints and the lace it produces on the garments or texture of woodwork and drapes depicted.It takes a while to see the genius developing in the work. But three dimensional sculptures made with refuse material to make up nightmarish creatures of the dreams of Juanito will pique your interest and motivate you to continue.This is not your conventional art exhibit but if you give it a chance, the talent and message of Berní and other argentines will come to life.There are no grand masters here but there is some more genius that is being portrayed.

Permanent collection very small. We went there the week where there were no temporary exhibits so we were limited to the permanent collection. The works were interesting but the tickets were expensive for just seeing the permanent collection.

Berni Exhibit. Loved everything about the Antonio Berni exhibit at the MALBA. It was well curated, and expansive (on all three floors of the museum). I anticipate this is similar for all temporary exhibits. They also had a lovely permanent collection, that appears to change frequently, which is a great way to see Latinamerican art!

A wonderful place to spend a few hours. At the time of our visit, the museum was presenting a retrospective of the work of Berni, Argentina's pride and joy. It was fabulous.The museum is well lit, and the exhibit was beautiful he curated. A wonderful plus – – they have an excellent restaurant and it is very pleasurable to have lunch there in the afternoon, either indoors or out.
Unique. Amazing collection of modern latinamerican art, unique taste, from ultra edgy masterpiece to must to know classics

MALBA. Smaller museum but had very good selection of Latin American art. i got to see some paintings I had only read about. Somme of the more modern art was a little unusual like three potatoes on a plate.

The home of Latin American modern art. Wonderful permanent collection and rotating exhibitions from Latin American artists. Well presented and easy to navigate, with just three floors. Check out the cinema and special workshops.

waste of time and money. Only one small Frida Kahlo and second grade art. BA is not an artistic paradise! There was only one floor open for viewing and the art was set up illogically. Lighting was poor.
