Pleasant Surprise. Paid 60 pesos for a ticket and another 80 pesos for the taxi from my hotel, and was very pleased. Nice collection (particularly surrealist). Beautiful building. Good way to spend indoors during a hot afternoon in Buenos Aires.

Malba. Small but very nice collection
Took me less than an hour to complete this including visit to gift shop

If you like modern art, this is the place. A beautiful modern building with contemporary and modern art of Latin America. There's a Kahlo, Rivera and Botero. The others I didn't know. When we visited only the first floor was open but that was quite large and an interesting visit. A cafe with indoor and outdoor dining.

Undewhelmed. Beautiful art work but need more displaced...Was in and out in under an hour..hopefully will have more artwork
when I visit again.
Architecturally interesting museum. This is worth a visit. The building is extremely visually appealing and the artwork is nicely displayed. Certainly, stop in here if you get the chance.

Berni. I actually went to Malba because I had heard that the Berni exhibition had been extended -initially it was going to close February 28. Unfortunately we were too late. Many of the important pieces of Modern/Contemporary Latin American art are either in te US or in Argentina but in private hands. It is always a treat when the Malba manages to exhibit works that only come out of the private owner's homes occasionally....

Not the biggest but great. Some interesting pieces in this museum, very vibrant too the very deep and meaningful, I suggest having a glass (or bottle) of wine in the museum bar after very good service
Quality art over quantity. Unless there is an exhibition there is not a lot to see. Definitely try and visit when they have a temporary exhibition on. The permanent stuff is only a couple of rooms.

Small but just right.. I like the small size of the museum, so I can spend an hour and a half and finish walking through the museum.It's not too overwhelming if you already got a busy day running around. The representative work of different well known artists are not most popular but make it more special since you don't see it everywhere. The overall quality of the art work is excellent and I did enjoy the visit.

Wonderful museum. Enjoyed the Antonio Berni "Juanito Y Ramona" exhibit from beginning to end!!! ... Loved it so much I immediately bought the giant size 400 page hardcover book from the museum store as I left!!!

Antonio Berni. It's a a more dynamic and modern museum than the National Museum of Bellas Artes (which lacks an interesting shop and provides no cafeteria - a serious mistake).The art of Antonio Berni provides a fascinating foray into two characters which epitomize the Argentinian way of life - Juanito and Ramona.

Very interesting. Great exhibits (Antonio Berni exhibition was on) in a really well laid out modern gallery with good facilities - lunch in the open air part of the museum restaurant was a pleasure as a start to our visit.

Good for introduction to Argentinian Artists. Nice building, well organized and excellent collection. There are permanent and occasional exposures. It's a very good sight for an introduciton to the argentinian artists and very close to parks.

If you know nothing re Latin American Art..... this is an OK spot. Building is attractive and well lit. Permanent exhibit lacks breadth. Better collections in L.A., NYC, Bilbao and Long Beach, CA. Temporary exhibit had just closed, so only one floor open.More positive reviews of restaurant than art!

Excellent!. Very small art gallery with rotating works from Argentine artist. We have visited 2 times in the last month to see two different artist. The cost is only 30 pesos to get in and you can spend hours reading and looking at amazing work. All the descriptions are in english and spanish.
Excellent!. Amazing place! Has different type of art, I liked how it's all organised into nice categories, spaces are big for appreciation. take your time, it's a big museum!
Nice. Interesting architecture...amazing collection of Argentinian artists' work. Freida Kahlo is the diamond in the collection.

amazing museum. we recently spent a morning here and fell in love with Antonio Berni's work. The permanent collection was interesting but the special exhibit blew us away. Sadly it is finished but if you can get the chance to see any of his work do so!

ANTONIO BERNI EXHIBITION. Before we went around the MALBA we had lunch in their very good restaurant -portions are large, which rather followed the size of the Berni paintings/ constructions. The Ramona series which details the lives of the hard done working class & girls of Argentina was mind blowing, colourful, funny & sad. But what a creative imagination for an artist I knew very little about. I assume when the exhibition finishes that paintings from the permanent collection will be put on show - as the Berni exhibition took up most of the rooms. Though I did see a fantastic Frida Kahlo -self portrait.Well worth a visit & the building / layout of the rooms is very good.

It's All About the Temporary Exhibits. Like many museums in South America, the MALBA relies mostly on temporary exhibits to fill the museum. The recent exhibit of Antonio Berni's collages of garbage to depict the daily lives of lower class Argentines was amazing and I would recommend it to anybody passing through Buenos Aires. However, the permanent collection is quite small, featuring a self-portrait by Frida Kahlo and a few other works from around Latin America. While I do think the Kahlo is worth seeing, it's not worth the admission price if the temporary exhibit isn't of interest. Before you go out of your way, check to see what the temp exhibit is.
Antonio Berni. Fabulous retrospective exhibition of one of the great Argentine painters sadly only open till Saturday.

High Impact!. For those who love art, especially famous artists, the MALBA packs a punch. I relatively new and open complex that was built for the purpose of displaying Latin American art all in one place that had been scattered about. With the originals by Frida, Solar, and Berni...to name a few.
not enough from permanent collection. show when we were there was technically interesting but repetitious. Their older Latin works are excellent
Great museum!. Fantastic exhibition Antonio Berni! The museum's architecture is beautiful. Nice restaurant to stop as well.

Fantastic!. A group of us visited MALBA back in January and were very impressed! The museum is spacious and airy, and the small shop is full of lovely things. The permanent collection contained some interesting work and a few key pieces (Khalo, Rivera) but the highlight was the uge Antonio Berni exhibition.

must see!. You could spend hours in this museum... depending on the collection.Antonio Berni is a particularly stunning artist– his style is unlike anything else, not only with his Ramona series, but also with the monsters he creates. Wonderful!The permanent collection seems to be fairly small, but well curated. There's a GORGEOUS piece by Remedios Varo on the second floor (I nearly spent 40 minutes admiring it before I realized I had to get going for a previous engagement).My only complaint is that, like many museums, there just aren't seats where you want them so you can sit and look at, or in my case, write about, the pieces that you really love!Beautiful museum, really.

Great collection. We were lucky enough to visit when they were showing the Antonio Berni collection - a really interesting Argentine artist. There is a small entrance fee but it is worth it. Alos a nice, resonably priced cafe with good food attached to the MALBA. Definitely worth a visit. Set in an interesting area with lots of embassies nearby.

Modern Latin American art; not very big. Beautiful museum in a very modern building. All Latin American artists & mostly from last 100 yrs. Because it is a new bldg, it is very accessible. Nice museum store.

An Amazing Surprise. The Art we saw here astounded us. For a quick hour look through we ended up spending triple the time. The main exhibition was inspiring with the use of recycling to form his collages. The building was a drawcard. Being on the local transport route system turned out to be a challenge when we came to return. A valued experience and an art lover's delight.
Antonio Berni.. I really liked the work of Antonio Berni. They made my day.The museum has also a very interesting collection of latin-american artistics from the 20th century.

A must for modern ethnic art. If you like modern art, and you like to see a south america perspective, dont miss this place. It's located near the Museo de Arte Plastico if you like the classics also.
good, select collection. the building is beautiful and the permanent collection is concise and interesting. The cafe is great for a coffee.

Small but good enough. This is a very interesting kind of small museum. The architecture is worth to mentions, and the art work they have is worth to be seen. It is a small museum, which is good, as sometimes you get tired of just walking around. So it takes the perfect timing without getting tired.
Very good lunch to accompany a very good gallery. Choice of seating. Quite posh, not so posh and outside. Great service, extensive menu.reasonable prices

Interesting So. American ideas. It was located on a major boulevard in a non-remarkable bright, very modern building. The few artists exhibited such as Antonio Berni, Luis Fernando Benedit & Juan Carlos Ditsefano are definitely unique in the art world by storytelling with multiple artworks. The art is organized into 5 clusters: Early moderns, avant-grade, art & politics, surrealism, & non figure art. The museum seem to be well lighted comfortable, and the artwork commented in both English & Spanish. Photography was allowed.
Malba Museum. The Malba Museum is an interesting place to visit in order to look at the public or private art collections. For those who knows this kind of places it is an obligatory visit to do.
Great collections. if you are fond of modern art and architecture, don't miss this museum.It also has a nice restaurant (not cheap!!) with delicious food
Great visit. An interesting museum of a latin american collection. Worth the visit. The museum's cafe reopened and is a good choice for lunch or tea.

Miss your flight if you like.. but don't miss this wonderful museum!!!. Malba is by no means a hidden gem in the heart of Buenos Aires. As you arrive at this very impressive building you will meet a fantastic array of Latin America Art which will not disappoint you. Exhibitions, reknown artists which have on many occasions visited the museum, the gift shop, the lively café, the Malba has it all. During the summer you can also join short courses which have been specially selected so that you may find something which will meet your interests. London has its Big Ben... Buenos aires has its Malba!!!
One of the greatest museums in South America. Great collection of pictures and scultures. Must see: Tarsila do Amaral pictures and Maria Martins O Impossivel gypsum, all white copy.

An easy museum visit without being overwhelming. I visited during the day on a week day and there was a decent crowd. The museum is small enough that you can easily see most of the places during a single visit and the lounge/restaurant is available for a cocktail afterwards. I loved the wooden bench that seems to grow like ivy through the museum. There are spanish and english descriptions for the art as well and you will definitely see some that you'll recognized. I was lucky enough to get to see the Julio Le Parc exhibition which was very cool and unique.
Dont waste time. Its so small and poor curated that even if they had all the famous artist on it it wouldn't be worth going. And that is a very big IF.
Very good museum!. We were lucky to see Antonio Berni's exhibit, it was wonderful! Very easy with children as well and great cafe!

Surpassed expectations. Wonderful modern art exhibited beautifully. The gallery is a perfect size to explore in a morning or afternoon, and MALBA restaurant is well worth a visit. Go on Wednesday for half-price entry.

Disappointing. We were disappointed by the display - too much focus on one artist's work, and too little variety in the rest of the art on show. If we understood correctly, only a percentage of the total art owned by the museum is on display, and perhaps, had we been able to see more of it, we would have enjoyed a greater range of artworks. The restaurant served us a delicious Caesar salad after advising us that our first choice (seafood) was not available on that day.

Very nice museum!. Went there in spring 2014 and were very lucky to see Mario Testino's IN YOUR FACE exhibition - a gem you can currently see in Berlin. Anyway, they had a vast amount of other amazing art and it was definitely worth the visit!

Loved this gem of a museum. This museum boasts beautiful airy modern architecture and a fun collection of Latin American art. It was very affordable. We had lunch in the cafe there which was fabulous. Highly recommended.

Wonderful art!. Beautiful artwork, with some really unique amazing pieces, paintings, and sculptures. Wonderful museum, and it's definitely a must see if you appreciate art, and end up exploring Buenos Aires!

Fantastic insight into Argentinian culture. We found the special exhibit of Antonio Berni, truly astounding. This place knows how to stage an exhibition and put art and the artist into context and perspective.

Berni exhibit was amazing!. I knew nothing of Berni, an Argentine artist, before our visit, but the extensive exhibit of his work was mezmerizing, meaningful and moving. The museum itself is roomy & open, and the exhibits of other artists' work were also most interesting. A fine modern art collection, and we take in the local modern art museums wherever we can!

Berni at Malba Buenos Aires. this is a great Museum replete with Latin American art masterpieces well chosen well curated when I visited a week ago the exhibition of Berni was on view a retrospective an eye opener to me since had only seen and viewed a few of his works prior to this retrospective. The Museum is so well run and it is a pleasure to visit it also has an excelleent restaurant which this time did not go to due to lack of time and a lovely gift shop to browse and acquire gifts to take back home not to be missed on your next trip to Buenos Aires.it is also located next to the Alcorta Shopping Center easy transportation is available as well as taxis ..
A Must.... Not only is this a beautiful museum with a wonderful restaurant but we had the privilege of viewing the show of Antonio Berni. Magnificent!

a small but impressive collection. the art was really good! I especially liked the challenge of creating fictional characters over time thru art. Delesio Antonio Berni did this incredibly well with his character Juanito. I liked his collages better than painted art.

Great space and we were there for a superb exhibition. Lovely modern building with excellent exhibition of works by Berni while we were there. Restaurant lunch expensive and not good value in my opinion,.
Wonderful. A great museo with wonderful curation. Beautiful and easy to get around. It is small but very good. Bueno.
A real find. The Antonio Berni exhibit wowed us, and the restaurant lunch was excellent. We had not heard of him but were quite impressed with his work.

Specialists in Latin American Art. The Museum is a must for visitors to Buenos Aires. Ina convenient Location on Avenida Libertador, it has an excellent collection of Latin American Art, including - for example - a Frida Kahlo. Antonio Berni Juanito and Ramona fantastic exhibition at MALBA. I have visited the MALBA museum several times before, but this visit was primarily to see a special exhibition “Antonio Berni – Juanito Y Ramona” of the work of famous Argentinean figurative artist, Delesio Antonio Berni [14 May 1905 – 13 October 1981]. I was really glad I went!The MALBA museum was inaugurated in 2001 with about 230 Latin American art pieces that were in a private collection and up to that point spread out in different places. Through the support of the friends of the museum and the government, today the collection is over 550 pieces and is very worthwhile to see. In addition, MALBA does offer some spectacular special exhibitions on a regular basis. Currently, and till March 1, 2015, there is an extensive exhibition of the art of Antonio Berni. Antonio Berni is one of Argentina’s prominent artists. He was born in Rosario, Argentina in 1905. In 1925 he received a scholarship to study art in Paris, France where several fellow Argentinean artists were working, including Xul Solar and Aguiles Badi. By 1928 he became involved with revolutionary politics. He returned to Argentina in 1931 and began his Neo-realism move, painting images depicting the struggle of Argentinean people in that decade. He responded to the political upheavals and instability of Argentina in the 40s and 50s, with a large number of political paintings including such famous ones as Masacre [Massacre] and El Obrero Muerto [The dead worker]. Beginning in the late 50s, the figures of a small boy “Juanito Laguna” and a small girl “Ramona Montiel” began to appear in Berni’s work, showing the struggle and difficulties facing small children as they grew up in Argentina at that time of industrialization and political instability. “Juanito Laguna” comes from the poor outskirts of a big city [any big city] while “Ramona Montiel” comes from the slums of a big city. In the 60s, Berni began to tell the stories of Juanito and Ramona, as they grew up, in his art work in the form of collages, oil paintings, sculptures and installations, in which marginality and misery acquired faces and names. Berni collected samples of the garbage accumulated around the slums to be used as material describing Juanito’s World. Ramona’s story accompanied Juanito’s and through her, Berni displayed another world of misery and exploitation [prostitution, power, sex and hypocrisy] that of Ramona.Berni’s work “Juanito Y Ramona” was exhibited around the world in the USA, Europe, Japan and Latin America. There are about 150 pieces of work in that exhibition, covering the period from the 50s to the 70s and showing the origins, the lives and the development of the two figures. It is shown on three levels at the museum.It is truly worth visiting, along of course with the permanent exhibition. You may also be interested in the movies that the museum offers on Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays [consult starting times at the museum or on its web site]. I did not yet go this year, but I was lucky enough last year to see some very interesting movies such as “Cornelia frente al espejo” [Cornelia in front of the mirror] by the Argentine writer Silvina Ocampo. I hope you enjoy the permanent selection, the special exhibition and if you can some of the movies as well. Please note that MALBA is closed on Tuesdays [instead of Mondays like the other Museums of Buenos Aires] .

A Must See!. The building itself is wonderful; the exhibits were breathtaking, as well! We even took time to have a bite at the restaurant, which was fabulous, too!

First class structure with interesting collection.. On a family vacation we spent a couple of days in Buenos Aires. Because most of us are interested in art we visited a number of museums. Wednesday cheaper and bring your Samsung smartphone. Wednesday is cheaper and if you bring your Samsung smartphone it is 2x1. The exhibition is fantastic in a modern spotless building. Very bright and good explanations. Atm is a brilliant berni exhibition on display.

Fun Art. We enjoyed the subject matter and style of art, well worth a visit. Was both silly and profound. Great use of various materials to create the desired effects.

At least most is really art. This is a beautiful building, both outside (where its clean geometric lines and shapes capture the eyes immediately, and inside (where the exhibition space allows the artwork to be vividly exhibited and effortlessly accessed by a series of escalators and elevators. It also has a restaurant offering some of the finest lunches and snacks in the city (no meals after 4 pm, although the museum is usually open until 9 pm.), but the prices can be a bit steep.To call it a museum of Latin-American Art is as much a half-truth as the pronouncements that have flowed from Argentine politicians over the years, not least the current presidential incumbent. I counted 6 paintings by 6 recognized non-Argentinian artists (Lam, Matta, Kahlo, Rivera, Botero and Sequeiros), although there are others of which the majority of even the most assiduous art-lovers will be quite unaware . If you come here at all, it will have to be for the food, or for the paintings by contemporary Argentine artists. For me (but not for everybody), these are two adequate reasons. I was truly seduced once again (my 2nd visit in 8 years) by the freshness, dynamism, creative use of shape and colour, and most of all by the honesty and humanity of the artists represented in this collection, compared with the shallow fakery and contrivance that characterize much work out of Europe and N. America since the beginning of the 20th Cent. Here are a few of the artists, previously unknown, that especially impressed me: Sergio Camargo, Emilio Pettorutti, Joaquin Torres Garcia, Xul Solar, Jose Gurvich and Kenneth Kemble. But most of all, because a Special Exhibition of his work took up 3 of the museum’s 4 floors, was Antonio Berni. His early work in the Permanent Collection was dramatic “social realism” straight from the heart of someone who truly cares, and was executed in the larger-than-life style of Rivera’s murals. This exhibition comprised about 100 very large paintings devoted to two specific characters he has created: Juanito (a young boy from the slums), and Ramona (a gorgeous – looking courtesan on the make). They are built up from collages, metal, earth, plaster and paint using a technique that is as breathtaking as the finished product. For me, he is the greatest artist the continent has yet produced.  Regrettably, in more recent times, here as elsewhere, “art” now takes the form of slashing a piece of canvass, or covering it monochromatically like a house-painter, or filling infinitely precious space with mixed rubbish to create what is called, with awe and respect, an “installation”.

Good museum, but depends on what you want out of it. I enjoyed my visit to the museum, but if you are looking for a large museum with tons of art, this may not be for you. The museum had curated art in a way that over 50% was from a specific artist trying to show the evolution of his work over time. The rest did show more Latin American art over the past 2 centuries, but its not an extensive collection like you may have in other large cities. Overall, worth going to.

Such an awesome museum!. I really enjoyed MALBA - it was one of the highlights of Buenos Aires for me. It is also in such a nice neighborhood. The art was beautiful, the grounds are lovely. It is a nice place for all ages. The cafe is also a nice place to sit and have a coffee. The food looked really good, though we didn't eat there.

Reminded me of the J Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles. The architecture of the museum is quite stunning and though much smaller, the airiness of the rooms reminded me slightly of the Getty Museum in Los Angeles. I thoroughly enjoyed the few items of the regular collection that were on display including the Freda Carlo. There was an exhibition being staged "Antonio Berni, Juanito y Ramona" which was fascinating and made me realize that for me, art must be at least fun to experience or make me think. This museum provided both. Well worth a visit. If you are a pensioner, take proof age on the expensive days- you can get in at half price.

Fascinating Art. Despite our preference for more classical art, our Buenos Aires guide encouraged us to see this contemporary museum. It was amazing; extremely interesting and creative works were well-displayed.
Interesting and contemporary.. I expected lots of old Latin American paintings but was impressed to find a wealth of contemporary, quirky and interesting exibits. They allow you to take photos too.

Interesting museum - worth a visit. Interesting museum which is currently showing an exhibition of Antonio Berni. It is a relatively small museum though with 3 levels - 2 1/2 of which are dedicated to the Berni exhibition. It would have been nice to have a larger portion dedicated to the permanent collection. $30 peso admission fee with a free cloakroom. A nice diversion for an hour or so on a rainy day. Within walking distance to Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes and Recoleta cemetery.
nice museum. not a huge collection displayed, but the museum is quite beautiful. What we did see was well displayed and interpreted - in both spanish and english. Nice restaurant too.

way above expectation. Stunning building in the modern gallery style. With a permanent collection of latino americano(mostly argentinian) art. But the temporary exhibition on presently was fabulous- the works were a 'rakes progress" following the lives of a shanty town boy and a prostitute in a way that symbolised the changes in Argentina.
Interesting, as far as it went.... Beautiful building, good traffic flow, interesting exhibits. 3 galleries on 3 floors was just enough for my non-artsy companion.

Superb. We went there not expecting too much but were pleasantly surprised by the architecture of the building and the excellent exhibit on Berni. The explanation on the exhibit was conveniently located before the rooms themselves where one could sit down and read all the information leisurely and comfortably. This is very well thought out. In addition, the works were set out in such a way that, even though there were a few people present, one could view the paintings or sculptures unhindered by other viewers. We came out of the visit with a smile on our faces.

WAS GLAD I GOT OFF THE TOUR BUS!. As our City Tour Bus passed by MALBA, I decided to get off and visit this beautiful museum. After paying the entrance fee (30 Argentine Pesos or about US $4) and leaving my backpack with the staff, I started my visit on the second floor.Each room has beautiful art works, very fancy and modern to my taste. I took pictures of those that fascinated me (See attached pictures). I smiled when I saw again some of the paintings on exhibit that I 'd seen before during my visit of certain museums in Mexico. There are more exhibits at the lower level of the museum which I also enjoyed seeing. Be sure to include this museum in your list of attractions to see when you visit Buenos Aires. I was glad I did!

Best museum we saw in BA. The museum was well organized and is inside an awesome building full of natural light. There was information plaques in english and the admission was so cheap. Maybe $50 pesos, like 6 dollars. A very manageable museum, can be done in an hour. The gift shop was super cool, check it out. Also the museum cafe served a great steak and a huge and ymmy fruit plate.
Grouchy staff. The museum was fantastic and the current exhibition of Antonio Berni is amazing. The staff are rude, dismissive and sour. They "guards" seem miserable.

MALBA's Collection Impressive. A great museum, which had an excellent exhibit of Bernini's social realism. This exhibit alone made the museum well worth the visit. It is one of the best museums int e city.

Good Exhibit. Visiting this museum was a great opportunity to learn about the work of Antonio Berni, in that sense, it was a very rich experience. Being him from Argentina, and by the quality of his amazing work, it is an very interesting and joyful experience to visit the exhibit. However, I must say I was expecting more from the Museum.Being the Museum of Latin American Art, I expected to see more artists from all over Latin America not just Brazil, Mexico, Argentina and its closest neighbors.It is however I great place to visit while being in Buenos Aires.

Superb museum. Went to exhibition of Antonio Berni works - stunning , powerful and moving. Museum is in a modern building, light and airy and houses a wide range of fascinating art works. Highly recommended

I expected more. Almost all of our friends told us - don't miss Malba, it is an excellent museum. We have been there and it is nice, but nothing outstanding. The paintings are very impressive (specially involving Tarsilla do Amaral and Antonio Berni) but the museum is very small (you don't need more than 1 hour or 1,5 hour there). I mean, it is very nice, but you can't compare to great museums such as the Prado (Madrid) or the Louvre (Paris).

Interesting collection, fabulous exhibits. Contemporary architecture sets the stage for viewing the collection of contemporary Latin American art, though it's "one of everyone" mix could use more depth. A fabulous exhibit more than made up for it. And don't forget the gift shop! In addition to a book annex, the main shop has shop terrific jewelry!

Rich collection!. It attracted me by having on its collection tha "Abaporu", as brazilian citizen, I was really impressed by this painting and for being in Argentina. The whole collection is amazing and everyone should spend at least two hours appreciating.

Nice museum and not too massive!. The collection at MALBA was nice and the Museum doesn't take hours upon hours to go through so it's a nice afternoon activity. What I really found wonderful was the museum store which carried some rather interesting books and collective pieces - as well as the restaurant on the first floor where one can sit in the garden.

Very interesting Berni exhibit. Major exhibit on Berni's work focusing on Juanito and Ramona, 2 recurrent characters which appear in many of his works. Many of these works are made of discarded/ recycled materials. Good discussion in both Spanish and English. Also exhibit/discussion of his innovative printmaking methodology which involved raised almost papier-mâché like materials. Attached cafe is supposed to be excellent. Wished we had stopped there. Virtually no restaurants on the walk back tto the Centro. MALBA's owner's house as well as quite a few embassies are nearby to the right as you face the museum.

MALBA is a must see. I always go to at least one museum in a new city but this trip was able to hit 3 during my stay in Buenos Aires...the Museum of Fine Arts, The Eva Peron Museum and MALBA. MALBA was by far the best with a wonderful exhibit of the works of Berni. The setting is well conceived and it is an easy, bright environment to see some gorgeous art! Don't miss it!

Great museum. Located in a very nice neighborhood in Buenos Aires and in a beautiful building, MALBA is a mandatory visit in the city. The staff is very polite and helpful. Don't forget to check "Abaporu".

Great Berni Exhibit. Impressive art museum set up by private foundation. extensive Latin American art collection, beautifully presented. Worth the visit. Nice simple cafe restaurant with outdoor terrace on ground level.

Beautiful museum with some really great art. A terrific modern art museum in a beautiful building, a stunning display all by itself. We enjoyed a very nice and reasonably priced (for the location) lunch in the café, with very good service.

Beautiful Building and great cafe. Absolutely pouring so had coffee and cake in the excellent cafe till the museum opened. There was an Antonio Berni exhibition - Juanito and Ramona - really amazing work - a lot of it collages made from rubbish. Lovely building

Berni was a discovery. This is a modern art museum which houses a permanent collection of Latin American Art, and it has special exhibits. We were very lucky to run into an exhibit of Berni, an Argentinian artist ( 1905- 1981), which was shown on all three floors. It was an overview of his entire oevre, very impressive!"At the beginning, the Argentinean Antonio Berni captured the anxiety of unemployed or oppressed laborers. A couple of years later, his vision converged on shantytowns (villas miseria), where his famous figures Juanito Laguna and Ramona Montiel represent poverty and inequity. He is one of the masters of Latin American political art and undoubtedly the most renowned and most relevant one of Argentina." (www.arslatina.com)
Great museum. Gives you a very good sense of Latin American Art. The Berni exhibit is fabulous. And, the cafe is great.
Easy to navigate. The museum has special exhibits as well as its permanent collection. All was easy to see and enjoy. A café attached was a delightful finish.
great museum, not to miss!. todo, beautiful cafe and exhibitions, nice for a hot day or friends activity.One of the most importan Latin American´s collection in SA
Nice art. Pleasantly different. Authentic museum of Latin America. Close to teh center and the walking distance to recoletas

An excellent Museum. The museum is small and limited but the pieces in their permanent modern collection are excellent. We saw an exhibit featuring the work of Antonio Berni. It was incredible and very well presented. The exhibit included videos explaining many features that would not have been evident from the artwork. Descriptions were in English so even us mono-lingual Americans could appreciate it. 2-3 hours is a good time to spend. The restaurant was overpriced.

A must see. It's always worth to visit MALBA!They have changing exhibitions of different artists as well as the permanent exhibition on the first floor with a lot of latinamerican artists.There's also a cinema on the ground floor where they show mostly on thursday-sunday classics from throughout the world.On wednesday entrance is half price to the exhibition.Bring along a sweater/jacket due to temperature differences inside/outside in argentinian summer.

Spain and it's former colonies. Every thing in the museum shows the similarity, and at the same time the difference between the art of Spain and the Latin American countries, each Latin American country has it's own different nuance, and unique feeling.

Nice modern museum. Not bad to mix up your trip. MALBA was inexpensive and a good break in our week trip to BA. The museum was 3 floors featuring several different artist. Most of the work was from the 1950's and up.

Attractive facility with fantastic collection. We so enjoyed this terrific museum with a huge collection, and what was on display covered the great art of Latin America across the decades. We so enjoyed the Antonio Berni show, with his Ramona and Juanito series...fascinating wood blocks and collages reflecting the hardships of many women and poor children in Argentina...also MALBA has a small but well stocked gift shop...of all of the museums in BA, this seems the place to visit.

A Nice Approach to Latin American Art. MALBA is a place to visit if you are in BsAs.The Collection is very nice and well displayed. Special Exibitions like Antonio Berni and Andy Warhol were remarkable.Some expressive paintings from Leon Ferrari, Frida Khalo and Diego Rivera, the super important modernist masterpiece from Tarsila do Amaral, Abapuru, and relevant cinetic art from Julio Le Parc, Cruz-Dies are the highlights from the collection.The buiding is also amazing. Staff is not nice at all. Both in the shop (which is small and super limited) and in the cafe/restaurant (overpriced), people seem to be making you a huge favor.

ok--the permanent collection is the best. I was expecting a lot more from this museum, particularly given its spectacular architecture. The permanent collection has several remarkable works, but he rotating exhibit during our visit was repetitive and, while the artist has clear artistic gifts, didactic in theme and portrayal.We also lunched at the cafe which was mediocre. Kind of grossed me out to see the waiters just rub used wine glasses with a towel prior to using them for a new guest.
For art lovers. This is a must-to-visit place for modern art lovers. I enjoyed every piece of art in the exhibition of Antonio Berni .
very impressive. I was not expecting to see such an amazing collection of Latin American Art as I did at MALBA. A must see!
Stylish and small. MALBA is a good take for a quick taste of Latin American art. It is a modest sized museum that can be visited in 1-2 hours. Fun even for those who aren't art buffs!

Amazing museum of latin american art. The MALBA is a great museum with very interesting exhibitions and artworks. The building is modern and interesting and the exhibition curating is very good. Until the 23rd of February 2015 it hosts the exhibition Juanito y Ramona by Antonio Berni, which has been one of the most interesting exhibitions I have seen. It is a must see for every art and history lover who visits Buenos Aires, with the artwork initially inspired from the social and economical history of recent Argentina and later inspiring tango songs.
Outstanding Museum of Argentinian Art. Size was easy to manage. Terrific exhibits. Easily accessible. Enlightening view of national art and artists.
wonderfull. it was a very nice experience because they had an Exposition of Frida Kahlo and it is very different to see those paitings and art in another Country.

Shame it is not free, but top visit...not to miss. Malba is probably the most dynamic and interesting museum in Buenos Aires. It is fresh, contemporary, creative. Focus on the permanent collection of Latin American artists, very good and well researched, and then enjoy the temporary shows on the different floors. A very well worth visit to do by yourself, friends, family. Recommended.
Good collection. The museum has a good collection of latim american art and modern architectural style with excellent taste

Enjoyable Art Museum for everyone. The museum was great for several reasons. It is air conditioned and so refreshing after walking in from the sometimes hot and humid BA streets. We loved the Berni exhibit was captivating and the English translations were informative. The size of the museum was not overwhelming as some can be. It is easy to take in the whole museum in a couple hours then enjoy the museum cafe afterwards for lunch or a snack. Overall, a good experience and shouldn't be missed.

Not Run of the Mill. When we were there, we saw a very interesting exhibit of art reflecting the daily life of a boy in a poorer quarter of the city and a young woman' choices as she seeks to live her dreams. The pieces in all the galleries were nicely mounted, and we enjoyed our afternoon.

Not My Cup of Tea. There was one Botero and one Frida Kahlo. The rest of the museum was pretty much dedicated to the Antonio Berni Juanito y Ramona exhibition, which was not my cup of tea. If you don't like Antonio Berni, skip this museum until February 23, when the exhibition ends...
Enjoyable even for a non-art buff. Not an artist or particularly savvy art connoisseur, but the exhibits were detailed and had English translations and information. Would recommend.
A MUST for anyone. Very wonderful display of permanent and also momentarily exhibits.A beautifully arranged coffee / bar / restaurant to go before or afterwards

Beautiful architecture. The museum itself is worth visiting for its architecture, considering it was originally designed to host a private collection. The current exhibition (Jan 2015) is not very strong though.

good enough. unplanned visit to restaurant after visiting the museum,service and cleanliness not so good, but the food wasexcellent, quality,portion,presentation. not cheap but worth every cent. highly recommend despitethe fact that floors and windows were not very clean, thesilverware,glassware,linens were fine.usually very busy, good if you have time, not for a quick meal.
Only in BA. this museum is a perfect scale - you can do the whole thing in 2 hours - and unique in that it has only Latin American artists. Great space with a lot of natural light.

A unique collection in a very attractive setting.. Although this museum is not very large (a plus if you are bringing children along), its permanent collection is a rich selection of many latin american artists important pieces. This winter had also a rather interesting Berni exhibit featuring his Ramona and Juanito pieces. The exhibit not only showed the art itself, with engaging narratives, but also provided insights into how Berni created and later enhanced his unique technique of 3d printing/collage. It was a very interesting experience with many aspects, artistic, intellectual, as well as0 historical and sociological. Very very nice!The building itself is very nice, with a very attractive cafeteria and garden. The neighborhood is also a very nice area for walking before and after the museum.

Great museum, and try to catch the Berni exhibit while it's there. If the rotating exhibit is good, this is a world class museum. We saw the Ramona and Juanito exhibit in January and loved the manageable size and layout of building. The entry works out to less than $3 USD.
We love the culture. We have visited the malba and the exposition of Berni. very interesting and beautiful museum . Nice to visit it !

Amazing experience - not to be missed. Was fortunate to visit during the special exhibition of art by Antonio Berni of his Romana and Juanito series of works - paintings, collages, models/sculpture, which were astonishing in their portrayal of the lives of two fictitious characters growing up in poverty in Buenos Aires.There were also some wonderful paintings among the regular collection.Our guide book said that entry was free on Wednesdays but this is only for people over 65 with proof of age. For others visiting on Wednesday, entry is half-price though it would have been worth paying the full price to see the special exhibition.

Magnificent Museum. If you only visit one art gallery in Buenos Aires make it this one. A beautiful space with some stunning exhibits, and regularly changing exhibitions. Easy to find, cheap to enter and not to be missed.
Amazing museum. Worth it to see Berni's exhibition Juanito y Ramona. Absolutely amazing. Really interesting museum overall, nice garden cafe!
A diamant in the city. We enjoyed this museum very much especially the Antonio Berni exposition. (Juanito & Ramona)We liked the restaurant too. Interesting building.
Very Nice!. Very refreshing and enjoyable atmosphere to experience modern and latinamerican art. This is another place that deserves a second and third visit.

Political art with a sense of humor.. We loved this museum (and liked its restaurant too). Even the benches are artistic: the slats of one dissolve into vine-like extensions that climb over the rail, swirl around the walls and then resolve into another bench on the next floor. A lot--but certainly not all--of the art we saw was political, and a lot was also quite funny, enough that we sometimes laughed aloud. Had a great time, as did the people around us.
Excellent outdoor restaurant.. This museum is about contemporary South American art. The current exhibit very interesting but only runs to March 2015. Not too big. Worth a visit.

Great Latin american art museum. Beautiful building, great collection. Had a great Verni retrospective when we visited. Most of the best Latin American painters are included here. Also good movies and restaurant.

A building with lovely light. This collection in housed in a beautiful building. The light and space feel magical. The galleries are nicely set up and the installations are well-thought-out. The book shop is very strong.

Interesting. We happened to visit the museum when they had a special exhibition on the work of Antonio Berni, very interesting. The premanent collection exhibited was, therefore, very limited. The building is nice.

Excelent place to visit in Buenos Aires. It's rare to see a museum dedicated only to Latin-American art, and this one honors the name. In a modern building, Malba has a permanent collection, although big names such as Osvaldo Guayasamín (Ecuador) are missing. Besides, it always provides very interesting temporary exhibitions. On Wednesdays the ticket is half the price and for teaches and students is free.

Very nice and modern museum. This is for sure the best museum to visit in Buenos Aires. Be ready for a line and arrive right for opening hours or even before. It's better to be there earlier also because the museum is getting more and more crowded (especially on raining days). There's a permanent display of famous 20th century latin american artists including one Frida Kahlo painting. Probably this is the reason why many people go there and it's really worth seeing it. And there is always a temporary display of an artist. We saw brilliant and wide Antonio Berni's artworks.

Excellent gallery, crap website. This gallery has a smallish permanent collection that nevertheless includes some masterpieces (including a Frieda Kahlo that's probably the highlight), but currently has a superb exhibition of work by Antonio Berni, who I must admit I'd never heard of, but I loved his series of Juanito and Ramona paintings, collages and prints. The museum website http://www.malba.org.ar/ looks lovely, but had no information on when they were open/closed over Christmas and doesn't have anything findable on the Berni exhibition (on til February) except via a fleeting link on the home page.It's possibly the only museum in the world that's closed on Tuesdays
Great Museum with Latin American Art. A great museum to spend 60 - 90 minutes. Beautiful setting with great art set in an appealing lay-out. A must see in BA.
World class. Superb collection. Contemporary Latin American Art. Arte Concreta. Grupo Madi. Nice Cafe. Nice bookstore. Excellent cinemateca.Worth a visit.

Superb museum and very good restaurant. MALBA is one of the top attractions (at least in terms of museums) in Buenos Aires. The content is largely modern art (although there is a separate modern art museum in the city). The museum includes both paintings and sculptures set in a lovely modern building. It also houses a restaurant , which is far more than a cafeteria and deserves a separate listing. In fact, the restaurant is reason enough (if you ever needed one) to justify a visit.

One of the 2 best museums in Buenos Aires. The building itself is incredibly interesting. I was there when they had an Antonio Berni exhibit which was absolutely amazing. They also had other Latin American art which was wonderful to see. This is a must for any serious art lover. Gave a great overview of Latin American art.

Antonio Berni. What a great exhibition! And the museum's permanent collection is good, as well, though the industrial art is not always my favorite. I only wished they were as good at marketing their museum through their gift shop! I would have loved magnets of some of the paintings, or some other easy trinket to remember the visit by.
Best Musem in BA. For me, the best museum of Buenos aires. Nice paintings. The architecture is very modern. It is a must go in while in the city.

Berni Exhibition through Feb 2015. First of the all the museum itself is beautiful. With light streaming in from every direction, multiple floors and an outside area off of a higher floor - it is impressive before seeing one work of art.I thoroughly enjoyed he Berni exhibit. The way it was laid out was very thoughtful, taking you through the times of the artist's fictional characters amidst the changing geographical and political backdrops of Buenos Aires.You can go with a guide, listen or just peruse at your leisure. We did the latter and it was a great opportunity after we left to sit outside on one of the benches, watch everyone go by the usual business of the day and soak in the city.The leather in the gift shop was very close to going in my shopping bag but I wanted to hit the street fair on a Sunday. That didn't end happen and of course, I now lust after the bags not bought :(Put this on your BA to-do list. Based on their gorgeous layout, attention to flow and friendly staff, you will not be disappointed, no matter what exhibition is there.

Do Not Miss the Berni Exibition. We went to the MALBA to see the permanent collection. We were interested to see the contemporaries of Frida & Diego. But the Berni exhibition was extraordinary & we felt very lucky to have been in B.A. while it was being shown.
My Favorite museum. My favorite museum so far in Buenos Aires. They have amazing and unique art exhibitions. very much recommended
A must-see experience. Well set out and varied displays. We had both visual and audio experiences. Good restaurant/cafe with excellent service. receptionists were excellent.

Modern art comes alive at MALBA.. The vibrant pulse of Latin American art is alive and well at MALBA.Definitely include a visit when you are in Buenos Aires! You'll be glad you did. The galleries are well laid out, and spacious. The variety of art mediums is considerable. Nice gift shop too.
Great place to spend a rainy day. Interesting collection. Smaller than I expected, but home to some iconic pieces. Learned a lot about South American modern art.
Antonio Berni's exhibit amazing. We loved the Berni exhibit featuring Juanito Laguna and Ramona. A beautiful museum and a great exhibit but just a so so gift shop.

Excellent museum!. I am usually not one for another boring art museum but the MALBA was really good. They had an exhibit called "Juanita y Ramona" that told a story on each level of the building. Very interesting and well done, the art is different, which I liked a lot. Definitely not your average art museum

An Exciting Look at Modern Art. We wish we had more time to spend at Malba. Architecturally the space is dramatic, but the size allows you to see everything and not feel overwhelmed. For art lovers, this is a must.
excellent exhibition. good permanent collection and the Antonio Berni exhibition Juanito y Ramon was fascinating. Very well presented.

Always Enjoyable. This is probably my fifth visit to the MALBA. And I always enjoy it.
And this time was no exception.
The Antonio Berni exhibition is fantastic. I especially like the series on the lowest floor of Juanito.
The permanent collection very good as well.
Catch the Berni show exhibition. It is on until Feb 23/15
A Great Museum Structure. A really lovely building with excellent exhibits of Latin American art as well as a permanent collection
Must see. The museum is very beautiful. The Berni exhibit is absolutely spectacular. There is no need for a tour the signage is in English.
OK but not great. Spent an afternoon here, the building and layout was very nice but the artwork was mostly not to my taste.

Nice Museum. The museum is in a beautiful building and the art is very interesting. You will recognize some famous works in the permanent collection and the Bernie exhibit on display is superb, mixing all sorts of mediums and very indicative of Latin American style. The admission price is very cheap (compared to American standards) and there is a nice cafe where you can sit outside before or after your visit.

fabuluous exhibit. MALBA has a fabulous exhibit of Antonio Berni's 'Juanito and Ramona' series apparently there until February. His creative ways of depicting the lives and 'choices' of the poor in Argentina is simply stupendous.

A modern And magnificent museum in Buenos Aires. If you like modern latinamerican art, the MALBA is the place to go in BA.I can not say the same for the restaurant, is dirty, expensive and the serve the coffe cold!
Go!. Important art works as the best museums in Europe. Cultural center well organized and prepared for long visits. Visit that should not be missed .
antonio Berni. very beautifull modern museum with nice natural light open spaces and strong work , super bookstore amzing exhibition of Antonio Berni
Amazing art. the Berni exhibition was amazing. Wonderful sculptural paintings and collages, three dimensional pieces made using found objects, fabulous portrayals of the times. Not to be missed!

Pleasant afternoon. Just grab lunch in the restaurant and enjoy the art.
Such a great selection of art work. Great atmosphere, although it is small and it is not the type of "get lost museum" , the latin american culture is really shown in this museum. There are not only paint but also sculpture. Great place to go.

Gorgeous Museum. MALBA is a beautiful modern building, with a very welcoming atmosphere. It was free, as was the other B.A. museum we went to, and the exhibition was wonderful. Antonio Berni's prints featuring the invented lives of Ramona and Juanito were just amazing. Many are quite large and the "taco" or plate the print was made from is hung beside the print. It's fascinating to see them both together. I wanted to return for a second view but there was just too much else to do. If you see only one B.A. museum, this is the one.

Great little museum. Impressive collection of Latin American Art. Currently exhibiting Antonio Berni a local Argentinian artist who was very prominent in the mid 20th century. Incredible works of art. The whole museum can be seen in about an hour or two.

must see for art lovers. Some of the most unique and interesting art I have seen for a while. I love visiting art exhibitions, but I am no expert. This really was one of my top sights in BA. Highly recommend.

modern museum. wonderful way to learn some South American history while enjoying Argentina! We especially liked viewing the painting and art while listening to our daughter, a Latin American history major studying abroad in BA.

Art Museums. I went to this museum twice over the summer with my 20 year old daughters. We all loved it! Being from the NYC area I felt this had a more relaxed atmosphere and viewing the art was very enjoyable and unrestricted experience.

Very nice museo. I had a really good time at this museum. I read several reviews and have to say I agree with the positive ones. The exhibit was very nice and the entry fee was reasonable. A very nice, modern, well-done museum.
Worth a visit. Really an interesting exhibit of Latin American art here. Mostly paintings. The building is also very beautiful. Glad we went and saw it on a rainy day in BA.
Nice Manageable Art Museum. Real enjoyed my visit here. The architecture alone is interesting and the exhibits when we were there facinating. It's small and focussed, which I appreciate.

The best contemporary museum in Buenbos Aires. MALBA is the better art attraction in Buenos Aires. The permanent collection is one of the best in Latin America and the temporary exhibitions have international standards. There are always space for emerging artists too. The incredible building, an international award, also deserves the visit. MALBA has also a beautiful store and a very good cafe and restaurant.
Great Escape into Modern Art. Great collection of latin american art in a modern open space. A must go to when in BA- and onward to the Japanese gardens for lunch

One of the best. Every time we go to Buenos Aires we visit the MALBA and found a very selected exhibition with a lot of taste and usually very unique. the local is magnificent in a very good location, easy to get a taxi
Wonderful collection. Not a huge collection but a very good one and not to be missed. The building is also quite impressive.

Worth a visit or two. One of the newest museums in B.A., with a very good collection of Latin American Art, unlike the Fortabat museum which is a little inconsistent. The temporary exhibitions are always superlative and if the gift shop could do with a little more variety, the restaurant is quite good.
MALBA. This museum is wonderful - very accessible, beautiful, and the art is wonderful. A definite highlight of our time in Buenos Aires.
Fantastic Museum!. A must-go in Buenos Aires, great architecture, great artists, even good rare films to see. Nice cafeteria, too.
A Must.... This museum of LatAm art is a beautiful place to visit. Lovely modern architecture, excellent permanent exhibition, lovely area. The restaurant: very good food, rather expensive prices!

World Class Art. Do not miss MALBA experience!
Amaizing latín american art collection, a museum that Porteños are prod of.

Love the Brunch. We had a nice Sunday brunch in their cafe where many locals were enjoying afternoons with their parents/grandparents. This was a manageable museum for the afternoon where we saw an interesting exhibit by a local artist Antonio Berni (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antonio_Berni) following two fictional characters 'Ramona y Juanito' as they grew up there through the realities of life coming from the country to Buenos Aires.

Even our 4-year-old enjoyed it. The museum is very nicely planned, the exhibits are just enough to get you full museum experience and not too overwhelmed by it, just a little more would be exhausting, but they keep it just right it seems. I'm not a fan of art museums but we were nearby and decided to take a look and I was not disappointed. Even our 4-year-old daughter liked it, ignored some of the exhibits and spend a lot of time studying some others, so I figured modern art really works with little kids. Some rooms were boring, then some were more exciting, we took a lot of pictures and got some ideas for little arts and crafts projects (I think that's what they call inspiration!). There is a little souvenir shop, but things are overpriced there, I've seen the same local designers' jewelry sold at a different store at a much lower price, so it's not the best place to shop, but a nice way to spend a couple hours in the afternoon.
Don't miss this!. There was a Berni exhibit during our visit. Very captivating. We learned a lot. It's a great building!
MALBA visit. Very nice museum, worth a visit. Take a taxi to get to it on a hot day, otherwise relatively short walk from the center.Very nice cafeteria on site.

A cristal box for delighful treasures. Berni´s crocodrile is one of pieces I like the best out of the MALBA´s collection. The other thing I love about this place are the tremendously big glass panes.A lot of light with no direct sunlight ever, quite a challenge!.
Faboo. Great little museum Great and very varied art. Had a really great time here! I loved the Argintinean art, which is a specialty here.
Something different. Such a light and airy museum with some extraordinary works. Very modern building. Well worth a visit

Manageable museum. When you are in South America, you want to spend most of your time strolling outside, but this museum was a good size and price (60 Ar pesos). It was a great way to get a flavor of Latin American art and we spent about 2h.

Small and cool. Very interesting exhibits from local artists. It's a cool museum to visit and it's near amazing parks so I would recommend a stop before grabbing a coffee and enjoying the surroundings.PS: Read the historic context before each exhibition room. It makes the visit a lot more interesting.

Must do. Impressive museum - looks like new but been there a while. Great way to enjoy Latin culture. We saw a large exhibit of the work of Antonio Berni, featuring his series on Juanito Laguna. He is associated with Nuevo Realismo (social realism regarding impacts of industrialization and urbanization). I would not have known about him except for this excellent exhibit.
Please don't miss this. Excellent collection, beautiful building, outstanding retrospective of artist Antonio Berni. Surpassed my expectations.

interesting art. I went there in the morning and it had a lot of people. it is very cheap to get in like 50 pesos.I saw different art work from many Latin American painters and some interesting sculptures also. It is also next to the Bosques de Palermo park so after staying at the museum for a few hours I took a nice walk in the park.

Great space and curation. Highly recommended, especially if you can go whilst the Antonio Berni retrospective is on. It's light, airy and easy enough to get around. I'd say it's about the right size as well, big enough to draw you in but not so vast that you lose the will to live trudging between exhibitions. The Antonio Berni work is fantastic and the retrospective is well enough curated to give you an understanding of his creative development. The coffee shop/ restaurant is downstairs and has an outside area which you can access independently if you need refreshments before entering.

Must See art museum in Buenos Aires.. If you choose one art museum to visit in Buenos Aires, this is it. We spent 3 hours here mostly looking at a large exhibit of works by the artist Antonio Berni... Amazing sculptures, portraits and mixed media works of Juanito and Ramona, who are two characters he depicts in the most unusual and unforgettable ways- one of a kind! The museum has some of the best works by Latin American artists you can see anywhere in the world. Don't miss it!

Top notch museum experience. Incredible collection of modern and post modern South American art, well displayed. You can't miss Pablo Reinoso's Enredaderas spaghetti bench, Rogelio Poleselo's optical artwork, Tarsila do Amaral's Abaporu painting (maybe the most recognizable Brazillian work of art of all).The architecture itself is another work of art, beautiful building.

Nice modern Art museum. This is a mid-sized museum that displays a permanent collection and temporary exhibitions on modern Latin American art. The permanent collection, in display, is not extensive, but it holds some master pieces from the first half of the 20th century. It holds paintings from renown artists like Tarsila de Amaral, Frida Kahlo, Fernando Botero and others. The building has a contemporary minimalist design and it evoques similar museums like the Thyssen-Bornemisza in Madrid or the MoMA in New York.
If you have a Samsung smartphone... It's two for one admission! Otherwise Wednesday it's half price (30 pesos). Good visit for a rainy day.
Yes .... Enjoyable. Depending on the shows, it can range from great to 'what the hell is that'. Excellent cafe.
Great moder Latin Art. This is a must do with your children its not so gothic compared to most museums with 16th century art. We loved our visit here lost great and interesting pieces.

Robert Mapplethorpe. The museum is wonderful. The building itself, the coffee shop and the food was great as well. I saw the famous Abaporu a painting by Tarsila do Amaral, which I had never seen in person, only in books. However, the highlight was the temporary exhibition of Mapplethorpe work on the last floor! His powerful images are still imprinted in my brains...loved it! we visited April 2012!

beautiful museum, small interesting collection. great architecture, well located, the collection of 20th century latino american art is small but really interesting and will certainly grow in the coming years. When I visited the museum there where no special exhibit. I recommend the museum cafe, great food, reasonably priced and great service

MALBA. We really enjoyed this gallery. The collection of contemporary Latin-American Art was a comprehensive representation of well-known Latin-American artists and the gallery space was airy and open enhancing the vibrancy of art from this area of the world. We were interested in the relocation of the Berni mural and watched the video which explained how the art conservationists did this.The gallery is in an area of Buenos Aires which is pleasant to wander around. There is a good restaurant in the gallery.

Good Rainy day activity. A light atmosphere and some very interesting art make a nice afternoon in Buenos Aires. Check open hours carefully - the line is long at opening time. The store has nothing good to bring home which is too bad because the museum is worth remembering.

Well Curated Latin Art Museum. The MALBA was on our "must do" list for Buenos Aires, and we were not disappointed. The museum is dedicated to Latin American artists and has a nice selection of 20th century pieces. The day we visited was the first day for the exhibit of Antonio Berni and his unique xilocollages and xilocollage reliefs. 2 of the 3 floors were designated to this artist and his delightful ongoing story of Juanito Laguna and Ramona Montiel that covers approximately 40 years of his career. It is hard to describe the pieces, found pieces fastened to a wood backing then printed onto paper. Many of the art works had the original woodblock next to them. Visit their website to get more information, but if you love art museums, don't miss this one!

Not worth it. For all that I had heard about MALBA, the permanent collection there is still rather in its infancy and can be visited in approximately 15 minutes. Interesting, yet nothing to write home about. Definitely not at par with the amazing galleries in other big cities in the world.Unfortunately, the temporary exhibition was closed at the time when we visited, something that seems to happen on a regular basis. So better to check that you are going to have more than a single floor to visit before you go!
Art lovers delight. Definitely a museum to visit. Great exhibition of both local & regional artist housed in a museumwith excellent light & air. One of my favorite places to visit in Buenos Aires.
Not the best day but worth it. It was beautiful but they were changing exhibitions that day so it was a bit messy. Exhibitions were great though.

Great art museum!. This is actually an excellent art museum, but I only gave it 4 stars because about half the museum was closed due to renovations. Just wanted to forewarn people...there is still some fabulous stuff to see so it's worth a look anyway

A beautiful contemporary space.. On view was some very cutting edge art by well-known South American contemporary artists. We were disappointed as just the ground floor was open; they were installing Antonio Berni on the upper floor which we wanted to see very badly.
Very nice museum. Current installation of Berni was fantastic. Museum has an important permanent collection worth seeing including Diego, Frida, and Covarrubias.

Mablatoast. I found the temporary exhibit on Berni to be a great window into the regions history, he's a maniac (weird monster art). It is running until February 2015. The permanent exhibit seemed kind of limited to me but was still enjoyable. I personally like to do audio tours at art galleries and museums and was a bit disappointed that they did not offer either a live or recorded one.

Berni exhibit. The museum was better tan expected. The Berni exhibit could not have been better. The permanent exhibits were not nearly as good. Even though it was Latin America I hoped to see more Rivera's and Khalo paintings.

World-class museum, beautifully presented art. A wonderfully spacious and welcoming museum of world-class modern art, allowing close access to the works. The only downside is the poor service in the restaurant.
One floor open. Be careful, only one floor open. Was interesting; but short visit. Not worth the price of admission. We were in town for one day. Had no choice

Rivera & Kahlo Together Again. These two most famous South American artists are represented by only one major work each but they are spectacular & they draw the crowds that invariably are impressed by the art of many contemporary talents in a building designed to showcase their work
Latin American Art. Great place to view the work of several latinamerican artist plus usual special presentarions. Beautiful building and spaces

Berni exhibit is a must see. MALBA has a major exhibit on of the work of Antonio Berni - it's brilliant - amazing colours and very creative. The choice of materials was fascinating and the inherent social commentary was incisive.

Interesting and diverse. The permanent exhibition gave a nice overview of the story of Latin American art, while the temporary one gave a deeper insight in Antonio Berni. This excibition in aortic suit was amazing.

Well curated selection of Latin American art. MALBA has good selection of Latin American art from new and more famous artists. The architecture of the building is also worthwhile to take a look at.
There is a great gift and bookstore also at the museum and those are also worth a visit.

ONLY ONE FLOOR OPEN. We were advised that only the first floor of the MALBA was open. Not having been there before, we did not know the significance of this point. We were done in 30 minutes. Quite disappointing. Make sure the museum is open completely

Wow! What a museum!. We were lucky enough to visit MALBA as they were installing a once in a lifetime Antonio Berni exhibit of his Juanito and Rowena works. We looked at the current exhibit of contemporary Latin American art, which was fabulous, and then returned a week later in an epic downpour, to see the Berni exhibition. There are no words to describe how fabulous it is. It was put together as a joint venture between MALBA and the Museum of Art in Houston, so it probably will be exhibited there as well, when it leaves Buenos Aires in February. See it if you can, but the permanent exhibit at MALBA is terrific as well.
MALBA. For those who like the modern art. not the first place to visit in BsAs, but if you have some interest or time to loose you could walfk on these greeny place

Spectacular collection!. I visited MALBA in May, 2014, and I was impressed with the collections of European and Latin American art: Botero, Kahló, Rivera, and more. MALBA's galleries are well curated and the museum's location itself is central to the Law School at the University of Buenos Aires. The entrance fee is meager compared to similar museums, but the experience is definitely world-class.

Stunning building and collection. This is fascinating - shows the development of 20C Latin American art, slowly drawing away from its Parisian and European models. Permanent collection is in five clusters with some striking conceptual art. In Aut 2014 there was a remarkable temporary exhibition on Antonio Berni.

Interesting sojourn. Nice building with variable exhibitions. Extensive gift shop plus a relaxing coffee/restaurant with inside and outside seating. Not close to train lines but is within walking distance (20mins) of Bulnes station on Linea D.

Powerful Series by Antonio Berni, Junaito y Ramona. We spent our first day touring Malba. Although we went expecting to see its collection of Diego Rivera, Frida Kahlo and other modern masters, we were treated to a special temporary exhibition by Antonio Berni, an Argentinian, called Juanito y Ramona. Life sized, using paints and found materials either mounted on wood or formed into fantastical sculptures, the first series tells the down trodden story of Juanito, an imaginary boy living in a shanty town. His next series turns to Ramona, an imaginary seamstress turned prostitute, whose dreams have been turned to nightmares by the monsters of life's realities. I would think that enjoyment of the museum's collection would depend on whether you like the temporary exhibit as the permanent collection is rather small. We absolutely loved our day there, ending with coffee at the delightful cafe.

Limited display. I visited last week and only one of three levels was open. I cannot say whether ticket prices were (not) discounted because of this. The person at the ticket offer mentioned nothing about limited access, so I asked because I could see the levels were cordoned off. What I did see was an average display of latin american art in various forms. I recommend you check if all exhibits are available before going to MALBA.
great collection of art!!. Great and unusual collection of art in a very chic small museum . This place is a must see even if it is not a very cheap one .

Great museum. MALBA is a small museum, compared with the ones in US and Europe, but with a beatiful and great collection. The building is an artwork. Even kids love the place. Do not miss it when visiting Buenos Aires.

Two out of three floors closed to the public. The building is stunning and the collection on display quite interesting but overall the visit was a huge disappointment given that two out of three floors were closed due to an upcoming exhibition. Maybe not too surprisingly, this was not communicated to visitors at the ticket office...
Interesting but not a lot to see. Quite expensive entry , some good modern works but only over one floor so unless there is a temporary exhibition on not much to see for your money .
Definitely worth the visit. Not the biggest museum but i prefer it this way, size is not everything! Great collection in a fantastic location and building.
Interesting. I did not care much for a number of the paintings but the installations were breath-taking. Also, some of the works involving light and mechanical structures, were very clever.

20 minutes. Luckily we found out it was open late on Wednesday and cost less. Perhaps this is because the entire third floor was closed, having just closed a temporary exhibit. We had planned to spend no more than 2 hours, we saw the actual permanent collection and gift shop in 20 minutes. There were some artists whose work stood out. You'll have to go to see what I mean.

Great experience. We really liked this museum. The building is architecturally interesting and very modern. There was an interesting temporary exhibition and the permanent collection is varied and contains some real gems.

A small museum, result of private collections.. A little bit of everything: One Frida Kalho, one Diego Rivera, one Bottero, etc.....It was good for getting a taste of Latin American Artists. It was doable for a short afternoon visit.
Really enjoyed it!. Love to see the local arts. For those love Latin American arts, please also visit the museum of popular arts.

Limited access. The special exhibition was changing so we only saw the permanent collection. I was a little disappointed give the amount of space that was closed and no warning before we went in to the museum.

Well curated, lovely place to visit and nice staff. We really enjoyed our trip to MALBA. We stopped for a coffee in the elegant cafe. Then walked around the collection. Really enjoyed the kinetic pieces and seeing the Frida Kahlo. Impressive building.

Very small,. Nice, but very small collection. Whole third floor was closed when we were there to prepare for a temporary exhibit. The cafe is lovely and good for people watching. The food, however, was a complete let down (wilted salad, Whole Foods pre-made-like sandwiches) at American museum cafe prices.
Modern and great place to be!. The museum has important South American collections and they are all very well distributed among its rooms. The museum location is also very beautiful.

A must go museum in BA. Amazing contemporary art - it's really fun to go to there is really cool stuff and normally, really awesome exhibitions also. Must go if you are a tourist and recurring go if you are an Argie :)

Busy museum late on a rainy Sunday. We went there as the streets were lakes in heavy rain. Pleasantly surprised! Lumiere Parc was a sensory experience like no other . Do not see this exhibit if you have epilepsy! Having said that it reminded one of deep sea fish and jelly fish. The basement floor is a wee bit too avant garde for what I would call art but the other floors are very cool. Service in the museum cafe was horrible so would advise to go to a local cafe! It has an interesting gift shop.
Fascinating Latin American art. Some amazing local art - the modern art is perhaps more interesting than some of the museums that focus on the "masters".

Ongoing Excellence. The MALBA is a wonderful example of modern Latin American Art and has new and exciting exhibitions frequently, in addition to their permanent collection.Often, at openings of new exhibits, there is a free champagne reception. I have seen several great exhibits this year, including Mario Testino, Le Parc Lumiere (kinetic) and other extremely interesting art installations. I would highly recommend a visit. There is also a nice cafe attached and a comprehensive book and gift store.

Lovely little Museum. I Strongly recommended this museum. Every time I come to the city I go to visit the MALBA and I was never disappointed. Malba is not a very big museum and so it's enjoyable for everyone. There are always interesting and new expositions and the museum shop has lots of interesting books about all types of art.
I don't know art. It kept me occupied while my daughter was attending a 3 hour class - that's impressive if you know me.

Muy bien!. Loved the architecture of the building and the way the exhibitions are represented. I especially came to see Frida Kahlo, but unfortunately they only had one of her paintings - I thought they had more. The price was only 25 pesos because I was a student, so you get so much of an experience for a very small amount of money. I will definetly visit this place one more time before I leave Argentina!

Perfect art museum to visit. An absolutely stunning space to view contemporary art. A really great and varied collection of local and South American artists. Temporary exhibit until October of the work of Julio le Parc is really fantastic and not to be missed. http://www.malba.org.ar/en/evento/le-parc-lumiere/The restaurant is also good for lunch.

Got Art?. BsAs has more Art in one city than most countries in the world. Make sure to give yourself plenty of time to see it all. We were amazed at the collection of fine art and please bring a language converter if you go.

Great Exhibition. There was a nice exhibition when i went there and the museum is modern, not too big, so you don't get tired of it and great located if you like to walk: it's in a green neighborhood of Buenos Aires

An artwork itself. Wonderful architecture and contemporary art collection topped with a beautiful café and art shopping. The building worth the visiting itself and the Palermo neighborhood is perfect for a long walk. Don't miss!
Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera. Although MALBA is a smaller museum, the paintings are high quality. It is worth the small entrance fee to see the Frida Kahlo and Diego Rivera paintings.
Nice small museum.. We loved the interactive light show. You don't need more than two hours if you are not an avid art enthusiast.
Painting collections. The museum is an art museum that has a good collection of modern art, mainly paintings. Very good for those that like paintings.

Fun museum. Very cool (though small) museum. I thought the light exhibit they currently have by Julio Le Parc was fascinating and worth the price of admission! Was only $5pp. Good if it's a day with bad weather like we had. For whatever reason, when we showed them our Samsung phone it was 2 for 1 admission!
Very small collection. Julien Le Parc installations were interesting but permanent collection was very poor. Nice building with couple art pieces noticeable...
Don't miss this museum!. Great capsule summary of regional art, established and developing. Great museum store and excellent book store.
Excellent exhibition of internationally recognized artists. Has European paintings from various periods by famous artists plus rooms exhibiting Argentinian paintings and indigenous art.

Well worth a detour. The current installations by Julien Le Parc are incredible but even the regular collection and the chance to eat in the bustling but elegant restaurant made it worth a little wander through the lovely area near the botanical gardens.
