MALBA. I really like this museum. It's modern, nice, big. What I most like about it is that there's always something amazing to look forward to. The permanent collection is good, but it tends to get a bit boring after a while. For instance, I've seen the permanent collection so many times, it feel repetitive, but it's still good/entertaining. I love the fact that MALBA has many activities to offer--meaning the public participates a lot and can learn from the arts. The cinema offers really amazing films, and there are usually discussions about the films/directors, and you can participate if you want, and there are guided tours for those who want to learn, or are just curious. The prices are relatively good, it's free on wednesdays, and I think you get a discount if you're a student, or are ovver the age of 65, or under 12.MALBA also has a very nice restaurant, where you can go have coffee, or dinner, or both. What I most like about MALBA is that you can dressed really nicely, or normal, and it is OKAY. There are many temporary exhibitions, like Yayoi Kusama, and they tend to be AMAZING. This last one was so successful, you had to wait in line for HOURS to buy your tickets. It was totally worth going.

A must for Art lovers. Im not a specialist in Art but the place is great set and has a lot and changing exhibitions that make it a must-visit when coming to Buenos Aires and looking for art or visiting museums

Latin American Art. The Latin American Art Museum of Buenos Aires ((MALBA) is in Palermo, on Figueroa Alcorta Avenue.Operated by a non-profit organization, the museum proudly boasts of excellent pieces of art, paintings by Frida Khalo, Antonio Berni, Xul Solar, Diego Rivera, among others. The aim of the institution is collecting, preserving and promoting Latin American art as well as providing the public with an opportunity to foster their knowledge in Latin American artists.It also holds temporary exhibitions, as for example Yayoi Kusama’s at the moment of this review.Not to be missed!
MALBA in BA. Mainly fun thanks to the temporary exhibition of Yayoi Kusama - made it a bit of a different experience. Permanent collection is a bit disappointing.

Exceptional art, exceptional presentation, exceptional experience. This museum was by far my favourite stop on the trip.They blend painted, photographic, sculpted and video art into various engaging and intricate exhibitions to showcase the artistic flair of Latin America.The classic and contemporary exhibits painted a powerful imagery of Art from Latin America and the rest of the world. There was an exhibit which the museums patrons could contribute to the exhibit that really captures the spirit of art that this museum represents.
I went twice!!. It is worth your while! A great museum with modern art and changing exhibits. I went back again in July because it was such a great museum. On Wednesdays it is free for students.

make it part of your walking tour day. Museum is petit stil very interesting on its architecture and exhibitions. I recommend you make this visit as a part of a walking day through "Libertador Avenue" from the ZOO and Japanese garden all the way to Recoleta stopping at MALBA, PALACIO ERRAZURIZ having a drink at Madame Croque there at the garden, keep going to Recoleta Area, Museum, Cementery, walks...and last the Pearl: finish your day having a glass of wine at Park Hyatt Palacio Duhau ( opposite Patio Bullrich mal) Alvear Avenue...enjoy!
Yayoi kusama. Fantastic exhibit! Informative, Interactive, and what can I say about the artist. Genius!! The museum is well organized and fairly priced. Can't wait to see what exhibit is coming next!

Incredible private collection. I still can´t believe that this is a private collection. I was surprised about the high level of culture of the people in buenos aires. I was lucky to enjoy the Kusama art.

Very interesting modern building, housing a very good collection of Latin American art. These painters are exceptional, but very poorly represented in European collections. Both the display and the organisation are excellent in this Museum. They put on special exhibitions, we have not visited one in our last trip, but always try to see the permanent collection at least once in our regular visits to Buenos Aires

Great collection and building. It's always very nice to return to MALBA. They have a solid latin american art collection and always good temporary shows too. The store has a great book selection, and the cafe has very disputed tables in the summer days.

Don't miss the Yayoi Kusama exhibit!. The trees all around the museum are wrapped in polka dots. That means the Yayoi Kusama exhibit is in full bloom (I think through mid-Sept). I wasn't sure what I was getting myself into, and even at 6pm on a Wednesday, there was a long line to get in [Samsung phone users get 2x1]. Once inside the exhibit is incredibly immersive and acts like a time machine, taking you back to the free-loving 60s and 70s - she organized a lot of orgys and happenings. The infinity mirror, black light, and polka dot rooms are all really fun and bring you into the experience. It's really fun and helps make your time in BAires feel a little more cultured.
Great Latin American Art. Greta Permanent collection in a great and modern building. Go and admire latin american art, including great argentinian painters and even Frida Kahlo originals.
As any museum should be. This is not a museum just with pictures on the walls. It's a place that belong to arts and arts belong to it.
Great way to spend an afternoon. Runs great exhibitions, we viewed the Japanese artist Kusuma's installations. 60 revisited!! Convenient location. Close to public transport

If you like modern art, this is the place for your to visit, well worth it.. Nice museum in a beautiful modern building. If you like plastic and modern arts and paintings, this is the place for you to visit.

Top-notch -- be sure to factor in waiting in line. This is a beautiful modern art museum. The exhibition quality is comparable to that at MoMA in New York, although it is a much smaller museum. One surprise was that there are quite long lines to enter, which seemed to be a result of having far too few persons selling tickets. We waited in line around an hour to get in. The restaurant is currently not open. The design of the building is very modern (again, MoMA like). The top floor seems to be designed to have a non-permanent large exhibition. When we visited, there was a retrospective of a Japanese artist (Yayoi Kusama). Again, some lines to enter into some aspects of this exhibition -- there was a room where you could experience her sculpture and only three people at a time could get in. The second floor housed the permanent collection, which is focused on Latin American modern artists. It begins with artists who were creating around the time of Picasso/Matisse, through present day. As I'm not all that familiar with these artists, I don't know whether they left anyone out, but it was very nicely presented. Also on this floor was a non-permanent exhibition (smaller). On the first floor is a relatively small museum store (with some tasteful jewelry, scarves, home objects, as well as books), and another small exhibition space (more Kusuma when we were there). If you enjoyed this museum, you may want to check out the less known Museo Sorvini (located in Parque de Tres de Febrero) -- it was also very nice, but from the guidebooks, we didn't expect to like that one as much as we did.
Great architecture and excellent exhibits.. Latin American art and novel exhibits. Spent 2hours strolling and admiring artwork. Watch out because foreigners pay more for the entrance fee!
The best museum of Latin American Art in Sud America. The best museum of Latin American Art in Sud America. The permanet colletions is a complete collection of latin american masterpieces of art.

great modern art museum. MALBA is an excellent space to view the modern artists of Latin America. The art fuses with the architecture. A bench is not just a bench. For more info read my blog.http://havefunflysafe.com/2013/06/22/things-i-have-learned-in-buenos-aires/
Small but interesting!. Interesting works by South American artists and temporary exhibitions by other artists. An hour or two well spent.

Infinitely good!. The Yayoi Kusama exhibition is well worth a visit, or two, or three... It begins right from the street with the trees on both sides of the museum entrance dressed in red and white Kusama polka dots. The motif is repeated through the museum, including on the lift and escalators. Make sure to see all her exhibits, especially the ones with her press releases and memos - what politics the woman had, even in the 70s! There was a huge queue to get into a room with infinity red and white penises (at least that is what they looked like to me, when we finally got in after one hour), but as there were two of us, we took it in turns to stand in line and go look at the other exhibits on the way. The Labyrinth (dark space, lit up with coloured lights and mirrors) was enchanting as was another dark room with coloured spots floating all around. I don't know why the queue had gathered for the other room, these two were the best in my opinion, so I am glad there was no queue there, anyway! It was all fantastic, though there were some pieces that left me bewildered and others, disturbed, but on the whole, I fully recommend this exhibition. Only, make sure you get there on a full stomach - the cafe was closed, and I do not know for how long. But then, if you walk for about 10 - 15 minutes towards Recoleta, you can get some lovely food to eat! More about that maybe in another review : )

Great Exhabition Obesesion Infinite. There was a huge queue to get into the Exhabition Obesesion Infinite by Yayoi Kusama, maybe 30 minutes. We also saw queues when we passed it in the week. It was however well worth the queue. Some great paintings. No cafe that we could find in there.

Yayoi Kusama!!!. Malba has at a temporary exhibit of the Japanese artist Yayoi Kusama. If you happen to be in Buenos Aires while this exhibit is still going on... spend the time. It is definitely worth it. The permanent collection, though small, is worth visiting. A nice painting of Frida Khalo (Mexican), a couple from Pettoruti (Argentinian), Botero... This is not the MoMA but you will not be disappointed. One thing... the museum does not open until Noon!!!!

Great collection of modern latin art. I'd say that MALBA is probably the only essential museum visit in Buenos Aires. Bellas Artes is good (and free), but I find the collection here much more inspiring. There are always temporary exhibitions, many of which are quite good, but the permanent collection of Latin art on the second floor is always there, and gives a terrific survey of key artists, many of whom are overlooked by museums in the US.Also, check out the film schedule, as they play a lot of interesting movies here. Small but well-selected stuff in the gift shop, too.

one of the best curated museums anywhere. MALBA wowed me -- both the temporary and permanent collections showed Latin American Art at its best. Missing from many other museums in BA, the MALBA's curatorial vision is well thought -out and cohesive. Someone here has vision and focus.

Limited Exhibits. I had heard very great things about MALBA. It was supposedly one of the top rated things to do in Buenos Aires. However, when we went only two exhibits were open and we go through the entire museum in about an hour and a half. The art that was on display was beautiful, but I wouldn't put MALBA on the top of my priority list for places to visit in Buenos Aires.

MALBA. Excellent permanent collection of early, mid, late 20th Century Argentine and Latin American artists. See the Tarsila do Amaral work and the Joaquin Torres-Garcia and Xul Solar art was wonderful. And they have a killer Cubist Diego Rivera!

modern art. It is great place for modern art lovers to get an insight into the art scene here in Argentina. I spent a rainy afternoon here. It also has a great café to have lunch which I recommend if you get the chance.

Excellent museum !!!. A modern setting for an excellent Latinamerican art permanent collection. It's a private museum run by a foundation who's responsible for all cultural activities. There's even a good cinema with a very special programme. And after your visit don't miss a drink at the bar (choose the terrace weather permitting). The restaurant is also very good but a bit pricey though. All in all, if you love art, then MALBA is a must!!

Yes, go to MALBA!. MALBA was great. It was smaller than typical museums, but the same size as most contemporary art museums. It featured a wide variety of Latin American artists and had a wonderful exhibition of Fernando Bryce's work, of which I had never seen. It was a wonderfully curated exhibit. Since then I checked the website and there have been other exhibitions of wonderful work. Definitely worth the visit!

Surprisingly Amazing. I don't usually like art museums, but the exhibit when I went (June 2013) was very interactive and experiential. The exhibit artist used mirrors, lights and stickers to bring the viewer into a whole new world. I felt like I was in OZ. For those who won't be able to catch the Yayoi Kusama exhibit, the building was great. The perfect size with just 2 and half floors. The standing exhibits were interesting and creative. Not the place to go if you are hoping for extensive Argentine culture, but a great art museum. And I think it is free/cheap on Wednesdays (Bring your student ID!)

One of my favorite parts of my visit to BA. Awesome gallery. The building itself is really fantastic and the museum itself is curated really well. Nice staff as well! And you can take pictures!! Also saw children's groups in there with an English speaking interpreter having a discussion over the painting of Frida Kahlo. This should definitely be a stop on your museum tour. I'd put it at number one. It was definitely better than Bellas Artes. If you are a student they may let you in free as well!! They did for me!This is also in a really great location- down a couple blocks from all the embassies. It's a great idea to do Bellas Artes and MALBA together (because the walk is only 15-20 at the most) and then head down the main drag for a bit toward the embassies to see them. Then turn left into what I think is Centro (maybe Recoleta first and then Centro?) Anyways, it's really nice!!

interesting art collection. Nice museum of modern art from Latin America. You only need about an hour to tour it all, but well worth it. Located nearby the bosque park that is nice to walk around on a sunny day.

A quick visit for fans of modern art. This museum is somewhat limited (two floors were closed when we visited in June 2013) but what we saw was quite good and thought-provoking. (Well - at least for those of us who like modern art. The grandfather in our group was not impressed - haha.) The tickets are inexpensive and you can see the whole main floor in an hour or less. We saw one Frida Kahlo, one Diego Rivera, one Fernando Botero, a few Xul Solars - so, quality, just not a lot of quantity. Some interesting sculptures and some artists with whose work I was unfamiliar.Couple of caveats - you will likely need to take a cab to get there - it's not too close to the subte. Oh, and right now (summer 2013) the cafe is closed too. We found lunch at Le Pain Quotidien about a block away that was quite good - just sharing that in case you are planning a visit in the next few weeks.

Cool Space. When we visited MALBA only one floor was open (the other 2 were being prepared for a special exhibit). It was nice to see so many works of art by Latino artists. They have an original Diego Rivera and an original Frida Kahlo. Nice for a low key afternoon.

Worth a visit. We walked to this museum from our hotel in Recoleta and it was well worth it! We then found a lovely spot nearby for lunch and strolled back to our hotel. I would definitely recommend a visit to MALBA.

Not to be missed. It's one of the newest museums in Buenos Aires.You'll find latin american art from a private collection and international artists art in a beautiful building where you can also find a good and small shop and a coffe bar.

Really enjoyed the museum!. I found MALBA to be a more intriguing attraction than the Museo de Bellas Artes. Although I naturally have a soft spot for modern art w/ a colorful twist, MALBA has a cornucopia of works that will catch and take firm hold of your attention. I was a bit disappointed by the lack of exhibits (only 1 floor was open), but I think I was just unlucky.

Good. I agree with what some others have said about this museum. Early 20th C is my favorite period of art, but as far as collections go, I think that The National Museum (de las Bellas Artes) has a more impressive collection. Too bad the Bellas Artes collection can't be seen in the Malba building...which is much brighter! When we asked about a cafe, they simply told us there isn't one, not that it is being renovated as per another reviewer. I do think this is worth going if you love art, however!

Small collection, beautiful building. Really enjoyed MALBA - it's a relatively small collection, but the current exhibit I saw was excellent. Nice gift shop too. The only disappointment was that the cafe was closed for renovations.

Wonderful Collection of Latin American Art. The museum is quite beautiful and well-designed, and the collection is very good, especially for modern Latin American art. There are exciting pieces by all the major Latin Americans, from Frida Kahlo to Xul Solar to Figari. A must for art lovers, especially those who already love Latin American art and those who want to learn more about it.
small but worth the time. It only took about an hour to go through the museum, but they had a good collection of modern art from the region.

A gem of a gallery. Good things come in small packages and the Malba is one of these. I delighted in the exploration and discovery of new artists and I found myself lingering for many hours in awe of works and styles that made my own creative juices flow.

A must for appreciation of Latin American Art. Although the Museum shows predominantly Argentine artists, it is well represented by other Latin American paintings (Botero, Khalo, etc). The restaurant offers nice lunch menu.

Boring, is this really art?. Can't say i really understood why this place was so popular. Went with my daughter and I have to say the modern ideas of art are ugly and many displays were even scary for my daughter. Museo Nacional de Bellas Artes was about 1000 times nicer.

Nice but Small. This privately run and spectacularly designed museum is among BA's must-sees and, judging from the long line at the entrance, one of the most popular galleries. We particularly like the Latin American section (e.g. Argentinian Xul Solar, Chilean Roberto Matta and Mexican Diego Rivera). Frida Kahlo’s "self-portrait with monkey and parrot" is another highlight. But overall the collection is way too small, deserving only an hour. If you have visited many modern art museums in Europe and the Americas, don't expect any wow factor. Leave time to browse books at the gift shop.
Adreanna Varajeo is amazing. Great museum and the featured artist in May was Adreanna Varajeo whose work is incredibly powerful and through diverse mediums. Really worth a visit.
for breakfast, for lunch, for a museum cafe. As star chef Jean Paul Bondoux now has his hands in the game...Good for breakfast, delicious for lunch
Good collection but small. Nice collection of modern art but quiet small. We went round within an hour. The building is nice and the café next door worth a visit
Excellent museum. You can't miss it! Excellent art in a fancy building! There are different collections you will love. Wednesdays is 50% off opens from 12 to 8/9 pm.
Loved it. We hit a rainy day in Buenos Aires, so went to MALBA. We were pleasantly surprised. The space is beautiful. The art is fabulous and not so huge to be overwhelming.

Fabulous modern building, a small but representative collection.. Worth an hour or so of your time. Contains di Cavalcantis, Boteros, Riveras and some Argentinian paintings. Most of all, admire the soaring modern architecture of the building. Costs 8 pesos for senior citizens.

Great discovery. I had a very good time in this museum. I discovered a lot of artists I had never heard of and the permanent collection offers a great panorama of the main artistic movements of the 20th century. I also enjoyed pretty much the temporary exhibition of the Brazilian artist Adriana Varejao.

Probably the best Latin American modern art collection. You will find the largest collection of latin american art in the world.
After the tour you can have a drink or grab something at the cafe's museum , a very cozy place.
Nice location and building. Great concept which needs to be expanded both in its permanent collections and temporary exhibitions. Disappointingly, my most recent visit was uneventful and unmemorable.

Fantastic Modern Art Museum. This is an ultramodern, privately run museum which presents some fascinating and unique art work. We loved the benches which flow from one floor to the next. Highly recommended!

Beautiful exhibition. This place is definitely worth a visit if you're at all interested in art.
Head along to check it out for yourself! Entrance fee of about 30 pesos from memory.

Nice Collection. The MALBA has one of the best Latin American Art collections in the world. Displayed very well with a nice rotation of visiting collections, very impressed by the museum and its contents. Highly recommended

Nice stuff but too less!. We had big expectations when we went there as we like modern art very much and try to visit all museums and galleries exhibiting modern art. Although the quality of articles displayed was good, they were so less that we were finished in 40 minutes. Only one part was open and the rest was closed. Do not know why and there was no explanation anywhere either.

For art lovers. We didn't know much about MALBA when we made a stop there, except that we enjoy modern art. We LOVE this place. The pieces were nice, though may be sparse. The gift shop, however, is quite small and didn't have much merchandise for temporary exhibits.

best art museum in the city. We went to 3 different art museums in Buenos Aires, but this was by far our favorite. The art is unique to the region, and they also had a nice cafe on the ground floor to get lunch at after visiting the museum.

Nice space. Modern architecture defines the space where several art exhibitions take place at the same time. Besides the permanent collection (quite good), cutting edge artist are showcased. Coming in June, Yayoi Kusama!

Worth my 32 pesos!. For anyone who loves contemporary art, don't miss this museum which has a decent showcase of drawings, paintings, photographs, multimedia, sculptures and installations by various Latin American artists. You just need a max of 2 hours to cover this attraction. They only open at noon and don't go on Tues coz they are closed.
Great time exploring art. We enjoyed viewing the many different pieces of art here at the MALBA. A good rainy day activity. Glad we took the time to take this in!

Slick and captivating. Combines many media in a slick, yet modestly sized gallery collection. It is all quality: the big names of Kahlo, Rivera, Berni, Stern and Dias, and wonderful conceptual pieces - check out the 'triffid-like' garden seat, and the funnily provocative video "the way things go".

Beautiful building without enough art. The MALBA is located in spectacular building but needs more art. The permanent collection of contemporary south american artists is excellent but small. The special exhibits are interesting but during this 2nd visit in 5 years we found half the museum closed to the public. They have a terrific gift shop.

Funky museum. Funky museum. Cute cafe downstairs to have a coffee or drink before or after the visit. There's a funky noisemeter right outside the museum. Museum has interesting expos with photography, modern art, contemporary art etc.

latin american modern art. Being from New York I am constantly exposed to excellent art and museums, but the Malba was something new and different. The artists here are all from Latin America, something you rarely see in the US or Europe. Very nice collection.

Enjoyable. I very much liked this museum. They show many different pieces from pictures to sculpture or videos.
Worth a visit
Nice manageable museum. Nice small collection and loved getting in free since we are 'seniors'. But we were disappointed that the restaurant there was closed.
If you are into Modern Art. Do not leave Bs As without paying a visit to this great museum. The modern building, itself, is worth the trip.

Worth a visit to meet LatAm art of today. Nice building and collections, not too big, and a very intersting moment with artists (mostly Argentinians, but not only) you wouldn't necessarily know. A must see with the Proa in La Boca.

provocative. I went through the store while may husband was in line for the ticket. The most remarkable item was a leather tote with simulated breasts on one side and rectum on the other. It seemed to be a symbol for the whole museum. Not necessarily sexual provocation, even though there was a lot of that, but shocking for the sake of shocking. Very few things worth taking pictures of for me - a Frieda Kahlo, one Diego Rivera, a pterodactylus mobile. There was a lot of painful in your face ugliness at $38 a ticket. The one beautiful thing was the building - light, airy, joyful. Not quite enough for the price.
Must do. Fantastic house and ambience for Musdeum. Very interesting exhibitions. Good location next door to other 'must see' exhibitions.

Good for a rainy day, and they let you take pictures!. It wasn't very big (compared to London's Tate Modern for instance), and they could have added better facilities (a bigger shop, and a coffee shop and restaurant).I liked what was on display though, and it was amazing that they let you take photos.
Beautiful. Great archtecture, but the exhibition were not that exciting. The cafe is too simple, could be more for a museum of that size and fame.
A must be art place to see. Worldwide class modern art museum, with may be the nicest collection of Latin-American art in the world. Every stay in Buenos Aires, I come here to see new works

Hilarious art museum. This is basically a personal collection, and the collector shares my tastes, so I loved it. Shiny kinetic sculptures, op-art in cast acrylic and in bright acrylic paint, and the most ridiculous bench in the world.

The history of Modern BA and LA art. Not only do they have the best collection of modern BA and Latin American art BUT they had in 2009 the best Warhol show I have ever seen with the exception of the one in Monaco in 2003 at the Grimaldi Pavilion. They always have a show of recent purchases so you get to see some of the best contemporary work being done in LA. Also, I must put in a plug for their restaurant..sit outdoors and enjoy medialunas and cafe or any number of interesting salads and sandwiches. If you speak Castellano, spend the whole afternoon here and attend one of the movies...always interesting.

Interesting. Not extensive but nicely put together and the modern section has some things that make you laugh. The second floor is closed at the moment for a new exhibition coming. Open until 7 so good to do at the end of the day.
Awesome art collection. I liked everything in this museum. It was easy to find and a pleasure to visit. I would highly recommend this museum.

Malba May 2012. The day I went to the Malba, in May 2012, and the works of Frida Tarsila had been lent for an exhibition in the United States and only to return there in November. Nobody warned us diso before paying the entry. On the other hand, had a very good exhibition called Bye Bye American Pie. It was a really good experience!!

Too small, to thin, but in a beautiful building. This building and its location is well chosen. I wish I could say the same for the works displayed, only one of diego and one of khalo, the visitors are expecting much more, much more. and the works that are not well known are of little interest, poorly chosen. They take a significant entrance fee too. too early. build a collection first.

Beautiful building, between exhibits. They were installing new exhibits so two floors (areas?) were closed when I went. Permanent collection exhibition was delightful, as was the bulding design. Nice gift shop ;-)
Wonderful Museum. Beautiful building with impressive Latin Americam modern art beautifully displayed. Check hours. Open late some nites.

My favourite. I love this place for its clean architecture and modern art. Always something interesting to see. And I love Frida's 1942 self portrait that is always there. They don't mind photos which is wonderful. And not too much to be overwhelming - perfect for me
Great selection of Latin American art. Very well organized and interesting selection of latin American art. Make sure to check opening times as the museums are all different.

A famous place in BA. and worth a visit, as the art on display is by well known artists both Argentinians and from further North (Mexico). A trip to the MALBA is best combined with one to the Belle Artes museum as they are within 1/2 of walking
great. really surprisingly good, I am not a big fan of modern art but this was really good! We enjoyed a afternoon there cafeteria looks very cosy to!

Explore new directions in art. MALBA is a must when visiting Buenos Aires. It showcases a wide variety of different styles and explores the range of modern art including some fascinating interactive art and 3 dimensional pieces. There are several pieces that have the vibrancy you think of in terms of Latin-American art but also some surprising and unexpected things as well. Don't just walk past the videos,It is worth it to take the time to see the the images of the video morph and change. When we were there one of the artists had on display a series of pieces that were painted on shower curtains to give you the image that you were looking at a figure inside a shower. Fascinating. It does not take a long time to go through the exhibits but it is well wo
just right. A taste of modern Argentinan aesthetic. Can be done in a hour and a half. Some interesting works, a few burned into my memory banks.
A nice pit stop in Palermo. I spent about an hour here first thing in Palermo. Nice museum and it won't take a terribly long time (I just strolled through the videos)
So worth seeing!. Wonderful collection -- easily managed in an hour or two, not overwhelming, completely refreshing. This and the Decorative Arts Museum are not to be missed.
WOW. If you like modern art, don't miss this spot. Building is spectacular and the exhibits are not only fantastic but displayed beautifully.

Great permanent collection. The permanent collection is lovely.
The Oscar Munoz photography display upstairs (temporary exhibit I think) was amazing!
what building!. although the art is not to my taste, the building and the display of the art is magnificent. well worth going. a nice cafe on the premises, and parks surrounding the building.
Modern art is a super modern building. Modern art is a very modern building. Wonderful outdoor cafe in a green area. A very pleasant experience.

Wednesday Free Day a bargain!. What a remarkable collection of modern art! Cool building, nice gift shop, great cafe. As seniors, visiting on a Wednesday (when museum has extended hours) we received free admission, which was an unexpected bonus.

A worthwhile museum. The museum contains an interesting collection of Latin American art. It is a modern building with a real pretty lobby. The art collections are all different, paintings, photos, sculptures and movies. A good way to spend a couple of hours.

Eclectic collections. Yes, art is in the eye of the beholder. My eye wasn't impressed by much of what I saw. Video loops of water going down a drain isn't "art" in my opinion, but others may differ. Some good Latin American artists are represented and worth a look, but a lot of the rest left me wondering why the curator alloted so much space to what looked like middle school art projects.

A good example of art. If more of now-a-days millionaries followed the example of Constantini, life would become more pleasant.Malba is a small but very efficient American art museum in a nice district of Buenos Aires.One main claim that there are some lacks concerning some movements, but since a collection is a personal option, the paintings and sculptures reveal the most brilliant artists.The shop is also a nice place for goods for also reasonable prices
My first frida calda. It was amazing, really enjoyed the art work, an it had an eclectic mix so there is definitely something there for everyone.

Calling modern art fans.... The museum is 3 stories @ 16 pesos person. If you are a modern art fan it is a bargain to see a couple of well known South American artists like Frida Kahlo but then quite a few unknown artists. You should consider the day's activities as the art work is very moving so you might walk out with a different mood then when you entered. Definitely not a child's place.

Stunning Oscar Munoz exhibition. MALBA's focus seems to be on rotating exhibitions rather than the permanent collection, and they do bring in the big guns. When I visited, there was an absolutely fabulous Oscar Munoz exhibition and another by Tracey Emin. If you are planning to visit, I suggest looking at their website beforehand to see what's on.

A Must See for Art Lovers. We visited the MALBA during our recent visit to Buenos Aires and loved the broad range of representative South American art. Highly recommended.Our only issue was with the onsite restaurant. We had heard it was a good option for lunch. We had to find ad clear our own table and find our own menus. After about 10 minutes one of our party found a server and asked them to take our order. After another 15-20 minutes without getting service we walked out. Unfortunate since there are not too many other lunch options close by.

Well worth a visit. I wouldn't say Buenos Aires has a lot to offer in the art department but the fantastic permanent exhibition here is well worth a visit, I spent a highly enjoyable hour strolling around. the crazy bench alone makes it worth the trip!
Inspiring visit. Great architecture and an inspiring exhibition. You can even get good food in the cafe. Certainly worth a visit.

Great art, perfect size. We loved MALBA. Amazing light and architecture. The art was wonderful and the size perfect...doesn't take more than an hour of your day. We hit it on the way to the Buenos Aires Zoo...also highly recommended!

Glad She Made Me Go.. The day we went was the most beautiful day of our entire stay in Buenos Aires and the last place I wanted to be was in a museum. But- WOW-this former palace was extraordinary and gave a picture of what upper class life was like in BA in the early 20th Century. One thing not to be missed is Croque Madame, the museum's cafe. The food was incredible and worth a trip itself.

Excellent collection, beautiful building. We had the MALBA on our list, but never made it a priority, until we were dying for something to do to escape the 43' heat. An excellent decision, the MALBA is full of well-curated shows, and a fantastic permanent collection. They also provided english translations of the curator's notes which was very nice, and much appreciated (and lacking in other museos in BA).
Interesting Look. A few pieces will really interesting. Most interesting of all was the realization of how derivative New World art can be. The building is lovely.

LOVED it. The building of the museum is glorious and the collection features the best latin american artists of the 20th century. I fell in love with Antonio Berni here. The cafe is excellent; a little pricey but worth it for the quality of food and wine list as well as the atmosphere and the service which are both excellent.
modern museum. It pays a photo of its interior and exterior, beautiful construction. The galleries didn't apeal much to me

Not to missed.. Amazing museum that is also a bargain. Currently the entrance fee is around 3 USD. The museum normally has 3 rotating exhibits in all different mediums. Allow yourself 2 hours, more if you plan on having lunch at the excellent indoor/outdoor cafe. Don't miss the gift store and book store as well. You can take pictures as well just make sure you don't use the flash. This is one place where you can go back to again and again and always see something new. It is one of the first stops whenever I have guests here visiting.

Must see on the list of Buenos Aires sites.. Amazing exhibits in different mediums. Entrance fee is a bargain...around 3 USD. Sidenote: They have a wonderful indoor/outdoor cafe that is not to be missed.

MALBA is worth a visit!. Beautiful museum and we went on a Wednesday when entry was reduced for adults, and actually free for retirees. Had a lovely gourmet lunch outside at the cafe there. All in all, a delightful way to spend an afternoon!

Highly recommended - great building & modern art. Not only is the building amazing, but this 3 storey museum is the right size for a family visit. Our 2 kis - 9&11- enjoyed it too.Great mix of sculptures, photos, paintings. And great pics of Andy Warhol.Note that Wednesday is half price....
just ok. I used to expect much more than I saw there. The exibits was not really nice, and the permanent exibit was ok. The staff is not helpful. The best there is the atmosphere.

Long walk there for not too much. Its a long walk from downtown, although the parks you pass through are very pleasant. Museum focuses on just a few artists, none of whom impressed us, but then we are not big modern art fans. And its hard to get an impression of the building from the outside 'cos of trees and other buildings.

Very rich modern art museum. Beautiful museum, vast collection of Latin American art, permanent and temporary exhibitions. We had the chance to discover the photography of Oscar Munoz, a great experience

Good Experience. Really modern museum with some good exhibitions. Not a big place, but definitely worth a visit. Just be warned, it opens later at 12pm so don't get there about 2 hours early like us. . .

Amazing Munoz Exhibit!. We went to this architecturally interesting modern museum after reading good reviews. It is a really cool space, with a nice cafe for a drink or lunch (which was much needed given the ot Buenos Aires day). The special exhibit was by a Columbian artist Oscar Munoz, and it was spectacular - both in the work itself and the well spaced displays. The permanent collection was also interesting, and I am not normally very into contemporary art. There is an entry fee of about 6-7 US dollars, but it seemed very worth it to us.

A Small Well Curated Collection. Shows the richness and inventiveness of Latin American art with examples of works by luminaries like Wilfredo Lam , Diego Rivera, Zuniga, Botero,and other well and lesser known artists in a modern and well lit space. An exhibit of works on paper is there now and should not be missed.

Small is beautiful!. This museum is small and beautiful! The building in itself is a work of art and it has a very nice collection of latinamerican modern art. The cafe beside it is a nice way to end your visit.

Wonderful. Beautiful and fascinating museum.
We had a terrific tour guide who was both knowledgable and beautiful and it was a very enjoyable experience.

Beware the early morning queues.... This is a striking architectural building housing an eclectic (to me slightly disappointing) collection of modern art. The temporary exhibits were better. There's a nice cafe with terrace, and a good bookshop. It's a place to make sure you visit - but beware of getting there just after opening: there was already a small crowd, and so you find yourself hanging about to buy entry tickets in a long slow snake of a queue, and on the day we went the ticket sales people were all attitude - austere and unfriendly. No way to make their day...
So So. Most of it was slightly weird. There was one good display by a very imaginative photographer that was worth seeing

Small museum but very special. This small museum in a modern building houses a permanent collection of Latin American art as well as other exhibits.We were completely engrossed in all the art we saw and even though the museum is small we spent a good 2 hours viewing the video art and the permanent collection.

WEIRD. As much as we love contemporary art this place was a bust. Perhaps the art got lost in translation, but we were not fans. Building was beautiful and there were a handful of wonderful pieces in their collection, such as the self-portrait of Freida Kahlo. The best part was the reasonable price and easy access.
Well worth a visit. Excellent permanent collection, definitely not to be missed. Interesting South American artists plus works by Kahlo and Rivera.

Great South American artists. This museum gives you an overview of South American artists. There is another art museum in BA, however, you will see artists that you can find in Paris, NY or anywhere else. Here I wanted to see a different culture.It's small, you see it in 2h or less (depending of course on your pace). We really enjoyed the permanent exhibition but loved the temporary one by Oscar Munoz.To go for restaurants after, you either walk a bit or just get a cab, there isn't much stuff around.

Do not miss this. This is a great museum, a must go. Do not miss ABAPURU, by Tarsila do Amaral, probably the most iconic Brazilian painting that unfortunately was sold in an auction to Argentina not too long ago...
outside. The bread is delicious, very tempting it is nice to sit outside. People there are young smart and usually go after visiting the museum. Beware of bag stealers.

Delightful, manageable museum. You can get a sound overview of Latin American art in 20th century and see some innovative exhibits. It is a nice treat and quite affordable - like 4 USD entry. the gift shop and cafe are also nice. It was a great ay to spend a couple hours before heading to the airport.
Very cool. Small, clean, with nice pics and paintings, good for a quick stop. Easy to go and has a mall very close for some shopping after the visit.

Modern Art. I wandered through this amazing, modern museum and was delighted by the exhibits. One of the more interesting exhibits was a live exhibit of a young man and woman in bed in their bedroom just carrying on as though no one else was there. They weren't up to any hanky panky when I was there but it was interesting to see the responses on the other onlookers.

Great Museum. Really enjoyed the MALBA. I went on a Wednesday afternoon so the entrance fee was half off (16 pesos instead of 32). There were a lot of great works well laid out. I really enjoyed the Diego Rivera, Frida Kahlo and Anotnio Berni pieces. The Munoz exhibit on the 3rd floor was wicked! Definitely a great way to spend an hour or two.
Lovely with nice resto. Loved the format and size, and the art; good exhibitions. We had lunch and it was very good, although service was slooow

Pricey but Outstanding Building and Collection. Well worth the walk over from Bellas Artes or Recolecta area. Worth the admission just to see the building but the collection is an eclectic mix well worth an hour or so.

Museum was great - pity about the restaurant.. the Munoz exhibition was great, the Tracy Emin retrospective also well presented. the museum is light, airy and will laid out. Unfortunately the restaurant next to the museum is USELESS - SERVICE is NON Existent - waited 15 mins to get the menus and another 20 before giving up on service - go somewhere else if you want a drink before or after - not only is service lousy but the prices are worse than the restaurants round Recoleta

Impressive collection of Latin American art – and a real bargain in U.S. dollars. A very impressive collection of Latin American art – and a real bargain in U.S. dollars – 22 A$D or about USD $4.50. The architecture of the building is marvelous, especially on a clear day. Was struck with the display of a number of artists – reflecting their work form the late 20s until the 1980s, 90s and into the current century.The attached photos give just a glimpse of the museum’s contents.Exhibits have a full description in Spanish, as well as a full description in English. (This is a real bargain if you are senior from the U.S. – special senior rates.)We passed on the restaurant – there were no tables outside available – service inside seemed to be slow. While waiting we scoped out the menu, and it seemed very over-priced. About five blocks away, we found one of the multitudes of marvelous Palermo Viejo cafes, and had a delicious late afternoon lunch outside – engaging in eating, people and dog watching.

Excellent collection of Latin American art. This museum has a great collection of latin art. It has important pieces from the best times of modern and contemporary art.The architecture of the museum is an attraction as well and the restaurant very good, despite the service not being in best shape.

Like the restaurant better than the museum.. I wasn't impressed with the permanent collection at MALBA. It's actually smaller than I imagined it would be for the price. The best part of this museum is the delicious, trendy restaurant that is attached. Cute outdoor dining area and nice bar. Wonderful lunch fare and great people watching.
Gret museum. One of the best museums in BA. Well laid out with senior discount. lots to see in all rooms and good english discriptions

Amazing!. Abaporu by Tarsila do Amaral. Proud to be Brazilian!
Nice place, small but very, very terrific! Great place!
Small big museum.
A must see. This was one of my favourite museums. The art was fresh and inspiring, and the temporary exhibition of a Rio painter's work was fab. If you go on Wednesdays, it's half-price :-)

Wonderful art and good restaurant too.. This is a lovely building with Latin American Art mostly from the early 20th century, and two other exhibition halls. It also contains an art and architecture library and an excellent restaurant as well as the museum shop. We saw a spectacular exhibition based on photography but containing installations using video and some unusual photographic techniques, the work of Oscar Muñoz. It's amazing, and finishes on Feb 4th 2013. Tip: if you plan to eat there after looking around, book a table on your way in.

Worth a look. Enjoyable and can be completed leisurely in a couple of hours. In a well-designed building in a pleasant neighborhood. The permanent collection is of high quality, though somewhat small in number.

Amazing museum for Latin American art. The building is magnificent (so is the cafe) but it's the modern Latin American art that's breathtaking. Some of the work is so haunting that the images will be forever in our minds.

Small, but nice. the art was a little too modern for me. The videos they were showing were very interesting. Definitely go on a Wednesday when there is discounted price! if you are a student, bring your id!
not much to see. Interesting but a small collection. I would not go if you have just few days for visiting Buenos Aires.
Latin Modern Art. You don't find much modern art from Latin America in US museums, so the MALBA was a great experience. Well organized and a nice cafe as well if you get hungry.

Nice way to spend an hour.. If you want to see some Latin American art and you have a short attention span this is the Museum for you. Great little collection and the price of admission isn't too steep either. You can scoot around it really quickly. The cafe is very expensive so don't plan on eating there.

A great little museum.. Malba museum is filled with great Latin American art. There are different exhibits all the time.
Also has a cute store where you can get gifts.
And a cafe/restaurant with outdoor space. A definite to include on your Buenos Aires tour.

Nice building - nice gift shop. There are some nice pieces on display here, but it is a small collection on display with a lot of second rate art. Still worth a visit if you have time. Bus 67 stops here.

Great place, nice paintings of latinamerican painters and great building. You can see and admire great samples of major latin american painters, some Warhol, on Frida Kalho and many others..If you like arts and architecture you will surely enjoy.

Nice collection. The Diego rivera piece and the Tarsila do Amaral Abipuru are by themselves enough to worth a visit, but I got to know and enjoy many other latin artists. And the shop has cute souvenirs.

Gorgeous building is art in its own right. Loved the collection, but the building and its furnishings are worth the visit; really, really inspiring. When we visited, they were featuring a collection of videos by British artist Tracey Emin; not sure why she was being featured at MALBA, but I really, truly hated this feature. Sorry. Otherwise, I recommend MALBA as a must-see while in BA.
Beautiful building.. Perfect for a Sunday afternoon visit after doing San Telmo in the morning. Delicious and elegant cafe, modern art, outstanding gift shop.

A stellar survey of Latin American art. The title says it all: an impressive collection in a stunning facility that demonstrates the range of contemporary art emerging from South America now. With a stylish restaurant to retire to afterward.
The most interesting museum in BA. If you like modern art and would like to know more about latin american artists it's a perfect place to visit.
Latin American Art. excellent museum, very modern and bright building, I was pleased with the art in display, great pieces by Rivera, Kahlo, Tarsila do Amaral
Recommend to visit!. Good collection of modern paintings and pop-art like Diego Rivera and ndy Worholl and very interesting installations.

Excellent curation in a well-designed setting. This is a really delightful museum. I'm from NYC and accustomed to the likes of the Metropolitan Museum of art, the MOMA and the Guggenheim, and MALBA is a worthy visit even to a museum-spoiled person like me. The building design is terrific, and size-wise, MALBA makes for a perfect morning or afternoon - enough for a few hours but not overwhelmingly large. The permanent exhibits are great and the special exhibits we saw were really exceptional. I was not highly familiar with Latin American art so this was the perfect way to "see" the culture from the perspective of the arts world. They have a very nice but pricey cafe on site that we considered but passed on. It's clearly geared to tourists and the menu looked good but it was fussier than we were in the mood for. But they have nice indoor and outdoor seating so worth a consideration.A great visit!
Nice!. It's always a great pleasure to visit this Museum, if you have time, go to the restaurant for a complete day!

Must See for Architecture. The building itself is a must see for its interesting modern architecture. The art is good too especially the wood bench that wraps the entire museum. The cafe food is very good but service was slow.

Excellent and unique museum, in a great building. I loved this museum - I can't remember the last time I found a collection to be so interesting and memorable. I have very little familiarity with Latin American artists beyond Mexico, and so I found it fascinating, and loved the mixture of different styles and media. It's not a huge museum, so totally doable without getting tired out, and the building itself is also great - I was in love with the benches that were works of art themselves. The gift store was also excellent, with a charming bookstore hidden downstairs, and the cafe was good too! I think Bellas Artes gets more press, but if you only go to one museum in BA, make it MALBA!

Beautiful building with impressive Sth Amerian modern art. A great example of impressive architecture housing beautiful modern art by South American artists. enjoyed seeing Frida Kahlo self portrait too. Interesting visit and glad we did.

Museum seemed unimpresssive, restaurant horrible. I stopped here for information and a beer / snack. The waiters were unattentive to put it nicely, just RUDE to be more realistic. No one would look at us for quite some time, and when we finally stopped to ask someone if they would like us to seat ourselves they hardly even responded, and referred us to "a guy up front" who was not present. When we sat on a sofa where others were served we were litterally ignored and stepped over clumsily three times until our table mates (who we did not know) called the waiter back and asked him to serve us. He responded something along the lines of "not yet" because he had other people to serve. We just left. Don't bother.

Disclaimer: I don't like modern art. ...and so MALBA was a bit tough for me to like. It's a visually interesting space for sure, but the art... I just couldn't get into it. I'm not going to offer a critique because I generally dislike most modern art and I don't consider myself particularly knowledgeable about such, but I think I would have enjoyed sitting in a Recoleta park, staring at a beautiful sculpture.
Modern Art in the City. This museum of contemporary art stands out for its modern architecture as well as their standing collection of contemporary latin american artists
A good private collection. Is nice to see latin art as it is usually far for me. I would have expected more argentinean art but I found art from Mexico and Brazil.

Don't miss this one!. Nothing to dislike about this lovely museum. Excellent architecture & gallery space, a fabulous collection of South American contemporary art, all beautifully displayed. Not only that, I found a number of wonderful Christmas gifts in the museum shop.

Stunning collection of Argentinian Art. Being Monday, many places are closed but not the MALBA. It was thoroughly enjoyable: we went there looking for the iconic masterpiece Manifestacion (demonstration) 1934 by Antonio Berni but were rewarded with much more. The Modeles also by Berni in 1977 was another social statement of our times. la gran tentacion, 1962, was a third we enjoyed. Beyond Argentinian art, the other paintings we recommend are Parejo( couple) by Alejandro Xul Solar, 1923 and the Brazilian Tarsila do Amaral's Abaporu, a visual stunner.

Interesting, but not exciting. Gives a good idea of Latin American Art in a very cool modern building. It also tells the history of the various periods in history quite well but I didn't find it more exciting than interesting.

Very interesting. It's not so bigger but a great museum. Important pieces are in exhibition and the fixed art pieces are from locals and international artists. Attention to discounts (I get 50% because I have a Samsung smartphone). Students get 50%too.
great building bit art not my taste. really enjoyed the visit- but didn't really enjoy the exhibition- don't let that put you offwacky shop and good art book shop

Excellent contemporary Latin American art. This is a great museum. A bit of a hike (on foot) from the Ricoleta Cemetary (about 20 minute walk), but well worth the effort.It looks like a new-ish building, purpose built for displaying the best of Latin American contemporary art over three levels. There is also a nice cafe within the building.Well worth the visit.

Great art, reasonable entrance fee!. Some amazing works in a rather small museum (I'm from Chicago). I saw the entire thing in about an hour, but 1 room on the 1st floor was closed. My favorite was the wooden bench whose slates go from the 1st floor throughout the atrium - Keep an eye out for it!
Its a great place!. The permanent collection has very good material. For transitory expo, you may need some good luck. The building architecture is fantastic and the region in BA one of the best
Outstanding. This gallery is worth the visit. The artworks are fantastic and really showcase the variety of styles and the talent of South America. A really refreshing experience.

Lovely art. A unique introduction and presentation of Latin American artists and modern exhibits as well. They do not translate nor offer English guides so you are on your own to figure out the artwork. The gift shop and cafeteria are not that impressive.citi card holders get 25percent discount.

Great Museum. I really found this museum very well presented. Everything from the architecture to the presentation of the art was excellent. The building brings the outdoor into the building as well. The collection was very good but I found myself wanting more. Oh and don't miss the cafe. The food is excellent and well presented and don't forget the beer and wine, very good.

Beautiful Building, Disappointing Collection. The Malba is in a very nice modern building. Unfortunately, such nice architecture deserves to house better collections. The most interesting piece in the museum was a wooden bench in the hallway, that had the wooden seat slats continue right off one side, down the hall, over the balcony, and down to the next floor where they flowed right into another wooden bench. That was impressive.

Beautiful building and interesting but not outstanding art. Bookshop and giftshop interesting and good cafe restaurant. Museums, in my view, are not up to much in BA, but this is one of the best ones, with elegant architecture and interesting art, but unfortunate conclusion is that whilst USA borrowed from the European tradition and built on it, Argentina just borrowed. But it is a calming and thought provoking break from laid back frenzy in the rest of the city. We had a lovely lunch afterwards on the terrace of the cafe des artes, good fish and salads and nice views.

Samll interest. Thought it would be free on Wednesdays but in fact we had to pay ARG15 each. For that we got to see the permanent collection of Arte Latinoamericano, a whole exhibition of moving circles - press a button you got them to interact with each other and Safari by Matias Duville which was beyond our understanding - particularly the jacket attached to the end of a chain?? That said, sometimes the simplest things are best. In the common corridor we got to sit on a wooden bench - the "tendrils" of which wove themselves across the balconies and around the floor, while mesmerized by the workings of Malla Electrocinetica ll. This a mechanical type oblong that moved, twisted and reshaped itself all by a series of hidden wires. Easy to miss as most people are busy negotiating the escalators. That oblong & the people watching were worth the entrance fee

building as attention-grabbing as the art. It's worth visiting not only because of the art works displayed, but also because of the beautiful modern building. My wife being an architect, she was more interested in the building than the art, actually. Unfortunately many of their important paintings were in an exhibition abroad, but it was still great (I had seen them on a prior visit).
Something different. Not being very familiar with Latin American art this gallery gave a good overview of the wonderful array of latin art.

For modern art lovers. Modern art museum with interesting exhibits. Worth visiting if you are into modern art. Reminds me of Tate Modern in London. One of the attractions worth visiting in Buenos Aires.

Not worth going until they bring back the GREATS!. I paid my £5 entry fee, which isnt that cheap compared to some of the other museums on offer in BA and was pretty disappointed that all the best (most famous) work was somewhere else. I like art but im no expert so i'll just say the rest of the stuff seemed like filler to me. A plate of rotting potatoes or a photo of a scrunched up piece of paper isnt really art in my opinion.

Not the time to go, whole floor closed and best works are in Houston. Great building but missed all their best works shown on website. Very confusing not to see them there and now back at my rental see that they are in Houston for an exhibit. One whole floor was closed to arrange another exhibit and nether of these 2 facts were mentioned when I bought my ticket. Glad it was not too expensive to visit.

Modern art classic style. The building is amazing and you get the feeling of a city that is called Citty of design. For the case of renovating a few rooms some exihibitons unfortunately were closed. Anyway the coffe was fine, too.

Beautiful modern building. Frieda K has gone to Houston, and we missed her.
Well worth a visit for the building alone.
If the exhibits enthral linger.
Nice mix of contents, good idea for a rainy day. This is truly a world class museum, particularly if you like Latin American art. Even the gift shop has unusual and elegant goods for sale.

Nice space, relatively small, ok exhibits.. Nice space with coffee shop and cloakroom for those wet umbrellas. Was smaller than I'd anticipated, enjoyed one of the exhibits but the other one not so much. Entree fee is only USD$3 pp.

Beautiful modern building and good collection. When I first visited Buenos Aires, 20 years ago, this museum did not exist. It was a pleasure to visit it this time. The building is modern and beaufitul and it is lovely to walk around the collections, it is all very fluid. The permanent collection is not big, but there are always temporary ones. This time I enjoyed very much Fernando Bryce´s "Drawing modern art", a collection of drawings depicting images from newspapers,ads, political leaflets etc. The museum has a good coffeeshop, a bit on the expensive side and a bookshop-souvenirs shop as well. Definetely worth visiting!
The best museum in town. You have to go there, of course its not the MET or the Louvre but its worth it. Check the itinerant collections before going, carefull i beleive monday is closed.

Amazing museum!. The building is beautiful with it's architecture and definitely worth a visit. We visited the museum on a Wednesday and also the fees were a bit cheaper than other days. It was very interesting to see some art from local artists. All in all, very nice and I would go there again on my next visit.
Before a movie. Splurge before you go to the cinema or after touring this wonderful museum ( best in BA for contemporary and modern art) have a cappuccino and chock

All the good art is on loan. I really wanted to see the works of the great Latin American artists like Rivera, Kahlo, Botero, and such, but this entire collection was on loan to a museum in Houston. I decided to not go in since what I really wanted to see wasn't there anyway. I left disappointed, but I'm sure when the collection is back it will be worth the entrance fee to go and see! The building is really nice!

Unless contemporary art is your thing.... I'm not so sure on this museum. I consider myself pretty open minded when it comes to art and museums, but this museum was a let down for me. It is a beautiful, modern museum, but all three floors are practically bare (excluding the exhibit on the third floor). I'm not the biggest fan of contemporary art, however the lack of art work was what bothered me. Go if you enjoy a minimalist and contemporary approach to art. Otherwise, I'd most defiinitely recommend a coffee at their cafe, particularly the outdoor cafe, it is very beautiful, albeit slightly expensive!
Interesting Museum. We liked the location and most of the exhibits. It was a cultural experience for my teenage son . However; we were not impressed with the 2nd floor exhibit.

What is art?. The nearest subway station is Scalabrini Ortiz (Linea D), after you get there you must walk around 20 minutes to get to the museum.The time a person spends at a museum varies a lot, but if this is your only attraction at the neighborhood consider doing some other things nearby as well ("Jardim Botanico" is my tip).The museum has a good atmosphere with a gift shop and a snack bar at the ground floor.

small, but interesting. I visited this museum while in BA on business. The museum is small, but the price is very reasonable ($25 pesos, I believe), and there are some interesting pieces. I enjoyed the historical ads and 3D art. The area is lovely as well.

A beautiful modern art museum in a great environment. Located in a beautiful neighbourghood this museum is smaller than what the architecture suggests from the outside but still hosts great permanent and temporary collections. Tickets are very cheap for international standards.It is modern art at its best and illustrates the most relevant Latinamerican movements. If you are looking for older modern art you should probably go to MAM insteadFilms are an extra asset but be ready for queuing up as it is very popular with students in particular and population at large.The shop includes some very interesting pieces but pricy . The cafeteria looks to the gardens and has a very good selection of pastries and dishes. Wines are good even when maybe not that cheap. The "dulce de leche" brulee a real finding and coffe selection enjoyable.The Paseo Alcorta mall just five minutes away may complete a very enjoyable day if you are not that into art.If you are into art you may first go to Museo Sivori and then finish at Malba with a nice dinner. In any case you may want to check with the museum net site before going to any, with almost 200 museums in Buenos Aires you can chose exactly what you want to see.
Great art!. Fantastic collection of Latin American art in a very modern setting. Definitely recommend.

Nothing mind blowing here - except the crossaints!!. This review is mainly about the cafe attached to this musuem, you have to get the crossaints here, they are only $1.50 (AUS) and taste divine!! Also, DO NOT get a taxi in front of the museum (or any touristy places), flag one down from the street. These taxi's parked in front of MALBA will try to rip you off if they find out you're not local. Be careful.

Not Impressed. Went to the Malba and was hoping to see traditional Latin American Art, however the art was extremely modern and abstract. There was barely any traditional art and in my opinion the art did not represent Latin America, it represented more of a modern art movement that included pop culture and political issues. Also, unless you're a big fan of contemporary art don't plan on spending too much time at this museum. Most of the paintings barely have a descriptions besides the artist's name. All in all I was not impressed with the Malba, and after all I have heard about it I was expecting much more.

Cool building, great art but limited collection. I love a modern art museum, so i headed to the Malba to see what it had to offer. The building is great, really light and airy, and the art that they have on display is nice. However, i was surprised by the small size of the collection. Would have liked it to be a bit bigger
Exciting, innovative pieces. This gallery of modern and contemporary art is certainly worth a visit. it is not a huge gallery, but it has a good range of mediums from the artists on display.
Great find for art lovers. Beautiful building for displaying art in convenient location. Reachable on public transport. Best of new latin american artists.

Not so good. Visited this museum yesterday- kids at elementary could do better when it comes to "art". I hoped to see works of Diego Rivera and Frida Kahlo but they were traveling. Instead there were some pathetic excuses for what some call pop-culture. The fee for the entrance was 60 pesos/couple.DON't waste your time.
overrated museum. Much more fanfare than needed. Its ok museum but nothing exceptional.
No art there. Almost all of their paintings,like Frieda Kahlo and Diego Riveira is in Huston right now. It is far togo to visit the museum and the staff isn't very helpful

MALBA. I guess I thought that this museum would be something completely different. I'm not a huge fan of modern art. I just don't get it, and honestly I don't want to. The website showed a nice mix of modern and classical art, so I was looking forward to this museum. The first exhibit was Bye Bye American Pie, which was very interesting. It claims to show the US from the 1970's to present, however it was mostly a collection of pictures of people taking drugs and lots of pieces of 'art' that were just a blown up map of Iraq with words 'painted' on it. It was a very depressing, and hardly encompassed anything of value. The 'live' animatronic was bizarre as the heads looked more like Abe Lincoln than GW, but the point was very clear.The rest of the museum was a collection of modern 'art' photographs, which is basically photoshopped pictures. Overall I was disappointed in the lack of real art, and was surprised that this museum was very small. I would skip this museum, unless you can't get enough of modern 'art.'
Always First Choice When Doing Museums. Like most Museums, if the like the current exhibition, you'll like the Museum. This is a modern, world class, clean & excellent institution. Don't miss.

Nice to do on a rainy day. We were supposed to go to Polo Elite, but it was cold and rainy. So our concierge told us to go to MALBA. Long but nice walk from Palmero Soho. Not expensive but the museum is very small. A good Starbuck nearby.

Excellent museum in the heart of Buenos Aires. Worth a visit, a contemporary museum well laid out and with many contemporary Latin American artist. Does not take long for a visit, nor is it expensive, but some very different exhibits.
Building stunning, paintings sparse.. Dissapointed that Latin American artists such as Frida Kahlo were not represented
Malba museum. Very interesting art museum in Buenos Aires, many important collections.
Beautiful space for art. The building is beautiful, with plenty of diffused, natural light. The art work is mostly modern. A lovely place to spend a few hours.
Great building lousy exhibit. What a beautiful facility wasted on boring, lackluster art.

Modern Artwork from Latin American Artists. Nice collection of modern artwork from LatAm artists. Don't miss the piece called "Enramaderas" which is a set of wooden benches on the second and third floor that interconnect through flowing branches.

Very nice museum but many of the Latin American artists were on loan to other museums.. We began by purchasing the guide at the store and getting the audio guide which is very helpful.The second and third floor contains most of the Argentinian Artist but also some Andy Warhall's. The exhibits are fantastic. Unfortunately we found out some of the well known Latin American artists were on loan to other museums in the US. So if you want to see some great Boteros, you will have to go to Houston, Diego Rivera go to New York and Kahlo go to Los Angeles.We finished by having lunch at the restaurant which was superb. I had a mineral water and the salad which was fantastic. The service was attentive. They first bring delicious breads and 4 different types of dips.
A Stunning Art Museum. This art museum has wonderful exhibitions of modern art and is a must see part of any visit to BA. There is a very attractive cafe attached.

A great house for art!. This is a great modern facility, with plenty of great spaces. It's permanent & rotating collections are a good insight into how Latin cultures have adapted through the different periods of artistic expressions, challenging social, political and religious conventions.

Good collection, shocking exhibition.. Awesome Latin art and great installations of the benches that become hanging art.When we were there the 'bye bye American pie' exhibition was pretty shocking. Mainly Larry Clark's photos of going home to Oklahoma and shooting drugs and living 'regular American life.' It still churns my stomach. I really liked it because photographs have never done that to that extent before. Not a really great feeling leaving the place though.The cafe was great too. ordered a coffee and then a wine - and both came with free little bites to eat. Little brownie squares and a little cheesy bread thing with horseradish sauce. Just glad I ate before the exhibition. Not for the faint of heart.

We loved it!. Very nice museum. We saw "Tarsila do Amaral" and much other. Organized, clean, great atmosphere. The restaurant / cafe inside the museum is pretty good also. We had lunch one day and everything was awesome! It's one of the best programs in BA for sure.
beautiful building. a beautiful building, an interesting collection, skip the restaurant overprized.

The MoMA of BA!. MALBA is really the MoMA of BA, from the crowd to the artwork. The people watching is just as interesting as MoMA, if not better due to the latin vibe. Exhibition space is great, the size of the museum is not overwhelming and can be done if a few hours. A must see for art lovers!

Impressive Building but Miserable Collection. I can't recommend a visit to this museum. The collection is not very interesting and the temporary exhibit, Bye Bye American Pie is the most outrageously anti-American thing I have seen anywhere. It was awful.

Good collection. The museum is very interesting but I was very disappointed to find out that the Constantini Collection, which reunite Tarsila do Amaral, Frida Kahlo, Diego Rivera and other important LA artists is off till October-2012. I believe the museum should make that clear on their website!

Nice Collection and Building. The permanent collection is so-so and the individual experience will hinge on the rotating collections, but we enjoyed MALBA. Spaces are well designed and the entire visit can be done in 2-3 hours. The attached cafe and patio is also worth a stop although prices are on the high side.
Nice building.. Current exhibit provocative without being memorable. Cafe overpriced.

A disappointment. Many of the guidebooks tout this place as the finest museum in Buenos Aires. I would not go that far. First, there was an expectation that we were going to see some of the great iconic contemporary Latin American artists like Diego and Frida. However, the collection, or a vast part of it, is on tour in the United States. Instead they have two temporary exhibitions, one of which was called "Bye, Bye American Pie" which was of second rate American contemporary artists whose premises is to display the decline of the American dream. Great! Just what we need to ge touring the world! We were not impressed. The building itself is spectacular. The front line staff were less than welcoming and spent more time talking to each other in personal conversations, than paying attention to visitors and assiting them. There is also no map guide for the museum so you have to blindly find your way through the museum. For the money, I think you would be better off at the Collection of Amalie Fortabat in Puerto Madero -which has a combination of traditional and contemporary art from mostly Argentine artists.

Wonderful building and marvelous exhibits. This is a beautiful building with a fabulous collection that at times is shocking and other times playful. The restaurant serves first rate food and the patio is absolutely delightful. We saw the "Bye Bye American Pie" exhibit and were introduced to some American artist we knew nothing about before. It seems part of their permanent display is not available for view right now which was disappointing. We have however seen plenty of Kahlo and Diego exhibits in other places.

What happened to Frida and Diego?. MALBA is a magnificent art gallery with lots of room for displaying work by Latin American artists, so it was unfortunate that the big show in place for our visit was a selection of works by US artists, gathered under the title "Bye Bye American Pie". Not really an impressive collection at that -- there are many US artists who have done more interesting or challenging work to select from. What bothered us was that promotional material and guidebook listings for the gallery all promise works by Frida Kahlo, Diego Rivera, and others -- but none are currently on display.

Great visit on a rainy day!. Small museum, great permanent collection and good expos.Loved the "bye bye american Pie" expo.The Café Malba is a must for lunch. The food was amazing. Expensive but worth the price.
interesting if small museum. nice exhibits, not as extensive as i expected but i enjoyed myself.

If you like modern art, don't miss. This is a beautiful museum. We were there in between exhibitions so unfortunately did not see all, but what we did see was well worth the admission. The permanent collection is well curated so that you can see relationships between art works. I would have liked an English audio guide. The cafe looked great and I was sorry to not be there at mealtime, but the cappuccino and croissant were delicious.

Modern and interesting. Great way to spend an afternoon enjoying art. There are different expos that change. Very interesting, Beautiful art work of Latin American artist. I also recommend having a cup of coffee in their cafe. If you are an art lover it is a must.

If You Can't View the Art, Have Lunch. See what's showing here before you go. Most of the galleries were closed when we attended. Not a lost trip at all, though, because we took advantage of the restaurant and had a foodie lunch to die for amid fashion forward-clad patrons.

Fantastic Art Collection!. The Bye, Bye American Pie exhibit really tested your mettle! Unfortunately, a lot of their permanent collection was on loan to Houston Art Museum. Overall, a great experience and well worth visiting!
Great cafe. The day was hot and humid and we needed a break so we headed to the cafe at MALBA. The decor is stylish and the coffee is wonderful.

Do not miss MALBA. This Latin Art museum had a very modern edge to it, and most of the art we saw was also in the "modern" category. Take your time to enjoy the art, building, decor and people watching including the deck on the second floor. There is also some interesting history about the museum on the lower level. The cafe is a must stop so plan for a meal before or after your visit.
cool place. i liked everything. loved the artist that was presenting.

The atmosphere was good but it was too small for the most important museum of Buenos Aires. The location is good and it isgood too take look around and have a coffee in the museum coffee shop which is very nice. but the museum is too s.mall and you can visit it in less than one hour .
Eye Opening. We were most struck by the clear telling of the Argentine history through the art. The emotion in the paintings and installations was palpable.
A fresh look at modern Latin American Art. Lovely Museum, unpretentious, modern and a fresh look at Latin American art and artists which I knew little about.
nice. It was a nice visit. The exhibitions that were on show were a bit adult for all tastes though. The museum is a bit small as compared to similar ones in europe.

Beautiful building; solid collection. Go there for the chair sculptures that flow from one floor to another, the excellent museum cafe, and the interesting architecture of the building. The collection is quite avant garde; if you're looking for something strikingly different to MoMA/ Tate Modern etc then this could be well worthwhile.
Average Modern Art Collection. Thought it will be a very nice one but very limited collection. Try to visit Museum of Bella Arte much better
