Good contemporary art. Unfortunately, the second floor with the permanent collection was closed while we were there, but the current exhibition was enjoyable.
Quite interesting. We liked a few displays and found some surprising, couldn't understand the modern art. The cafe outside is excellent.

terrific modern collection!. The range of modern art, both latin american and north american, is phenomenal and the space and book store are terrific, not to mention yummy restaurant. Not cheap but worth it.

Lovely Visit. We were told by our local guide to go see the MALBA and we were really glad we did. The place is new bright and the exhibits which were from South American artists were most interesting.When we were there the main artist on display was from Venezuela and his works were imaginative and lively using light. It was a visit we thoroughly enjoyed.
small but very nice collection. the museum is rather small but the collection is quite nice.....a bit hard to locate but, worth the effort

Outstanding museum!. Beautiful building that is easy to walk in it and stimulating, well displayed art that ranges from the well know Kahlos and Spilimbergos to the new gloriously outlandish and innovative . The building sits in what I consider the most beautiful neighborhood in all Buenos Aires, with open green spaces. It has a restaurant with poor inattentive service, expensive but good food, and one of the best Negroni I ever had outside Rome's Cafe Canova, great to sip in a nice day amidst the greens that surrounds the restaurant.

A don't miss attraction -the best of the muses. We saw a wonderful exhibit of kinetic art by Carlos-Diego Curz in this magnificent museum.the design of the building brings in natural light. Check online to see what is being exibited. Have lunch in the busy cafe.
Interesting building, not much on display at the time. We must have been there "between seasons" as the amount of art actually on display was minimal. Very interesting building, nice cafe.
Wonderful building, so-so collection. The best stuff is on loan to Houston MFA for several months.Stuff on display is mainly 50s adn 60s, but interesting enough.
One of the best in Buenos Aires. Very modern design. Interesting building. Don't miss out the cafe of the museum.
Color and space exhibition. A wonderful exhibition of works of Carlos Cruz-Diez, all about color and light and perspective. So happy I managed to see it.
Great modern art!. Wish the permanent collection had been open, it was closed when we were there as they changed it. Terrific modern Museum and nice restaurant to boot!

Good introduction to Latin American modern art. MALBA is a small museum, but had a nicely curated collection of Latin American modern art. The cafe attached to the museum offered an excellent lunch afterwards.

MALBA. Both you and your teen aged children will enjoy a visit to MALBA. Quite a variety of contemporary art. The building itself is note-worthy. And the staff are wonderful, very helpful in getting us to our next destination.

Exhibition is closed so wait till it will re-open. We were greatly disappointed as we have heard so much about the collection in MALBA. However all exhibition was relocated to Houston. So not worth getting to the museum right now

Seemed all new even second time. I went here for a second time with some people who had not been. I enjoyed it just as much the second time. The exhibits are great and when you are on a trip where you are doing lots of activities, the size is just right. You can spend two hours easily, but also go quicker if you want. The store is cute and the restaurant has a great atmosphere, although I have only gotten drinks there.

Incredible!. This place is very special! The building itself is modern, with nice lines, full of sculptures. The galleries are just stunning! I was very glad to be in front of works of Tarsila do Amaral, Ligia Clark, Portinari.... It is one of the best - if not the best - museum of latin american art of the world.

A Great Building with Interesting Art. The building in which MALBA is housed is wonderful. It rivals and to some degree reminds us of the MOMA in NYC and the interior of the Guggenheim in Bilbao. The building it self is worth the trip. The art was extremely interesting. Highly recommended.
Brilliant architecture and fascinating art. the airy spaciousness and excellent curating. And a great cafe.
Worth a visit once the permanent collection opens again. Saw a great exhibit by Carlos Cruz-Diez. Were disappointed that the permanent collection was closed so we didn't see anything else.
Excellent Collections of SA art. Not an extensive collection, but a good representation of SA art and culture. The museum is easy to do in a couple of hours between lunch and afternoon tea.
Argentina 2012. Good collection of fun Carlos Cruz-Diez 'physiochromes' (change colour as you walk past them) and other Latin American artists

great modern art. there is a fantastic exhibit right now, "Carlos Cruz-Diez: El color en el espacio y en el tiempo". It's only until March 11, 2012 (I believe). The standing collection was interesting, but it was really that traveling exhibit by Cruz that blew me away!

Nice Museum, but not that much too see. Went to the museum to check out what BA had to offer for Modern Art and it was o.k., glad I paid the student admission. The exhibit on the 3rd floor dealing with "colors" was pretty cool and the other two floors had a couple works from famous Latin artists. Maybe I just don't get artwork, but hoped the museum would be a bit bigger.
Modern Arts of Argentina. If you like modern art, this place is a must. it is near Palermo park - nice place to spend the day at the Gallery and at the park

nothing special. One of the few museums open on the first day we arrive in BA (carnival) so we had few choices. Worthwhile if you have lots of time to take in the sights but skip it if on a tight schedule
Awesome Gallery. The MALBA was great. A wonderful collection of modern art and excellent exhibition space. Coffee shop also worth a visit.
The best art collection en South America in a beautiful environment. Do not miss and take advantage of the great movies programmed in their cultural agenda.

A "must" if you are interested in Argentine culture. I live close to the museum and sometimes I find some free time to visit Malba. As soon as you enter, you'll see a beautiful painting of De La Vega and will enjoy not only the rest of the collection but also the building design itself.By the way, there is a small restaurant with good food inside (you can eat there even without visiting the museum)If you have some spare time after that, you'll find yourself in a very nice area of the city, close to the beautiful parks (for example, El Rosedal)

Good museum. Went here on a Saturday just after they opened. Fun exhibits, good artwork, audio tour okay not great. Would have liked a lot quieter group of visitors. Everyone was talking loudly, much different than what we see here in the States.
Well worth a visit. A great art gallery - a bit like the Tate Modern. Over several floors and with a lovely restaurant - great for lunch.
A very fine Art Gallery. Perhaps the best private collection of latinamerican painters in the world! Excellent
Nice South American art museum. The greatest paintings of South American artists are here. Worth the visit.
I dislike museums but loved this place!!!. Lots of fun, interactive. Only some of the descriptions also had english but there was a good commentary in English which really helped!

Can be Missed. We were disappointed in the collection...we visited last week and thought we would be in for a treat....all I can say is that it was not expensive, great bathrooms, very nice cafe with excellent service...not my usual comments about an art museum. Building is interesting and liked the layout just needs to add to their collection of we need more appreciation!

Expensive and litle to see. Too big name for a too small collection.Is a private business museum-gallery. One thinks will see hundred works of Latin American well known painters . Is only 1 (one ) from Frida Kalho, Diego Rivera, Botero , end 2-3 more.The rest of the huge building is occupied by experimental works of mondern artists with works not to the taste of everyone.
A short but interesting trip. The temporary exposition worth the trip. The coffee next the museon is hideously expensive.
great lunch. a very good museum restaurant with good food, wine, but slow service
MALBA Visit. Excellent medium sized museum with a fine collection of SA art.
Wonderful Small Museum. Easy to see most of the works in a reasonable amount of time. Wonderful, colorful, exciting art. A favorite stop in B.A.!

Excellent. MALBA is in a beautiful building and includes a wide range of Latin American art, including many cutting-edge modern pieces. But the highlight of my visit was a exhibition of Op Art paintings by Carlos Cruz-Diez, which clearly traced the development of the artist's signature style, particularly his Physichromie series.It was a 45-minute walk from my hotel in Palermo to the museum, which took me through several parks and past a number of monuments. Discounts on admission are available if you are Citibank customer (even if the card is issued outside Argentina).
MALBA. A private colection made public for all of us to see. Beautifull works of art, beautifull place to see them

Malba just right for a couple of extra hours. The beautiful Malba museum in Buenos Aires is a three story complex with a number of spectacular pieces by well known artists such as Rivera and Kahlo. You could hit two of Buenos Aires' finest museums such as Malba with the National Arts because they are close to one another and compact within the same day. The four of us really enjoyed this place. Tip: Nice discount on entry on Wednesdays.....

Nice collection. This was the most pricy museum I visited (but still cheap compared to the US) and there were a number of interesting exhibits. The architecture of the building is pretty cool too, and the museum is surrounded by beautiful parks of Palermo

Good architecture - a good gallery. MALBA is located in a nice part of BA and is well worth a couple of hours' visit. The focus is in the art (mainly painting) of Latin America, and there will probably be some special or travelling exhibition as well. The current (to 11 March 2012) exhibition of the Venezuelan "line" artist, Carlos Cruz-Diez, is stunning.
Excellent museum. Excellent latin american Museum. There is a famous Frida Kahlo painting and a very nice latin american collection. Worth to visit

excellent latin american art works. i loved the museum! It was better than I expected with great art works from latin american artists (not just diego rivera and frida kahlo). Very colourful and loved the temporary exhibition from carlos cruz-diez, el color en el espacio y el tiempo.Go on wednesdays as it is only $AR 12. Late opening from 12 am.

A must. It's a must. Beautiful place to visit; beautiful architecture; beautiful paintings. You will find from Frida Kalho's, Diego Rivera's to Modern Art. Also, you may find interesting to visit the microcinema where indie films are shown. I remember being able to watch "Metropolis" (the extended version which was found in Argentina) with live music and found myself delighted by the experience.If you're a student, you have discounts on Wednesday if you show your Student Card.

Great place to spend a couple of hours. Interesting modern building with some excellent works - look out for touring exhibitions. A cinema offers historic movies. Avoid the associated cafe/restaurant; surly staff and slow service.
Worth seeing. It is not that large of a museum so you can fit it in to a tight schedule. Interesting collection.
Just a warning - closed on Tuesdays. My friends who visited said that everything about the museum was great. Unfortunately, I chose Tuesday to visit and it was closed. Sorry I missed it.
Small, but interesting. We enjoyed our visit to MALBA, although we were surprised at how small the museum was. Loved the funky benches they have there!

Culture and a good lunch. A lovely place to go on a wet afternoon. It doesn't open until after mid day but they have a delightful restaurant for lunch and it does the most wonderful pastries for a mid morning coffe before exploring the delights of the gallery. You can take a tour which is most informative or just pick up a guide book and wander at leisure
Impressive. Beautiful building; our guide did a rapid tour of the highlights of modern and contemporary south American art, though I got a little overwhelmed by the end and wandered off

Interesting. I liked the Diego Rivero and Frida Kahlo on display, as well as the contemporary Latin American artists and special exhibition. You can get here by bus. The building itself is beautiful and there's a nice cafe there too.
Well worth the time.. A great museum, it can take hours to go through; we were here for a month so had the time for an in-depth visit.

Partners with the Museum of Fine Arts of Houston. The contemporary art in the survey of Latin American art 1910-2010 was weak, but the work before 1960 was worth the visit. The highlight of the museum while we were there was the retrospective of the color "physichromies" by Venezuelan artist Carlos Cruz-Diez. Absolutely, magnificent. Malba is definitely worth a visit when new shows are installed. Nice cafe.
Great modern art museum. Loved this museum's architecture and special shows. And enjoyed lunch on the patio!

From the Art to the Cafe--Excellent!. We were happy to find an excellent cafe at this Museum. The Latin Artworks, especially the work by Carlos Cruz Diez, was intriguing and engaging. A must see in BA.

Well prepared to welcome.. The museum has an excellent architecture and light. It is very well built for a museum.It's a shame you can not take pictures of the interior.It has a very nice restaurant for light meals.It's a smooth ride for the afternoon.
exceptional modern art. if you are into modern art this is a must see. entry a bit pricey though.

Beautiful Museum . . . Great Experience. Ended our visit to BA at the MALBA. The featured exposition was outstandng, the architecture of the building amazing and the gift shop had interesting items for purchase. A must see even if you don't like art.

Always speechless at this place. Great architecture, great Latin American art. What else would I want from this fantastic place? Oh, and they've got this trendy café where lots of famous locals convene! Just go see Malba!
Well worth a visit. Really exciting exhibitions, and relatively small and easy to get around.

Exciting museum - very classy. It is a great experience on a beautiful day when the architecture really sings. The collection is interesting and amusing and in some cases, provacative. We enjoyed it very much!
A wonderful museum. They have a good permanent collection and they had a show by Carlos Cruz-Diez while we were there. I highly recommend this show which runs through 5 March, 2012.

Good place to see in BA.. This museum has a fine collection of works of art and interesting work in one of the runners who will not reveal the surprise to be as nice as it was to me. I enjoyed the visit and understand worthwhile.

Very interesting. We can´t take photos inside, but outside we can: there are inusitate work of arts. I enjoy it.
Good to go with children.

Not a very large museum, but several great works of art. We were lucky enough to see a retrospective of Carlos Cruz Diez, a master in kinetic and op art. Truly worth a visit if you can make it.The permanent collection is small, but has some impressive pieces, including several from Xul Solar that far outclass the paintings in the Xul Solar museum, as well as art from Diego Rivera and Frida Kahlo, among others.The most enjoyable piece is a long bench, that transforms into a vine and goes from the second to third floors. Playful and thoughtful.Only complaint: there are absolutely no signs regarding photography anywhere in the pamphlet or the museum. However, if you try to take a photo, you get yelled at. And, apparently, you are allowed to take phots of some pieces or art. There is no information about which pieces you can photograph and which you cannot, and this led to a frustrating stroll through the museum. The art, though, carries the day.
Great museum. I always went Malba when I'm in BA. They have important works of latin america artists and showcases of important portraits like Andy Wharol.

Good food, good setting, inattentive service. We hit MALBA just before lunch hour and were shown right in. 17 minutes later, a waitress brought bread and arranged for agua. 11 or 12 minutes later, I flagged a guy down to take the orders. To get out, I tracked a third person down -- who promptly forgot about my payment and my card. A fourth guy found the card and accepted payment. Oh! Did I mention the food was really top flight?
Architecture outshines the art collection. The building is modern and first rate, but the art collection is somewhat thin--substantial contemporary collection and well displayed.
Explore. Go. Just go there. Has its similarities to MOMA in New York, and European influence of architecture. Exhibitions vary, but high international standard
Best museum. Great exhibition, well mountedCovered spectrum of south american art and art history

Interesting. Great art, very cool building. Cafe outside nice way to end it. Tip: probably should have rented the audio tour. Not a lot of explanation of the order of the museum or the art without it. But defn recommended...
Nice way to spend an hour or so. Eclectic but not particularly exciting collection. Fabulous art book store.
What a place. Plenty of very nice paintings and art in a magical place in Buenos Aires. Not no miss
Interesting art in a great building. Lots of cool stuff to see if you are fan of modern art and the building is very unique.
Great museum. We enjoyed seeing all the art in this museum, the contemporary art nicely complemented the other cultural sightings throughout the city. It was well worth a visit!

Terrific.. very colorful... nice break. We spent about an hour at the MALBA after touring the city. It was quite colorful, very airy, well laid out and had many interesting modern pieces. Well worth a visit.
Impressive Museum. The displays were well organized and well-explained for those (like me) who can read simple Spanish. There is also an excellent restaurant where you can stop for lunch.

Interesting small art museum. On Wednesdays it is half off and it will take only an hour of your time to visit this museum that houses Latin american art by artists such as Diego Rivera and Frieda Kahlo. If this is your thing, it is worth a visit.
Good Service but Expensive. Superb Seafood Plater. Salads also good. When the bill came I was not so happy. however Service was good, and the Outside tables are great. Think 40 USD ahead
you shouldn't leave Buenos Aires without visiting the MALBA. great location, great building, great collection. just go and see for yourself!
Very unique. The art was very different and unique and I wished I had time to walk through again.

Do not miss. As the name implies, represents a good sample of what is best in the art of Latin America. With only two hours (1.5 hours for the exhibition and a half hours for a coffee), you will be happy to see the great masters of painting. Do not miss.
Excelente acervo e belíssima arquitqtura.. Vale a visita ao MALBA . Apesar de pequeno, tudo é muito belo e oraganizado.
Small But Worth a Visit. Various Latin American artists and photographers. If you want to be up-to-date on their works, this is the museum to visit. Big space in a modern building.

Go To Enhance Your South American Experience.. We thoroughly enjoyed the art on display at this modern museum. It was delightful, entertaining, experiential, and enhanced our appreciation for South American artists. Plan on one to two hours to see everything. Information is not available in English. And don't forget to visit the gift shop for some very nice and original items.

Modern museum in the middle of the city. visiting MALBA is a good plan, irrespective of the display of the moment. there is a nice bar "al fresco" to have a drink or relax before or after visiting the museum and the area where it is has really nices streets and houses with embassies that is worth it for a walk.

Beautiful building, great price and a wonderful collection worth an afternoon visit.. Malba is a wonderful museum and good respite from afternoon heat while in BA. The permanent collection and building is worth the admission. 25 pesos, Thursdays through Sunday and 12 pesos on Wednesday with discounts for seniors, children and students.The museum's collection can be viewed within an hour but more time is well spent on admiring the layout of the entire building, its contents and even the dining experience. The museum cafe is high priced but the food is very good and the atmosphere is quite nice.I would definitely recommend a visit to this museum with children and would visit again.

Great collection - a must see for Art lovers. While spending a few days in BA visiting the main attractions, we decided also to look into this great place.The architecture is modern and appealing and in fact worth visiting itself.The changing collections focus on modern art with a bias towards presenting SouthAmerican artists. This was refreshing to us as we are used to European artist mainly in European exhibitions and museums.
Skip It. Unless you are a true art fan, which we weren't, I would recommend skipping this museum. It was fairly small and is only for true art lovers.

A Very Different Modern Art Museum. This museum had creative modern art that was very interesting. We only spent about 1 hour there, and that seemed to be enough. It is not a large museum, but a good collection. It has a cafe next to it, which was very crowded, but looked nice. The bookstore has interesting things as well.
Perfect place!. Charming and loving place. Good tomeat too! Small and good acervo.
wow!. What a beautiful museum, with a fabulous exhibit of Latin American artists, most of whom were new to us.
modern art. not a fan of modern art. architecture is great though. not a very big museum. mostly it seemed visiting exhibition stuff. crowded to get into, but not too bad once in.
Interesting art, lovely building. Just as advertised, it's contemporary Latin American art, beautifully displayed.
Wonderful modern art.... Great exhibits showcasing more modern tastes. Go on a Wednesday to get cheaper prices...and bring student IDs!
Great Museum. Modern location with a lot of artworks and expos. Beatifull location.
relevant. If you like art, don't miss it. A great selection of latin american art. Great book and art store.

Interesting Art.. The galleries with fisicromias is unlike anything we have ever seen in the world. Quite Fascinating. The Chair that grows from one side and joins another bench on the next level fascinated my son. There was plenty to see and a pricey restaurant cafe that served an interesting curried chicken sandwich - excellent.

Interesting collection for Modernistas. An interesting structure whose collection can easily be enjoyed in an hour. A handful of significant pieces which are of interest to aficionados of modern art, Fabulous temporary exhibit of works by Carlos Cruz Diez that will extend into spring.

Enormous Gallery. On certain sundays the admission is free, although i do not mind paying the entrance fee as MALBA always has new and exciting exhibits on display. For instance, the last time i visited, a gallery focused solely on the works of an artist who shaped wood and painted it different colors, causing a hologram effect as you would walk past. They also have loads of classical style paintings and more modern art and photograph exhibits as well!

Nice building and good way to spend an hour. I visited the MALBA when it was raining. It's a very airy and modern building that's two floors of modern Latin American art. It was smaller than I thought it would be and there aren't that many exhibits. There is a nice cafe where you can find lots of business people having lunch and coffee. I suggest you go on Wednesdays, because they offer a discount on your ticket. It costs $22 AR every day except on Wednesdays, when it's $10 AR. Also, all the signs are in Spanish so you may want to rent an audio guide if you want English explanations. All in all, it was a nice way to spend a couple of hours out of the heat. It's right across the street from the Paseo Alcorta Mall in Palermo so you can browse through the mall after your visit.
Good overpriced museum.. Great Museum, a bit pricey, good sample of latin america artists. Not central location.

Excellent look at Latin American modern art. I can't ever remember seeing modern art from Latin America as part of big exhibit in the United States. So it was eye opening and impressive to see the great creative talents that I have never seen before. The layout of the museum is interesting and the art incorporated into the passageways. Definitely go check it out.

Great stop for a rainy day. A very nice musuem, especially on a rainy day. Spent 3 hours here enjoying the artwork of Latin American artists. Went on a Wednesday which is half price (free for me as a student). A great value. Had lunch in the restaurant which was priced at American standards but the food was very good and the people watching was great. Also visited the book store in the basement below the regular store, a great selection of art books, spent one hour here also.
gorgeous place. have a look at their exhibitions....contemplate and just feel well. definitely a must go !!! really liked it.
Beautiful Building. Not too large. Interesting Modern Art. Near Carrefour

An OK Art Museum with a decent cafe. MALBA was a bit disappointing with its curation. I was expecting it to have a bigger roster, but it was enjoyable. There were some young Latin American artists that were interesting to see, but I wish it had more. The cafe was pretty decent and provided light lunch fare, which was a nice break from all the steak and empanadas and pasta. Nice architecture and space.

Buenos Aires is not really a museum town. I don't think people go to BA to see art museums. MALBA is OK, on a par with an average small city art museum in the US (I don't think it even approaches Buffalo or Cleveland, much less L.A. or even Fort Lauderdale), but it might be OK for a rainy afternoon if you don't have anything else to do. I would prefer to visit one of the better shopping malls than spend time at MALBA. The spaces are nice, but there's nothing special to see there. Now, if you do want to see a great museum in Argentina, travel down to Trelew in Patagonia and see the Paleonthology Museum. Not only does it have great bones, but it really explains paleonthology in a way that even I could understand.

A Must do albeit a bit boring. Not a super huge museum fan, but knew I had to go to Malba. The artwork was pretty cool, the place was nice, and definitely something that everyone should see when they go to BA.

If you like modern art. Spacious and modern, the MALBA has great exhibitions all year around. For those who like modern art, from 1920 to now. There's also a cinematheque presenting various movies, like horror movies after midnight.
It is really worth visiting. It is a very nice and pleasant museum with great expositions there
Worth a visit - especially if it rains!. Very well-organised and reasonably prices art gallery - but a pity there isn't more older/more classical Argentinian art.
shop. when I got there it was still closed, so when it opened I only had time to enter the store, smaller than I expected
great fun, imaginative, cool. great fun, imaginative, cool.What more can I say that has to fill 50 words!

Intriguing, daring. While I was familiar with only a few of the artists with work displayed in this museum, I really enjoyed my visit. The Carlos Cruz Diez exhibit is really fascinating with works that change color depending on which way you're looking at them. The works of art throughout the museum are alternatively thought provoking, shocking, beautiful and inspiring. The ticket price is much lower than what you would pay for an art museum in New York or Paris, so it is definitely worth an hour of your time in Buenos Aires.

Frustration!. I expected so much from this museum. the external architecture is fine but inside, it was a flop! Perhaps it's not so bad, but the point is if you like traditional art, like I do, and despise modern art, you will not like it. That's my case, if it is yours too, this is not the museum for you.

Pretty cool!. Not a big contemporary art fan, but everyone says you have to go to the MALBA in BA. The place was really nice (I really liked the cafe!) but the art didn't really peak my interest and I got a bit bored!
Fab cafe. Not sure about the actual museum- we shamefully only made it on to the terrace of the cafe where we enjoyed their food and sparkling wine!!! Would strongly recommend it!

Nice Space, Nice Variety. Carlos Cruz-Diaz special exhibition was incredible! The permanent collection has some interesting pieces, and the museum is of manageable size. Entrance is cheap (10 pesos) on Wednesday.

One of the best Musems in Latam!! 10 years now. Although a rather small museums by international standards, this is one of the nicest museums I've visited either in Latam, US or Europe. If you go before 2012, do not miss the Carlos Cruz Diez exposition!! A great Venezuelan artist....you;ll love it.

small, very well curated museum. I don't have the largest attention spans for museums in the first place, but I do love modern art, and after a long day of walking around palermo and seeing the various gardens, this was the perfect, well air conditioned cap to the day. A relatively small collection (compared to the museums in New York and DC that i'm accustomed) with very interesting, modern pieces from Latin American artists to whom I hadn't had much exposure before.
Beautiful Building!. Great small museum if you like contemporary art. You can see it in an hour or 2.
Classy, Cool, Worth Seeing. Very cool space with interesting art you can access and experience within 1 hour. Some museums are daunting - this one is three straightforward floors.

Nice museum. This is a modern building that shows art well. There are three floors but really two that have art. One floor is for their permanent collection and the other is for their visiting exposition. There is a small but nice shop near the front entrance and an outdoor restaurant that looked interesting. I would say this museum is worth seeing.
very nice. a very nice pleace to visitnice architecture and depending on the exibitions a nice time to stay

Great insight into a different type of art. All the exhibitions on Nov 2011 were very unique. It was very refreshing to see a different type of art from the European one. It doesn't open until 12pm and on Wednesday the entry is free.
Brilliant. The best gallery/Museo in BA - even if you don't have much time its worth making the effort to go.

loved every minute. great little museum, great place to get a feel for latin american art.
loved work and range of Antonio Berni
got into restuarant, but found it a little expensive for my poor english wallet :O(

Get the best of Latin American Art. an amazing collection of Madi art, Op art, new figuration, and many other 1900's movements can be seen there, in a beautiful museum. Don't miss the temporaries exhibitions, they are great! (at least the one I saw)

Vale a pena a visita. The arquitecture is beautiful and there are incredible art pieces like the brazilian Abaporu, from Tarsila do Amaral. Besides, you can enjoy nice coffee or tea in the cafeteria with view to a park.
MALBA is an good museum, but it's a bit small.. There are some little valuable pieces and it's good to see the Abaporu masterpiece of Tarcila do Amaral.
If you are an art lover, sure!. Two hours well spent! Too bad the restaurant was packed by the time I left and I had to find somewhere else to have lunch.

An intresting place to visit in Buenos Aires. Excellent collection.
Good cafeteria
A place to understand a litlle bit latin american culture and richness

Modern and time art of Argentina. This museum is very interesting and on most tourist and local agendas, easily accessible by taxi or bus, but a good six to eight blocks from the green subte, Buenos Aires is flat so the walk is good exercise and allows viewing at a more intimate level. Head east and you'll find it from subte d auto palermo. Many docents to help with questions, great place to spend a half day, reasonable admission fee's

Great museum. I found this museum to be fantastic. I tried going Tuesday, but it is closed on Tuesday and went later during the week it is was great. The art was nicer than some of the stuff I have seen here in NY. The bright open space makes it very attractive as well. I showed my student ID and got 50% off.
Very interesting. Great overview on Latinamerican art. The temporary exhibitions were not that great at the time we visited it, bit the museum collection is worth a visit.

Modern, well designed in beautiful Palermo. Modern building with some fun surprises including a wooden park bench that goes "viral." Taking pictures is allowed and encourage. Don't miss the small, yet fun gift shop. They only take cash at the upstairs register, but will accept credit cards down in the gift shop. There is a pretty "confiteria" on the property.

Fine art gallery. Very interesting, impressive and diverse collection of art work from local and South Americam artists. I'm not a big fan of spending hours in museums and galleries and found MALBA to be the perfect size.
Modern art. Although the "M" in "Malba" doesn't stand for "modern", most of what we had time to see fell into that category. So, if you like it, it's great.

Amazing museum. I loved the Malba museum! We went on their 10 year birthday, so it was even free for us, but there are discounted days so find out which days they have special discount etc. The art was amazing and the whole design and look of the Malba is something to see.
One of the best museuns i ever saw. Well, Abaporu is there! And Marta Minujim exposition rocks! I loved her Carlos Gardel Ablaze!
Nice small collection. MALBA has a really nice small collection of Latin American modern art. Several pieces are memorable and the architecture of the building enhances the experience.

Best LA painting collection ever. Although the number of paintings exposed is not big enough (only one floor) and/or it is not an exaustive collection of LA Art, the Museum has the most representative LA Art paintings ever giving a complete frame of Latin American Arrt since 1910. A must see in BsAs.
great small museum. Great art (they even have a Frida). Very easy to navigate. Excellent cafe. The location is also great - you can walk easily to other spots.

Awesome!. Amazing art here. Frida Kahlo (sp?) self portrait, along with the famed Che Guevarra portrait, it may be the one that started it all. And a great exhibition going on now by Carlos Cruz-Diez, who is amazingly talented. It's a beautiful piece of architecture in its own right, and just the right size for a museum that's interesting, but doesn't have to consume a whole day or more to see. Highly recommended.
Skip It. If you have limited time skip this museum. Very few pieces of art were worth seeing and the museum is quite small. Also the fee to get in was high by Buenos Aires standards.

Good Latin American art sample. This museum has relevant art of the most representative modern and contemporary Latin American artists. You can have an idea of how these artists were trying to represent and change the world. It's located in the beautiful and green nieghborhoud of Palermo. Besides, there is a nice restaurant of international food at the first floor, you won't regreat to try.

Fantastic way to spend a couple hours!. MALBA is truly an awesome art museum. The collection, while most of it is more modern, is fantastic (and if you love modern art like me, this place is even better!). One of the coolest installations in this museum is the two benches... One on the top floor and one on the middle floor, that are "connected". You would only know what I mean if you see it. Even though photos weren't allowed, I managed to sneak a couple of this bench, which I will post later. Great museum though, and a must-see in BA!

\Lovely collection in a worderful building. We had a great time at Malba!Very important collection of Latin American art and also itinerant exibitions should not be missed.We always visit there when in Buenos \Aires

Impressive museum in Buenos Aires.. We spent a rainy and windy afternoon at the MALBA, Museum of Latin American Art. It was a nice break from the shopping and offered some interesting insight into Latin American culture and some of the local artists who have influenced art throughout the region. Though I am not generally a "museum-fanatic", the MALBA is a modern facility with lots of open space for the various collections and exhibits, and was a well-spent 2 hour visit. It reminded me of a mini-version of the MET with a touch of Guggenheim. We topped the visit off with a delicious afternoon snack at the museum´s cafe (yes, there was wi-fi.) One of the assistants at the MALBA told us that in the evenings they have a theater that features a variety of movies- including local Argentine, South American and even classic US movies from the 50s for about $8 US!

Best Museum in BA. This is, wihout question, the best museum in Buenos Aires, a city where the museums are, fir the most part, mediocre. We enjoyed, in particular, the exhibit of recent art from Argentina.

Museum Collection and Cafe are equally wonderful!!. My friend and I love to visit museums when we travel, both for the art and to check out the cafes which are often a great value and interesting ambiance for a lunch dining experience. The MALBA cafe did not disappoint us on either of those fronts; the art was great, very fun and interesting, The wooden benches with vines of wood extending over the railing and down two floors is spectacular! My favorite piece was a painting by Brazilian artist Tarsila Do Araral, yet there were many other pieces that really moved me...The MALBA cafe is not to be missed; I recommend that you plan a museum visit around lunch or even just tea--the drinks come with beautifully arranged plates of pastries or appetizer-type snacks (see photos, taken w/mobile phone). Design is one of my favorite forms of art, and this cafe is a splendid example of outstanding interior design, as well as cuisine design (if that's even a term! :) Make sure you check the hours before you go, the cafe opens before the museum--which opens late--as I recall. Enjoy.

Mixture of many different styles of art. My husband and i visited this museum today as a part of our city tour. The museum was clean, neat, organized and well light. The art on the second floor was my favorite because it included some more recognizable artists. I am not an art expert by any means. The last floor is full of modern art, which is definitely not my style. However, the displays were done well and it was interesting to discuss the concept of art with my husband. There is a small cafe and store on the bottom floor. The store was overpriced and the cafe wifi did not work with our phones.

Quite interesting!. Visiting the MALBA was my first experience at an art museum in Latin America. The place is really nice, and full of tourists and Argentines a like (but mostly tourists like me!). They had some impressive paintings from Frida Kahlo, and also one from Andy Warhol. I'm not much of a museum person, but I had a great time strolling around MALBA looking at the lovely pieces (and people watching as well). This isn't a MUST DO IN BA ALERT, but definitely something fun if you're into this sort of thing!Plus it's cheap!
Thought I was in nyc. Fabulous collection of art, wonderful new building and cafe too!! If you love are go, it's a must them after walk to the Japanese gardens! Such a beautiful part of ba

Great quality & small collection, well worth a visit at 22ArgPesos. The two floors of this building are impressivley modern as is its swish cafe/restaurant which you can enjoy without entering the gallery. Not a huge display but I really enjoyed the top quality 1960s-80s exhibits.

Fascinating museum with outstanding ans inovative exhibitions!. The museum is not very large and you can visit it thoroughly in about 1,5 hour. The exhibition is very interesting and full of inovative and creative modern art. I certainly recommend and it´s a must for those who visit Bs.As.

Pretty Good.... I`m normally not a huge fan of modern art, but this musuem had a number of interesting things to see... The had original Andy Warhol paintings and pictures, and an original Frida Kahlo painting which stood out from the rest, so I was happy about that since I`m a huge fan of hers....It`s really cheap and great for a first date or relaxing setting on a Sunday afternoon. Be sure to check out the Japanese Garden across the street, too.

The MOMA Sister-Brother in Buenos Aires. This place is the heart of modern art in Buenos Aires. I was glad to see so many foreign visitors there. When I visited they had a retrospective of artists from the early 20th century -mexicans, cubans and central americans. Plus the permanent collection is something not to miss. the building itself is also very interesting. There is a discount for persons over 60, and it is not allowed to take photos, which i found quite sad, as the building was quite interesting.The coffee shop is OK, but hugely overprized.

Great for art lovers. A wonderful collection of Latin American art. The space inside the museum is beautiful and had an airy feeling to it. Admission was regularly 15 pesos, but only 5 pesos on Wednesdays. I definitely recommend this for art lovers.

Small but nice museum. Malba is a small but nice museum of modern art, mostly with Argentine artists. You can spend there an hour or two, but not more, as it has just two floors. They have beautiful artwork.The cafeteria in the basement is far too expensive for Argentine standards. Whereas the admission fee for the museum is reasonable, the cafeteria is a rib-off. They pretend to be a French Cafe, with croissants etc, but in the end it is an Argentine cafeteria.

For Arts sake. i have spent a month in Argentina and Uruguay from mid April to mid May 2010.Melba was definitely one of my personal highlights in a country with many high lights . Their permanent collection is one of the finest exhibitions contemporary Art where . A real high light at the time i visited was an exhibition from the National gallery of Cuba . This exhibition complemented the collection and open my eyes to more of the creative talent of this embargoed land .Melba would be on my list of galleries to check out again should i be able to return to Argentina ..
A must see. A little but wonderful museu, with very important paintings.On Wednesdays the admission is free.

English pamphlet on second floor. You will find an english pamphlet with discriptions of the various decades of Latin American art in the 20th century to the left as you get off the escalator on the second floor. This was our favorite art museum in Buenos Aries. The building is beautiful as is the collection and its presentation. The museum cafe has a lovely patio to enjoy a pre or post museum coffee or meal. Try to go on a Wednesday when the ammision is 5 rather than 15 pesos.On a furture note, if you enjoy the work of Xul Soalr at the MALBA then I think you would also enjoy a visit to Museo Xul Solar which is a small collection of his work in a multi level home in once occupied.

Beautiful space, no English explanations. The MALBA building is beautiful, as is the neighborhood. However, I prefer going to museums where I can either read or listen to information about the art in addition to seeing it. They had nothing of the sort at MALBA (in any language), which seemed strange to me given its status as a top museum in the city. I was hoping for either a detailed guide book or an audio tour. I appreciate art, but understand the significance behind the works much more when I have an explanation. For that reason, I was disappointed in our outing there and won't recommend it to our English-speaking visitors when they arrive. The building is beautiful and there are well-known artists who have paintings on display; however, I didn't walk away with a greater understanding of Latin American art from my visit.

Small but meaningful. Remembering it started as a private collection (gathered by Eduardo Constantini), just like Calouste Gulbekian in Lisbon, helps you understand the importance of this museum, if you start getting disappointed by its small permanent collection.Its size is not only a result of its VERY SPECIFIC approach (20th century latin american art) but of Constantini's accurate perception. He chose (and could afford) some of the finest examples of contemporary art in the continent.Besides the Latin American artists known in the whole world, like colombian Fernando Botero and mexicans Diego Rivera and Frida Kahlo, it shows important pieces from the best 20th century painters in each country, like Tarsila do Amaral (her masterpiece Abaporu), Candido Portinari and Emiliano Di Cavalcanti, from Brazil, and Alejandro Xul Solar and Antonio Berni, from Argentina, to name a few.

It's a must!. The MALBA is the best museum in Argentina if what you're looking forward to do is to get in contact with the best latinamerican arts and artists. Its building shows an exquisite taste for modern architecture with a beautiful facade. It also organizes interesting courses related to literature and arts.

good cultural addition for you and the family. Great museum that is large enough without feeling unmanageable. Art work is wonderful with many famous pieces including Kahlo, Rivera, and other well known Latin American Artists. Only need about 30 minutes to see the whole thing, and a wonderful museum, recently having undergone a 13 million dollar renovation.

Good Introduction to Latin American Art. I had my reservations after reading some so-so reviews of this museum. I decided to give it a try anyway since I was in the area. I paid 5 pesos per person instead of the usual 15 pesos ( It was a Wednesday). I figured what could go wrong with 5 pesos.I was happily surprised with the airy atrium. There were a lot of people visiting that afternoon but I did not feel cramped in the museum. I saw paintings by Xul Solar, Frida Kahlo, Diego Rivera just to name a few. There was also a photography exhibition by Manual Alvaraz Bravo. The intertwined wooden bench by Pablo Reinoso was very interesting as the structure went into different floors. There were guided tours available but I arrived a little late for those. Instead I took a break at the museum cafe and had my beef pita bread sandwich and a cappucino. I finished off my visit with a quick browse in the museum shop and was surprised to find a quiet bookstore downstairs. The museum is very manageable and can be easily seen in 2-3 hours. 5 pesos or 15 pesos, it was still worth a visit. I felt I got a good introduction to Latin American Art.

You could probably skip this.... So we had read RAVE reviews about MALBA, so we went to check it out. I am not much of an art buff, so this review may be biased, but I found this visit to be a waste of time. The building is beautiful and immaculate, but I would def skip this if you 1) aren't really into art or 2) short on time. I guess I am a bit confused by what Modern Art is, and it can range from random splashes of color on a canvas to currency embedded onto a canvas. not my cup of tea - but then again, different strokes for different folks! (no pun intended!)

Even the Building is Art. I had no idea what contemporary Latin American Art looked like, but after a visit to this compact collection housed in a spare and airy space I feel like I have a good foundation. It is possible to see the entire collection in less than two hours. The building with its all white interior and 3 story atrium, is nice piece of modern architecture (but no threat to the status NY’s Guggenheim). In addition, the café serves fresh and tasty snacks, lunches and delicious coffee. There is comfy seating indoors and a terrace outside for enjoying good weather. So, even if you’re not a big fan of contemporary art, it’s a very pleasant way to spend a few hours. Note: Guide books tout the gift shop, but I didn't think it contained anything particularly unique or clever.

I was disapoiinted.. Overview:This museum is located in a new modern impressive building. It has a neat noise meter in front of the building that kind of resembles a traffic light. This museum houses a number of modern works of art, although the collection is small. The cost to visit in 0ctober 2008 was 15 pesos.Good:There were some nice works of art, but not a lot. I personally found that the building architecture was one of the best parts of the museum.Bad: Small museum. Not a lot of exhibits. And of all of the exhibits I found few good ones (but then again I am an average joe and not an art critic.).My opinion:If you are a TRUE fan of modern art, then this is a must see. If you are a fan of art, or just a tourist, then there are far better art museums (like Museo de Belles Artes) to see in Buenos Aires. Only visit this museum when you have exhausted all other options.Please take time to rate my review. Thanks!
Art and great architecture...... Worth a visit if only to see the building itself. Great space and some interesting work. Definitely worth the time to visit.

Another Palermo Delight. I enjoyed this fine art museum geared to those who appreciate twentieth century Latin American Art. I saw splendid paintings by Diego Rivera,Frida Kahlo,Joaquin Torres-Garcia,Jose Cuneo,Tarsila Do Amaral,and Emilio Di Cavalcanti just to mention a few. Argentines well-represented were Antonio Berni,Xul Solar,and Alfredo Guttero. My favorite painting was Berni's "Chelsea Hotel". This museum is also a splendid work of architecture located in very copacetic Palermo. It also has a fine cafe to enjoy coffee and medialunas.
Ok...to skip on your trip to BsAs. MALBA was supposedly a free museum, however it costs 20 pesos per person. Worth 20 pesos for sure, but irritated over their claim of free admission.Very small.
